1059142_11_ITEM7_P96_S5	The property is current on principal and interest payments on the Partnership's bond as of December 31, 2010 .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P97_S0	Woodland Park - The Partnership has identified circumstances which indicate that certain actions may be necessary to protect the Partnership's position as a secured bondholder of the Woodland Park tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and taxable lender.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P97_S1	As of December 31, 2010 , Woodland Park owes the Partnership approximately $15.7 million under tax-exempt bonds and approximately $914,000 under taxable loans.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P97_S2	The construction of Woodland Park was completed in November 2008 and lease-up continues, however, the property has not yet reached stabilization which is defined in the bond documents as the generation of a 1.15:1 debt service coverage ratio for six straight months.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P97_S3	Additionally, there were insufficient funds on deposit with the bond trustee to make the debt service payment of approximately $452,000 on the bonds which was due on May 3, 2010 and the property owner did not provide additional capital to fund the shortfall.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P98_S0	In order to protect its investment, the Partnership issued a formal notice of default through the bond trustee and started the foreclosure process.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P98_S1	The foreclosure process is expected to be complete in the first half of 2011.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P98_S2	This action will allow a new property owner to re-syndicate the LIHTCs associated with this property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P98_S3	If the LIHTCs can be successfully re-syndicated, it will provide additional capital to the project which can be used to support debt service payments on the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds until property operations improve to the point that sufficient cash is generated to pay any past due amounts on the bonds as well as ongoing debt service.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P98_S4	If the re-syndication is not successful the Partnership may pursue other options including making additional taxable loans to the property or completing the foreclosure process and taking direct ownership of the property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P99_S0	The Partnership believes that the most significant issue in the slow lease-up of the property and its failure to achieve stabilization has been the 100% set aside of the rental units for tenants that make less than 60% of the area median income.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P99_S1	At the request of the Partnership, in April 2010, the property owner reduced the number of units set aside for affordable tenants to 75% and began leasing 59 units to market rate tenants.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P99_S2	Additionally, the property owner has agreed that, if needed to stabilize the property, it would further reduce the units set aside for affordable tenants to 60% thereby making an additional 35 units available to market rate tenants.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P99_S3	As of December 31, 2009, the property had 116 units leased out of total available units of 236, or 49% physical occupancy.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P99_S4	As of December 31, 2010, the property had 190 units leased out of total available units of 236, or 81% physical occupancy.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P99_S5	Based on the level of leasing activity resulting from the change in the mix of affordable and market rate tenants, the Partnership continues to believe that Woodland is capable of reaching stabilization.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P100_S0	The Partnership has evaluated this bond holding, as part of the evaluation of its entire investment portfolio, for an other-than-temporary decline in value as of December 31, 2010 (see Note 2 for discussion of our impairment testing method).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P100_S1	Based on this evaluation, the Partnership has concluded that no other-than-temporary impairment of this bond existed at December 31, 2010 .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P101_S0	Our ability to recover the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds entire amortized cost basis is dependent upon the issuer being able to meet debt service requirements.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P102_S0	The primary source of repayment is the cash flows produced by the property which serves as the collateral for the bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P102_S1	The Company utilizes a discounted cash flow model for the underlying property and compares the results of the model to the amortized cost basis of the bond.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P102_S2	If the discounted cash flows from a property are less than the amortized cost of the bond, we believe that there is a strong indication that the cash flows from the property will not support the payment of the required principle and interest on the bond and, accordingly, the bonds are considered other-than-temporarily impaired.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P102_S3	These models reflect the cash flows expected to be generated by the underlying properties over a ten year period, including an assumed property sale at the end of year ten, discounted using the effective interest rate which is equal to the stated rate on the bonds as they were purchased at par in accordance with the accounting guidance on other than temporary impairment of debt securities.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P103_S0	The inputs to these models require management to make assumptions the most significant of which include:
1059142_11_ITEM7_P104_S0	Revenue and expense projections for the property operations, which result in the estimated net operating income generated over the ten year holding period assumed in the model.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P105_S0	Base year (model year one) assumptions are based on historical financial results and operating budget information.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P106_S0	The capitalization rate utilized to estimate the sales proceeds from an assumed property sale in year ten of the model.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P106_S1	The capitalization rate used in the current year models was 7.0% which the Partnership believes represents a reasonable market rate for multifamily properties.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P107_S0	The revenue, expense and resulting net operating income projections which are the basis for the discounted cash flow model are based on judgment.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P108_S0	Operating results from a multifamily residential property depend on the rental and occupancy rates of the property and the level of operating expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P109_S0	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, apartments in the market areas in which a property is located.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P109_S1	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and interest rates on single-family mortgage loans.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P109_S2	In addition, factors such as government regulation, inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of a property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P110_S0	The various revenue and expense projections for this property's operations are summarized as follows:
1059142_11_ITEM7_P111_S0	Woodland Park - Revenue and expenses for model year one (2011) are equal to the property budget.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P111_S1	Budgeted revenues of approximately $1.7 million are based on a budgeted average occupancy of 88%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P111_S2	Revenues are projected to grow over the ten years in the model to approximately $2.2 million in year ten based on average annual rental increases of 2% and an average occupancy increasing over time to 93%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P111_S3	Expenses are projected to grow to approximately $1.0 million in year ten based on average annual increases of 2.5%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P112_S0	In addition to the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond held by the Company, a taxable loan has been made to the owners of this property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P112_S1	The Partnership has evaluated this taxable property loan for potential impairment as of December 31, 2010 (see Note 2 for discussion of our impairment testing method).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P113_S0	The repayment of this loan is dependent largely on the value of the property which collateralizes the loan.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P113_S1	The Company periodically evaluates the loan for potential losses by estimating the fair value of the property which collateralizes the loan.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P114_S0	The Company utilizes the discounted cash flow model discussed above except that in estimating a property fair value we consider a number of different discounted cash flow models that contain varying assumptions.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P114_S1	The various models may assume multiple revenue and expense scenarios, various capitalization rates and multiple discount rates.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P114_S2	We may also consider other information such as independent appraisals in estimating a property fair value.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P114_S3	If the estimated fair value of the property after deducting the amortized cost basis of the senior tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond exceeds the principal balance of the property loan then no potential loss is indicated and no allowance for loan loss is needed.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P115_S0	In estimating the property valuation for the current year, the most significant assumptions utilized in the discounted cash flow model were the same as discussed above except that the specific discount rate used to estimate the property valuation in the current year models was approximately 6.5% which the Partnership believes represents a rate at which a multifamily property could obtain current tax-exempt financing similar to the current existing outstanding bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P116_S0	In addition to the discounted cash flow models utilized to estimate the property valuation, the Company obtained an independent appraisal for this property in February 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P116_S1	Based on the results of the discounted cash flow model and an evaluation of the appraisal the Partnership has estimated the property value for Woodland Park which collateralizes the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond and the taxable loan to be approximately $16.8 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P117_S0	Based on this estimated property valuation and after subtracting the amortized cost of the tax-exempt bond, the Partnership recorded an allowance for loan loss of approximately $700,000 in 2009 and an additional allowance of approximately $200,000 in 2010 to reserve for the entire taxable loan balance due from Woodland Park.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P117_S1	The Partnership will continue to monitor this investment for changes in circumstances that might warrant an impairment charge.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P118_S0	The owners of the following properties have been determined to meet the definition of a VIE and the Partnership has been determined to be the Primary Beneficiary.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P118_S1	As a result, the Company reports the assets, liabilities and results of operations of these properties on a consolidated basis.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P119_S0	Bent Tree - Bent Tree Apartments is located in Columbia, South Carolina and contains 232 units.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P120_S0	The tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds owned by the Partnership are traditional 80/20 bonds issued prior to the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P120_S1	These bonds require that 20% of the rental units be set aside for tenants whose income does not exceed 80% of the area median income, without adjustment for household size.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P120_S2	The bond has an outstanding principal amount of $7.7 million and has a base interest rate of 6.25% per annum.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P120_S3	The bond also provides for contingent interest payable from excess cash flow generated by the underlying property through the potential payment of contingent interest.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P120_S4	The bond accrues contingent interest at a rate of 1.9% annually and such contingent interest is payable only if the underlying property generates excess operating cash flows or realizes excess cash through capital appreciation and a related sale or refinancing of the property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P120_S5	To date, the property has not paid any contingent interest and the Partnership has not recognized any contingent interest income related to this bond.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P120_S6	However, the property is current on the payment of principal and base interest on the Partnership's bond as of December 31, 2010 .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P120_S7	Bent Tree's operations resulted in net operating income of $557,000 and $531,000 before payment of bond debt service on net revenue of approximately $1.5 million and $1.5 million in 2010 and 2009 , respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P120_S8	The increase in net operating income is a net result of decreased insurance and utilities expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P121_S0	Fairmont Oaks - Fairmont Oaks Apartments is located in Gainesville, Florida and contains 178 units.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P122_S0	The tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds owned by the Partnership are traditional 80/20 bonds issued prior to the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P122_S1	These bonds require that 20% of the rental units be set aside for tenants whose income does not exceed 80% of the area median income, without adjustment for household size.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P122_S2	The bond has an outstanding principal amount of $7.6 million and has a base interest rate of 6.3% per annum.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P122_S3	The bond also provides for contingent interest payable from excess cash flow generated by the underlying property through the potential payment of contingent interest.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P122_S4	The bond accrues contingent interest at a rate of 2.2% annually and such contingent interest is payable only if the underlying property generates excess operating cash flows or realizes excess cash through capital appreciation and a related sale or refinancing of the property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P122_S5	To date, the Partnership has realized $57,000 in contingent interest income related to this bond.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P122_S6	The property is current on the payment of principal and base interest on the Partnership's bond as of December 31, 2010 .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P122_S7	Fairmont Oak's operations resulted in net operating income of $630,000 and $715,000 before payment of bond debt service on net revenue of approximately $1.4 million and $1.5 million in 2010 and 2009 , respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P122_S8	The decrease in net operating income is the result of lower economic occupancy.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P123_S0	Iona Lakes - Iona Lakes Apartments is located in Fort Myers, Florida and contains 350 units.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P124_S0	The tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds owned by the Partnership are traditional 80/20 bonds issued prior to the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P124_S1	These bonds require that 20% of the rental units be set aside for tenants whose income does not exceed 80% of the area median income, without adjustment for household size.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P124_S2	The bond has an outstanding principal amount of $15.9 million and has a base interest rate of 6.9% per annum.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P124_S3	The bond also provides for contingent interest payable from excess cash flow generated by the underlying property through the potential payment of contingent interest.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P124_S4	The bond accrues contingent interest at a rate of 2.6% annually and such contingent interest is payable only if the underlying property generates excess operating cash flows or realizes excess cash through capital appreciation and a related sale or refinancing of the property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P124_S5	To date, the Partnership has realized $8,000 contingent interest income related to this bond.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P124_S6	The property is current on the payment of principal and base interest on the Partnership's bond as of December 31, 2010 .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P124_S7	Iona Lake's operations resulted in net operating income of $931,000 and $804,000 before payment of bond debt service on net revenue of approximately $2.5 million and $2.3 million in 2010 and 2009 , respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P124_S8	The increase in net operating income was a result of an increase in economic occupancy as well as decreased salary expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P125_S0	Lake Forest - Lake Forest Apartments is located in Daytona Beach, Florida and contains 240 units.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P126_S0	The tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds owned by the Partnership are traditional 80/20 bonds issued prior to the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P126_S1	These bonds require that 20% of the rental units be set aside for tenants whose income does not exceed 80% of the area median income, without adjustment for household size.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P126_S2	The bond has an outstanding principal amount of $9.3 million and has a base interest rate of 6.25% per annum.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P126_S3	The bond also provides for contingent interest payable from excess cash flow generated by the underlying property through the potential payment of contingent interest.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P126_S4	The bond accrues contingent interest at a rate of 1.6% annually and such contingent interest is payable only if the underlying property generates excess operating cash flows or realizes excess cash through capital appreciation and a related sale or refinancing of the property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P126_S5	To date, the Partnership has realized approximately $19,000 of contingent interest income related to this bond.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P126_S6	The property is current on the payment of principal and base interest on the Partnership's bonds as of December 31, 2010 .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P126_S7	Lake Forest's operations resulted in net operating income of $676,000 and $723,000 before payment of bond debt service on net revenue of approximately $1.8 million and $1.8 million in 2010 and 2009 , respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P126_S8	The decrease in net operating income is a result of increases in utilities and repair and maintenance expense.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P127_S0	Residences at DeCordova and Residences at Weatherford are bond holdings for which these ownership entities meet the Consolidated VIE definition.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P127_S1	Based on an accumulation of individual circumstances, the Partnership has identified that DeCordova and Weatherford's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds are in a position for which certain actions may be necessary to protect the Partnership's position as a secured bondholder and lender.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P127_S2	As of December 31, 2010 , DeCordova owes the Partnership approximately $4.9 million under tax-exempt bonds and $648,000 under taxable loans and Weatherford owes the Partnership approximately $4.7 million under tax-exempt bonds and $1.1 million under taxable loans.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P127_S3	The following is a discussion of the circumstances related to each of these bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P127_S4	As both of these entities meet the Consolidated VIE definition the bonds discussed below are eliminated in consolidation.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P128_S0	The construction of Residences at DeCordova was completed in April 2009 and lease-up continues, however, the property has not yet reached stabilization which is defined in the bond documents as the generation of a 1.15:1 debt service coverage ratio for six straight months.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P128_S1	As result of the failure to reach stabilization, the bond is in technical default.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P129_S0	As of December 31, 2010, the property had 65 units leased out of total available units of 76, or 86% physical occupancy.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P130_S0	This property is a senior (55+) affordable housing project located in Granbury, Texas in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P130_S1	The Partnership believes the most significant issue in the slow lease-up of the property is the current single family housing market in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P130_S2	Many potential tenants must first sell their existing home before they are able to move into a rental unit.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P131_S0	In September 2009, the Partnership was notified by the tax credit limited partner of the owner of Residences at DeCordova of its intent to withdraw from the limited partnership.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P131_S1	In January 2010, the Partnership concluded its best course of action for the removal of the current limited partner was to issue a Notice of Default through the bond trustee and to begin foreclosure procedures.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P131_S2	Such notice was issued in February 2010 and the foreclosure was completed in March 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P131_S3	Through this process the Partnership removed the limited partner which will allow the property owner to re-syndicate the LIHTCs to a new limited partner thereby providing additional capital to the project.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P131_S4	The underwriting estimate of LIHTCs to be generated by this property that would be available for re-syndication is approximately $2.8 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P131_S5	The syndication of the LIHTCs, at an amount less than the gross credits generated, would provide additional capital for the project in the form of new limited partner equity.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P131_S6	The Partnership believes that, if this can be accomplished, such new equity would be sufficient to allow for the current bonds to remain in place and operations be funded through an extended lease-up period.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P132_S0	The property continued to experience slow lease-up and was unable to re-syndicate the LIHTCs.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P132_S1	As a result, in December 2010, the Partnership issued a second Notice of Default through the bond trustee to begin foreclosure procedures in order to remove both the general partner and the limited partner and take ownership of the property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P132_S2	This second foreclosure was completed in February 2011 at which time the ownership of the property was taken by the Partnership.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P132_S3	At this time the Partnership expects to operate the property as a market rate apartment property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P133_S0	leased up and stabilized the Partnership will evaluate its options in order to recoup its investment in DeCordova.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P134_S0	Residences at Weatherford are currently under construction and will contain 76 units upon completion.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P135_S0	This property is a senior (55+) affordable housing project located in Weatherford, Texas in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P135_S1	At this time infrastructure construction activities have been substantially completed but no construction has begun on the actual apartment buildings.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S0	In January 2010, the Partnership issued a Notice of Default through the bond trustee and began foreclosure procedures to remove the limited partner.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S1	Such notice was issued in February 2010 and the foreclosure was completed in March 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S2	At that time the general partner was allowed to continue in that capacity and a new limited partner was admitted.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S3	The foreclosure was a reconsideration event under the variable interest entity guidance and as a result of the reevaluation, the bond was eliminated and the entity that owns the property was consolidated as a VIE effective in March 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S4	Through this process the Partnership anticipated that the new property owner would recapitalize the property by pursuing an alternative plan of financing.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S5	Specifically, the Partnership worked with the general partner of the owner to identify available Tax Credit Assistance Program ( TCAP ) funding through application to the Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs ( TDHCA ).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S6	In March 2010, a TCAP Written Agreement with TDHCA was approved and entered into which committed TCAP funds to the project pending the completion of formal agreements.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S7	Formal agreements and funding were originally expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2010; however, the process was delayed due to the large number of transactions to be closed by TDHCA.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S8	During the delay TDHCA identified certain issues in funding and compliance with other projects in which the General Partner of Residences at Weatherford is involved.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S9	As a result of these issues, in October 2010, TDHCA issued a Notice of Termination of TCAP Funding to the General Partner.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S10	Together with the General Partner, the Company unsuccessfully appealed the termination.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S11	Based on the termination notice, the Company has determined that the property fixed assets of Residences at Weatherford and the associated tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond which is eliminated in consolidation were impaired.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S12	As of December 31, 2010 the property fixed assets, consisting of land and land improvements, and the associated tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond owned by the Partnership have been written down.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P136_S13	The resulting impairment charge and provision for loan losses of approximately $3.3 million is attributable to the unitholders.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P137_S0	As a result of the failure of the property owner to secure an alternative plan of financing, the Partnership issued a second Notice of Default through the bond trustee to begin foreclosure procedures in order to remove both the general partner and the limited partner and take ownership of the property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P137_S1	This second foreclosure was completed in February 2011 at which time the ownership of the property was taken by the Partnership.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P137_S2	The Partnership has taken over the project and intends to fund the construction and stabilization of the project.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P137_S3	Upon the completion of construction the Partnership expects to operate the property as a market rate apartment property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P137_S4	Once the property is leased up and stabilized the Partnership will evaluate its options in order to recoup its investment in Weatherford.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P138_S0	The Partnership evaluated the DeCordova bond, as part of the evaluation of its entire investment portfolio, for an other-than-temporary decline in value as of December 31, 2010 (see Note 2 for discussion of our impairment testing method).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P138_S1	Based on this evaluation, the Partnership has concluded that no other-than-temporary impairment of the DeCordova bond existed at December 31, 2010 .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P139_S0	As noted above, the Weatherford bond and related taxable loan were written down in third quarter, 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P140_S0	The process and models utilized by the Company to evaluate bonds for impairment is described above.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P140_S1	The various revenue and expense projections utilized in the valuation model for DeCordova are summarized as follows:
1059142_11_ITEM7_P141_S0	Revenue and expenses for model year one (2011) are equal to the property budget.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P141_S1	Budgeted revenues of approximately $580,000 are based on a budgeted average occupancy of 90%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P141_S2	Revenues are projected to grow over the ten years in the model to approximately $710,000 in year ten based on average annual rental increases of 2% and an average occupancy increasing over time to 93%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P141_S3	Expenses are projected to grow to approximately $307,000 in year ten based on average annual increases of 2.5%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P142_S0	In addition to the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond held by the Company, taxable loans have been made to the owners of DeCordova.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P142_S1	The Partnership has evaluated these taxable property loans for potential impairment as of December 31, 2010 as described above (see Note 2 for discussion of our impairment testing method).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P142_S2	Based on the results of the discounted cash flow model and an evaluation of an appraisal completed in 2010, the Partnership has estimated the property value for the DeCordova property collateralizing the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond and the taxable loans at $5.9 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P143_S0	Based on this estimated property valuation and after subtracting the amortized cost of the tax-exempt bonds, the Partnership has concluded there is no impairment of the taxable loans made to DeCordova.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P143_S1	The Partnership will continue to monitor these investments for changes in circumstances that might warrant an impairment charge.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P144_S0	The Partnership holds an indirect 99% interest in the owners of each of the following properties.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P144_S1	These properties are encumbered by mortgage loans with an aggregate principal balance of $10.6 million at December 31, 2010 .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P144_S2	There are no tax-exempt bonds currently secured by these properties.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P149_S0	Meadowview - Meadowview Apartments is located in Highland Heights, Kentucky and contains 118 units and was acquired in July 2007.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P149_S1	The consolidation of Meadowview's operations resulted in recognition by the Company of net operating income of $368,000 and $355,000 on net revenue of approximately $864,000 and $819,000 in 2010 and 2009 respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P149_S2	The increase in net operating income is the result of increased economic occupancy and decreased salary and repair and maintenance expenses which was offset by an increase in utilities expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S0	In June 2010, the Company completed a sales transaction whereby four of the MF Properties, Crescent Village, Post Woods (I and II) and Willow Bend apartments in Ohio (the Ohio Properties ), were sold to three new ownership entities controlled by an unaffiliated not-for-profit entity.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S1	The Company acquired 100% of the $18.3 million tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds issued by the Ohio Housing Finance Agency as part of a plan of financing for the acquisition and rehabilitation of the Ohio Properties.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S2	The tax-exempt mortgage bonds secured by the Ohio Properties were acquired by the Company at par and consisted of two series.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S3	The Series A bond has a par value of $14.7 million and bears interest at an annual rate of 7.0%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S4	The Series B bond has a par value of $3.6 million and bears interest at an annual interest rate of 10.0%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S5	Both series of bonds mature in June 2050.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S6	The Company had previously acquired a 99% interest in the Ohio Properties as part of its strategy of acquiring existing multifamily apartment properties that it expects will be partially financed with new tax-exempt mortgage bonds at the time the properties become eligible for the issuance of additional low-income housing tax credits.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S7	In addition to the new tax-exempt bonds acquired by the Company, the plan of financing for the acquisition included other subordinated debt issued by the Company.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S8	The new owners ultimately plan to sell limited partnership interests in the properties and syndicate LIHTCs as part of the overall plan of finance.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P150_S9	The new owners have not contributed any capital to the transaction and the Company has effectively provided 100% of the capital structure to the new owners as part of the sale transaction.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P151_S0	Pursuant to Property, Plant, and Equipment - Real Estate Sales guidance the sale and restructure does not meet the criteria for derecognition of the properties or full accrual accounting for the gain.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P151_S1	The guidance requires sufficient equity capital as part of a sales transaction to indicate a commitment from the buyer (typically a minimum of 3 to 5% investment by the new owners).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P151_S2	As the buyer has no equity capital in this transaction and the property operations are the current support for the debt service, the Company, in substance, remains the owner for accounting purposes.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P151_S3	As such, the Company will continue to consolidate the Ohio Properties as if the sale was not completed.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P151_S4	Under the sales agreement, the Ohio properties were sold for a total purchase price of $16.2 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P151_S5	Cash received by the selling limited partnerships as part of the sale transaction represents a gain on the sale transaction of approximately $1.8 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P151_S6	The properties will continue to be presented as MF Properties and no gain will be recognized until such time as the transaction meets the criteria for derecognition of the properties and gain recognition (See Note 5 and 6).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P152_S0	The following is a discussion of the operating results for the three Ohio Properties.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P153_S0	Crescent Village - Crescent Village Townhomes is located in Cincinnati, Ohio and contains 90 units and was acquired in July 2007.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P153_S1	The consolidation of Crescent Village's operations resulted in recognition by the Company of net operating income of $146,000 and $366,000 on net revenue of approximately $726,000 and $749,000 in 2010 and 2009 , respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P153_S2	The decrease in net operating income is the result of decreased occupancy along with an increase in utility and administration expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P153_S3	Crescent Village also paid a one-time administration fee to AFCA2.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P154_S0	Post Woods - Post Woods Townhomes is located in Reynoldsburg, Ohio and contains 180 units and was acquired in July 2007.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P154_S1	The consolidation of Post Woods' operations resulted in the recognition by the Company of net operating income of $344,000 and $683,000 on net revenue of approximately $1.4 million and $1.4 million in 2010 and 2009 respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P154_S2	The decrease in net operating income is a result of an increase in advertising and utilities expense.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P154_S3	Post Woods also paid a one-time administration fee to AFCA2.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P155_S0	Willow Bend - Willow Bend Townhomes is located in Columbus (Hilliard), Ohio and contains 92 units and was acquired in July 2007.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P155_S1	The consolidation of Willow Bend's operations resulted in recognition by the Company of net operating income of $157,000 and $343,000 on net revenue of approximately $776,000 and $795,000 in 2010 and 2009 , respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P155_S2	The decrease in net operating income is the result of decreased economic occupancy and increased utility expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P155_S3	Willow Bend also paid a one-time administration fee to AFCA2.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P156_S0	The tables below compare the results of operations for the Company for 2010 , 2009 , and 2008 :
1059142_11_ITEM7_P157_S0	Property revenues of the Company consist of those of the MF Properties as well as the six Consolidated VIEs treated as continuing operations during the periods.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P157_S1	Property revenues decreased approximately $1.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to the year ended December 31, 2009 mainly as a result of Ashley Square and Cross Creek Apartments no longer being reported as Consolidated VIEs in 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P158_S0	properties were included in property revenues reported by the Company in 2010 compared to approximately $1.5 million of property revenues from these properties that were reported in 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P158_S1	The decline in property revenue due to the deconsolidation of Ashley Square and Cross Creek was partially offset by an increase of approximately $300,000 in property revenues generated by Residences at DeCordova which became a Consolidated VIE on March 1, 2010 and general improvements in economic occupancy.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P158_S2	Annual net rental revenues per unit related to the MF Properties increased to $7,295 per unit in 2010 from $7,119 in 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P158_S3	The annual net rental revenues per unit related to the Consolidated VIEs increased to approximately $6,920 in 2010 from approximately $6,216 in 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P159_S0	Mortgage revenue bond investment income of the Company consists of the interest income earned only on the mortgage revenue bonds that were not issued to finance properties owned by Consolidated VIEs.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P159_S1	The deconsolidation of Ashley Square and Cross Creek Apartments increased investment income by approximately $962,000.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P159_S2	These properties are no longer treated as Consolidated VIEs as of January 1, 2010, therefore the interest paid to the Company on the tax-exempt bonds is no longer eliminated in consolidation.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P159_S3	In addition, the Company realized additional tax-exempt interest income of approximately $1.9 million due to the acquisition of four tax-exempt bonds, South Park Ranch Apartments, Brookstone Apartments, Villages at Lost Creek, and Autumn Pines that were not owned during 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P159_S4	These increases were offset by interest income from Residences at DeCordova and Residences at Weatherford which became Consolidated VIEs on March 1, 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P159_S5	The interest income related to these bonds is now eliminated in consolidation.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P159_S6	The elimination of DeCordova and Weatherford interest in 2010 totaled approximately $478,000.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P160_S0	Gain on assets held for sale.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P160_S1	In September 2009, the Partnership sold the Oak Grove Commons apartments, an asset held for sale, to an unaffiliated party for $3.75 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P160_S2	After the deduction of selling expenses, commissions, and cash advances made to the property, the Partnership realized a taxable gain of approximately $863,000 from the sale.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P160_S3	There was no similar transaction in 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P161_S0	Gain on early extinguishment of debt.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P161_S1	In June 2010, the Company had the opportunity to acquire at a discount, and thereby retire, the $12.8 million outstanding mortgage debt secured by the Ohio Properties.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P161_S2	The early extinguishment of this debt resulted in a gain of approximately $435,000.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P161_S3	There was no similar transaction in 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P162_S0	Other income is comprised mainly of interest income on taxable loans held by the Company.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P162_S1	The increase in other interest income is attributable to higher levels of taxable loans outstanding in 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P163_S0	When comparing 2010 to 2009, a decrease of approximately $1.3 million in real estate operating expenses is the result of the Ashley Square and Cross Creek Apartments deconsolidation.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P163_S1	This decrease was offset by approximately $428,000 of expenses related to the consolidation of Residences at DeCordova and Residences at Weatherford, an increase of approximately $231,000 in administrative fees, and an increase of approximately $376,000 of acquisition related costs incurred by the MF Properties.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P163_S2	The acquisition costs incurred in 2010 by the Ohio Property owners represent expenses of non-controlling interests.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P163_S3	In addition, there were increases in MF Property related market ready, insurance, and salary expense .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P164_S0	The Company periodically, or as changes in circumstances or operations dictate, evaluates its investments for impairment.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P164_S1	The value of the underlying property assets is ultimately the most relevant measure of value to support the investment carrying values.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P165_S0	Investments tested for impairment include all fixed assets, bond investments and taxable loans made to various properties and other amounts due to the Company.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P165_S1	Such evaluation is based on cash flow and discounted cash flow models.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P165_S2	The Company concluded that there was no impairment of fixed assets or bond investments as of December 31, 2010, except for the Residences of Weatherford as discussed below.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P165_S3	This evaluation determined that a portion of the taxable property loans was potentially impaired and that an additional allowance for bad debt should be recorded.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P165_S4	An allowance for bad debt and an associated provision for loan loss of approximately $212,000 and $700,000 was recorded against the Woodland Park taxable loan in 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P165_S5	In addition, during the fourth quarter of 2010, $350,000 was recorded as an allowance for bad debt and an associated provision for loan loss against the cross collateralized Ashley Square and Cross Creek taxable loans.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P165_S6	In 2009 the Company recorded a $700,000 allowance for bad debt against the judgment receivable related to the 2008 foreclosure on the Prairiebrook Village bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P166_S0	the Company has determined that the property fixed assets of Residences at Weatherford and the associated tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond which is eliminated in consolidation were impaired.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P166_S1	As of September 30, 2010 the property fixed assets, consisting of land and land improvements, and the associated tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond owned by the Partnership were written down.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P166_S2	The resulting impairment charge of approximately $2.5 million is attributable to the unitholders.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P166_S3	In February 2011, the Company foreclosed on the current ownership and will continue to develop the property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P167_S0	Depreciation and amortization consists primarily of depreciation associated with the apartment properties of the Consolidated VIEs and the MF Properties, amortization associated with in-place lease intangible assets recorded as part of the purchase accounting for the acquisition of MF Properties, and deferred finance cost amortization written off upon retirement of the BOA Credit Facility in addition to new amortization of finance costs related to the closing of the TEBS Credit Facility.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P167_S1	The decrease in depreciation and amortization expense from 2009 to 2010 is attributable to a decrease of approximately $96,000 in deferred financing cost amortization, a decrease of approximately $708,000 in in-place lease amortization, and an approximate $581,000 decrease due to deconsolidation of Ashley Square and Cross Creek Apartments.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P167_S2	These were offset by a depreciation expense increase of approximately $200,000 due the consolidation of Residences at DeCordova and an increase of approximately $177,000 due to depreciation on assets added to the existing MF Properties and Consolidated VIEs during 2010 .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P168_S0	The decrease in interest expense of $1.7 million in 2010 as compared to 2009 was due to offsetting factors.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P168_S1	Approximately $1.5 million of the decrease was a result of the mark to market adjustment of the Company's derivatives.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P168_S2	These interest rate derivatives do not qualify for hedge accounting and, accordingly, they are carried at fair value, with changes in fair value included in current period earnings within interest expense.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P168_S3	The remaining change in interest expense results from changes in the average outstanding debt throughout the year combined with changes in the Company's cost of borrowing.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P168_S4	The average outstanding debt decreased slightly while the average cost of borrowing increased slightly from approximately 3.5% per annum in 2009 to approximately 3.6% per annum in 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P169_S0	General and administrative expenses increased mainly due to increased professional fees and administration fees.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P169_S1	Professional fees increased approximately $258,000 due mainly to accounting, legal and other professional fees associated with the process the Company utilized to respond to a comment letter received by the Company from the Securities Exchange Commission in the first quarter of 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P169_S2	Additional professional fees were also incurred for accounting consultation regarding the implementation of new accounting standards in 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P169_S3	Administration fees paid to AFCA 2 increased approximately $335,000 as the Company has a higher level of invested assets and taxable loans in 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P169_S4	Offsetting these expenses was a reduction in reimbursable employee related costs paid to AFCA 2.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P170_S0	Property revenues of the Company consist of those of the MF Properties as well as the six VIEs treated as continuing operations during the periods.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P170_S1	Property revenues increased approximately $1.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2009 compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P170_S2	Approximately $2.3 million is attributable to the acquisition of the Commons at Churchland and Glynn Place Apartments acquired in the second half of 2008 and Greens of Pine Glen, acquired in the first quarter of 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P170_S3	Property revenues for the VIEs reported a net decrease of approximately $317,000 due to reduced occupancy at existing VIEs offset by approximately $248,000 of increased revenues from a new VIE, Cross Creek Apartments, acquired in the second quarter 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P170_S4	The remaining decrease in Property revenues is the result of a decline in Economic Occupancy at the MF Properties.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P170_S5	Annual net rental revenues per unit related to the MF Properties decreased to $7,119 per unit in 2009 from $7,667 in 2008.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P170_S6	The annual net rental revenues per unit related to the VIEs decreased to approximately $6,216 in 2009 from approximately $7,664 in 2008.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P171_S0	Mortgage revenue bond investment income of the Company consists of the interest income earned only on the mortgage revenue bonds that were not issued to finance properties owned by VIEs.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P171_S1	Mortgage revenue bond investment income was flat year over year due to offsetting factors.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P171_S2	Income from three new bond investments acquired in 2009 was approximately $500,000.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P171_S3	Offsetting this increase was a decrease in interest income resulting from the disposal of two bond investments plus the foreclosure of the Prairiebrook bond in 2008.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P172_S0	Gain on sale of asset held for sale.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P172_S2	After the deduction of selling expenses, commissions and cash advances made to the property, the Company realized a taxable gain of approximately $863,000 from the sale.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P173_S1	The loss resulted from the write off of unamortized deferred financing costs related to the bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P174_S0	Other interest income represents interest earned on cash and cash equivalents.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P174_S1	Although cash and cash equivalents average outstanding balances were greater during 2009, the decrease in interest income is attributable to significantly lower interest rates earned during 2009 as compared to 2008.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P175_S0	Real estate operating expenses increased approximately $1.2 million during 2009 as compared to 2008.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P175_S1	Approximately $1.5 million of the increase is attributable to the acquisition of three MF Properties, the Commons at Churchland and Glynn Place Apartments acquired in the second half of 2008 and Greens of Pine Glen, acquired in the first quarter of 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P175_S2	In addition, Cross Creek Apartments, a consolidated VIE, acquired during the second quarter of 2009, contributed approximately $410,000 of additional real estate operating expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P175_S3	Offsetting these increases was a net decrease of approximately $770,000 in VIE real estate operating expenses mainly from decreased repairs, maintenance and supplies expenses.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P177_S1	Such evaluation is based on cash flow and discounted cash flow models.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P177_S2	The Company concluded that there was no impairment of fixed assets or bond investments as of December 31, 2009.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P177_S4	An allowance for bad debt and associated provision for loan loss of approximately $700,000 was recorded against the Woodland Park taxable loan.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P177_S5	Additionally, in May 2008, the Company filed a petition of foreclosure on the Prairiebrook Village bonds which were in default.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P177_S7	At December 31, 2009, the current receivable amount was $713,500.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P177_S8	Due to a number of factors the Company recorded an allowance for bad debt against the judgment receivable as of December 31, 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P177_S9	The allowance for bad debt and associated provision for loan loss recorded was $700,000.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P178_S0	Depreciation and amortization expense, which consists primarily of depreciation associated with the apartment properties of the Consolidated VIEs and the MF Properties, amortization associated with in-place lease intangible assets recorded as part of the purchase accounting for the acquisition of MF Properties, and deferred finance cost amortization related to a tender option bond credit facility that was in place until June 2009, increased approximately $1.1 million in 2009 as compared to 2008.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P178_S1	Approximately $1.1 million of the increase is attributable to the acquisition of three MF Properties, the Commons at Churchland and Glynn Place Apartments acquired in the second half of 2008 and Greens of Pine Glen, acquired in the first quarter of 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P178_S2	In addition, Cross Creek Apartments, acquired during the second quarter of 2009, contributed approximately $203,000.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P178_S3	These increases were offset by a decrease in amortization related to the deferred finance costs from the purchase of the six MF properties in June, 2007 that were fully amortized in 2009 and the tender option bond credit facility.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P179_S0	Interest expense increased approximately $96,000 during 2009 compared to 2008 due to changes in outstanding debt, borrowing rates, and the fair value of our interest rate derivatives.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P179_S1	Total outstanding debt from continuing operations was $87.9 million at December 31, 2008 as compared to $85.5 million as of December 31, 2009 and the Company's borrowing cost decreased from 4.5% per annum in 2008 to 3.5% per annum in 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P179_S2	These two factors accounted for a decrease in interest expense of approximately $348,000.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P179_S3	Offsetting this decrease was an increase in interest expense resulting from the mark to market adjustments reflecting decreases in the fair value of our interest rate derivatives.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P180_S0	General and administrative expenses were up approximately $185,000 in 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P180_S1	This increase was realized in professional fees and salary expense.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P181_S0	In February 2009, the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds secured by Ashley Pointe at Eagle Crest in Evansville, Indiana, Woodbridge Apartment of Bloomington III in Bloomington, Indiana, and Woodbridge Apartments of Louisville II in Louisville, Kentucky were redeemed.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P181_S1	The properties financed by these redeemed mortgage revenue bonds were required to be consolidated into the Company's financial statements as VIEs under the guidance on consolidations.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P181_S2	During the fourth quarter of 2008, these VIEs met the criteria for discontinued operations under the guidance on property, plant and equipment and they were classified as such in the consolidated financial statements for all periods presented.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P182_S0	In order to properly reflect the transaction under the guidance on consolidations, the Company recorded the redemption of the bonds as a sale of the properties as though they were owned by the Company.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P182_S1	The transaction was completed for a total purchase price of $32.0 million resulting in a gain on sale for GAAP reporting to the Company of approximately $26.5 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P182_S2	The redemption of the bonds did not result in a taxable gain to the Company.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P183_S0	As of December 31, 2008, Ashley Pointe, Woodbridge Apartments of Bloomington III, and Woodbridge Apartments of Louisville II reported assets of approximately $8.1 million and liabilities of approximately $23.3 million which are included in assets and liabilities of discontinued operations, respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P183_S1	For the years ended December 31, 2009, 2008 and 2007 net income, excluding the gain on sale, from these VIEs of approximately $347,000, $647,000 and $824,000, respectively, is included in the income from discontinued operations.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P195_S3	This evaluation did determine that a portion of the taxable property loans were potentially impaired and that an additional allowance for loan loss should be recorded.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P195_S4	An allowance for loan loss of approximately $1.1 million and $700,000 was recorded against the the property taxable loans during 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P195_S5	Additionally, in 2009 a $700,000 allowance for bad debt was recorded against the judgment receivable related to the 2008 foreclosure on the Prairiebrook Village bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P196_S0	the Partnership has determined that the property fixed assets of Weatherford and the associated tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond which is eliminated in consolidation were impaired.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P196_S1	As of September 30, 2010 the property fixed assets, consisting of land and land improvements, and the associated tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond owned by the Partnership were written down.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P196_S2	The resulting impairment charge of approximately $2.7 million is attributable to the unitholders.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P196_S3	In February 2011, the Partnership foreclosed on the current ownership and will continue to develop the property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P197_S0	Depreciation and amortization consists primarily of depreciation associated with the MF Properties, amortization associated with in-place lease intangible assets recorded as part of the purchase accounting for the acquisition of MF Properties and deferred finance cost amortization written off upon retirement of the BOA Credit Facility in addition to new amortization of finance costs related to the closing of the TEBS Credit Facility.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P197_S1	The decrease in depreciation and amortization expense from 2009 to 2010 is attributable to a decrease of approximately $96,000 in deferred financing cost amortization and a decrease of approximately $708,000 of in-place lease amortization which are fully amortized.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P197_S2	The remaining difference is directly related to an increase in depreciation expense on the existing MF Properties due to newly capitalized assets.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P198_S0	The decrease in interest expense of $1.7 million in 2010 as compared to 2009 was due to offsetting factors.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P198_S1	Approximately $1.5 million of the decrease was a result of the mark to market adjustment of the Partnership 's derivatives.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P198_S2	These interest rate derivatives do not qualify for hedge accounting and, accordingly, they are carried at fair value, with changes in fair value included in current period earnings within interest expense.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P198_S3	The remaining change in interest expense results from changes in the average outstanding debt throughout the year combined with changes in the Partnership 's cost of borrowing.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P198_S4	The average outstanding debt decreased slightly while the average cost of borrowing increased slightly from approximately 3.5% per annum in 2009 to approximately 3.6% per annum in 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P199_S0	General and administrative expenses increased mainly due to increased professional fees and administration fees.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P200_S0	from the Securities Exchange Commission in the first quarter of 2010.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P200_S3	Offsetting these expenses was a reduction in reimbursable employee expenses paid to AFCA 2.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P201_S0	Property revenues of the Partnership consists only of those of the MF Properties.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P202_S0	Mortgage revenue bond investment income of the Partnership consists of the interest income earned on the mortgage revenue bonds actually held by the Partnership during the respective periods including the bonds secured by properties owned by VIEs that are eliminated in consolidation in the Company's financial statements.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P202_S1	Mortgage revenue bond investment income increased approximately $985,000 in 2009 compared to 2008.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P202_S2	The increase is the net effect of approximately $907,000 increase in base bond interest resulting from bonds acquired in 2008 and 2009 plus a $2.2 million increase in realized contingent interest income offset by a decrease in base interest of approximately $2.1 million resulting from the sale of two bond investments in 2008, the foreclosure of a bond investment in 2008, and the early redemption of three bonds in February 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P202_S3	Due to the uncertainty in collections of contingent interest, the Partnership recognizes this as income only when it is realized.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P203_S0	Gain on sale of asset held for sale.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P204_S2	The losses result from the write off of unamortized deferred financing costs related to the bonds.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P205_S1	Although cash and cash equivalents average outstanding balances were greater during 2009, the decrease in interest income is attributable to significantly lower interest rates earned during 2009 as compared to 2008.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P206_S1	This increase is attributable to the acquisition of three MF Properties, the Commons at Churchland and Glynn Place Apartments acquired in the second half of 2008 and Greens of Pine Glen, acquired in the first quarter of 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P207_S0	The Partnership periodically, or as changes in circumstances or operations dictate, evaluates its investments for impairment.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P207_S1	The value of the underlying property assets is ultimately the most relevant measure of value to support the investment carrying values.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P208_S0	Investments tested for impairment include all fixed assets, bond investments, and taxable loans made to various properties and other amounts due to the Partnership .
1059142_11_ITEM7_P208_S1	Such evaluation is based on cash flow and discounted cash flow models.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P208_S2	The Partnership concluded that there was no impairment of fixed assets or bond investments as of December 31, 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P208_S3	This evaluation did determine that a portion of the taxable property loans were potentially impaired and that an additional allowance for bad debt should be recorded.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P208_S5	Additionally, in May 2008, the Partnership filed a petition of foreclosure on the Prairiebrook Village bonds which were in default.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P208_S6	In 2008, the Partnership recorded a receivable of approximately $987,000 representing the remaining amounts due from the project owner and developer based on summary judgment obtained.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P208_S7	At December 31, 2009, the current receivable amount was $713,500.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P208_S8	Due to a number of factors the Partnership recorded an allowance for bad debt against the judgment receivable as of December 31, 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P208_S9	The allowance for bad debt and associated provision for loan loss recorded was $700,000.

1059142_11_ITEM7_P211_S1	Total outstanding debt was $85.5 million at December 31, 2009 as compared to $107.5 million as of December 31, 2008 and the Partnership's borrowing cost decreased from 4.6% per annum in 2008 to 3.4% per annum in 2009 resulting in a $1.2 million decrease.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P211_S2	The mark to market adjustments related to derivatives offset this decrease.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P212_S0	General and administrative expenses were up approximately $185,000 in 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P212_S1	This increase was realized in professional fees and salary expense.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P213_S0	Tax-exempt interest on mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P213_S1	Tax-exempt interest earned on the mortgage revenue bonds, including those financing properties held by Consolidated VIEs, represents the Partnership's principal source of cash flow.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P213_S2	The Partnership may also receive cash distributions from equity interests held in MF Properties.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P213_S3	Tax-exempt interest is primarily comprised of base interest payments received on the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P213_S4	Certain of the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds may also generate payments of contingent interest to the Partnership from time to time when the underlying apartment properties generate excess cash flow.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P213_S5	Because base interest on each of the Partnership's mortgage revenue bonds is fixed, the Partnership's cash receipts tend to be fairly constant period to period unless the Partnership acquires or disposes of its investments in tax-exempt bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P213_S6	Changes in the economic performance of the properties financed by tax-exempt bonds with a contingent interest provision will affect the amount of contingent interest, if any, paid to the Partnership.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P213_S7	Similarly, the economic performance of MF Properties will affect the amount of cash distributions, if any, received by the Partnership from its ownership of these properties.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P214_S0	The economic performance of a multifamily apartment property depends on the rental and occupancy rates of the property and on the level of operating expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P214_S1	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, apartments in the market area in which a property is located.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P214_S2	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and the affordability of single-family homes.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P214_S3	In addition, factors such as government regulation (such as zoning laws), inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems, and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of an apartment property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P215_S0	The primary uses of cash by apartment properties are the payment of operating expenses and debt service.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P216_S0	Other sources of cash available to the Partnership include debt financing and the sale of additional BUCs.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P217_S0	As of September 1, 2010, the Partnership and its Consolidated Subsidiary ATAX TEBS I, LLC, entered into a number of agreements relating to a new long-term debt financing facility provided through the securitization of 13 tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds pursuant to Freddie Mac's TEBS program.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P217_S1	The gross proceeds from TEBS Financing were approximately $95.8 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P217_S2	After the payment of transaction expenses the Company received net proceeds from the TEBS Financing of approximately $90.4 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P217_S3	The Company applied approximately $49.5 million of these net proceeds to repay the entire outstanding principal of, and accrued interest on, its secured term loan from Bank of America.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P217_S4	The TEBS Financing essentially provides the Company with a long-term variable-rate debt facility at interest rates reflecting prevailing short-term tax-exempt rates.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P217_S5	Under the TEBS Financing, the Company transferred the 13 bonds, with a total outstanding principal amount of approximately $125.6 million, to ATAX TEBS I, LLC, a special purpose entity controlled by the Company (the Sponsor ).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P218_S0	In order to meet Freddie Mac's underwriting requirements with respect to the multifamily apartment properties financed by certain of the Bonds, the Sponsor was required to first place eight of the Bonds, with a total outstanding principal of approximately $70.5 million, into a separate custodial trust with The Bank of New York Mellon Trust Company, N.A. (the Custodial Trust ) that issued senior and subordinated custody receipts ( Custody Receipts ) representing beneficial interests in the Bonds held in the Custodial Trust to the Sponsor.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P218_S1	The subordinated Custody Receipts with a total principal amount of approximately $9.5 million were retained by the Sponsor.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P218_S2	The senior Custody Receipts, with a total principal amount of approximately $61.0 million, along with the remaining five Bonds that were not placed into the Custodial Trust, with a total principal amount of approximately $55.1 million, were then securitized by transferring these assets to Freddie Mac in exchange for tax-exempt Class A and Class B Freddie Mac Multifamily Variable Rate Certificates (collectively, the TEBS Certificates ) issued by Freddie Mac.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P218_S3	The TEBS Certificates represent beneficial interests in the securitized assets held by Freddie Mac.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P218_S4	The Class A TEBS Certificates were issued in an initial principal amount of $95.8 million and were sold through a placement agent to unaffiliated investors.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P218_S5	The Class B TEBS Certificates were issued in an initial principal amount of $20.3 million and were retained be the Sponsor.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P219_S0	The holders of the Class A TEBS Certificates are entitled to receive regular payments of interest from Freddie Mac at a variable rate which resets periodically based on the weekly Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association ( SIFMA ) floating index rate plus certain Facility Fees.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P220_S0	total Facility Fees were 1.9%, resulting in a total initial cost of borrowing of 2.15%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P220_S1	As of December 31, 2010, the SIFMA rate was equal to 0.34% resulting in a total cost of borrowing of 2.24%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P221_S0	Payment of interest on the Class A TEBS Certificates will be made from the interest payments received by Freddie Mac from the Bonds and Senior Custody Receipts held by Freddie Mac on designated interest payment dates prior to any payments of interest on the Class B TEBS Certificates held by the Sponsor.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P221_S1	As the holder of the Class B TEBS Certificates, the Sponsor is not entitled to receive interest payments on the Class B TEBS Certificates at any particular rate, but will be entitled to all payments of principal and interest on the Bonds and Senior Custody Receipts held by Freddie Mac after payment of principal and interest due on the Class A TEBS Certificates and payment of all Facility Fees and associated expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P221_S2	Accordingly, the amount of interest paid to the Sponsor on the Class B TEBS Certificates is expected to vary over time, and could be eliminated altogether, due to fluctuations in the interest rate payable on the Class A TEBS Certificates, Facility Fees, expenses and other factors.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P221_S3	Freddie Mac has guaranteed payment of scheduled principal and interest payments on the Class A TEBS Certificates and also guarantees payment of the purchase price of any Class A TEBS Certificates that are tendered to Freddie Mac in accordance with their terms but which cannot be remarketed to new holders within five business days.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P221_S4	The Sponsor has pledged the Class B TEBS Certificates to Freddie Mac to secure certain reimbursement obligations of the Sponsor to Freddie Mac.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P221_S5	The Company also entered into various subordination and intercreditor agreements with Freddie Mac under which the Company has subordinated its rights and remedies with respect to the taxable mortgage loans made by it to the owners of properties securing certain of the Bonds to the rights of Freddie Mac as the holder of the Bonds.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P222_S0	For financial reporting purposes, the TEBS Financing is presented by the Company as a secured financing.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P222_S1	Prior to the closing of the TEBS Financing, the Company had outstanding debt financing of $54.8 million consisting of two credit facilities.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P222_S2	The first credit facility was with Bank of America and had an outstanding balance of $49.3 million (the BOA Facility ).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P222_S3	As noted above, the BOA Facility was repaid with proceeds from the TEBS Financing.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P222_S4	The second credit facility was with Omaha State Bank and had an outstanding balance of $5.5 million (the OSB Facility ).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P222_S5	The OSB Facility was repaid prior to the execution of the TEBS Financing.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P223_S0	The TEBS Financing offers several advantages over the Company's previous credit facilities which, over time, are expected to positively impact the generation of CAD.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P224_S0	a lower initial cost of borrowing.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P225_S0	The Partnership is authorized to issue additional BUCs to raise additional equity capital to fund investment opportunities.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P225_S1	In April 2010, a Registration Statement on Form S-3 was declared effective by the SEC under which the Partnership may offer up to $200.0 million of additional BUCs from time to time.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P225_S2	In April 2010, the Partnership issued an additional 8,280,000 BUCs through an underwritten public offering at a public offering price of $5.37 per BUC pursuant to this new Registration Statement.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P225_S3	Net proceeds realized by the Partnership from this issuance of these BUCs were approximately $41.7 million after payment of an underwriter's discount and other offering costs of approximately $2.8 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P226_S0	Cash distributions made by the Partnership to unitholders may increase or decrease at the determination of the General Partner based on its assessment of the amount of cash available to the Partnership for this purpose.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P226_S1	Beginning with the distribution for the second quarter of 2009, the Partnership's annual distribution was reduced from $0.54 per unit to $0.50 per unit due to the General Partner's determination that higher borrowing costs and other factors would reduce the cash available to the Partnership to make distributions.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P227_S0	The Partnership's operating policy is to use securitizations or other forms of leverage to maintain a level of debt financing between 40% and 60% of the total par value of the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage bond portfolio.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P227_S1	At December 31, 2010 , the Partnership has outstanding debt financing of $95.6 million secured by 13 tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds with a total par value of $125.6 million plus approximately $15.2 million in restricted cash.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P227_S2	As of December 31, 2010 , the debt outstanding related to the total par value of the Partnerships' total bond portfolio of approximately $189.3 million plus restricted cash results in a leverage ratio of 47%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P227_S3	The outstanding debt financing is the TEBS financing agreement with Freddie Mac, discussed above (see Note 9).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P227_S4	Additionally, the MF Properties are encumbered by mortgage loans with an aggregate principal balance of approximately $10.6 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P227_S5	These mortgage loans mature at various times from November 2011 through November 2013 (see Note 10).
1059142_11_ITEM7_P227_S6	The total debt financing plus mortgage loans of $106.2 million results in a leverage ratio to Total Assets of 44%.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P228_S0	The Partnership's principal uses of cash are the payment of distributions to unitholders, interest and principal on debt financing and general and administrative expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P228_S1	The Partnership also uses cash to acquire additional investments.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P229_S0	unitholders may increase or decrease at the determination of the General Partner.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P229_S1	Distributions to unitholders depend primarily upon the amount of base and contingent interest received on the Company's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and cash received from other investments, the amount of borrowings and the effective interest rate of these borrowings, and the amount of the Partnership's undistributed cash.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P229_S2	The General Partner believes that cash provided by its tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and other investments will be adequate to meet its projected long-term liquidity requirements, including the payment of expenses, interest, and distributions to unitholders.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P229_S3	Recently, income from investments has not been sufficient to fund such expenditures without utilizing cash reserves to supplement the deficit.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P229_S4	See discussion below regarding Cash Available for Distribution.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P229_S5	As a result, beginning with the second quarter 2009 distribution, the General Partner lowered the Company's regular annual distribution from $0.54 to $0.50 per BUC, or $0.125 per quarter per BUC.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P229_S6	The General Partner believes that distributions at this level are sustainable, however, if actual results vary from current projections and the actual CAD generated is less than the new regular distribution, such distribution amount may need to be reduced.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P230_S0	The Consolidated VIEs' and MF Properties' primary source of cash is net rental revenues generated by their real estate investments.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P230_S1	Net rental revenues from a multifamily apartment property depend on the rental and occupancy rates of the property and on the level of operating expenses.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P231_S0	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, apartments in the market area in which a property is located.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P231_S1	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and the affordability of single-family homes.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P231_S2	In addition, factors such as government regulation (such as zoning laws), inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of an apartment property.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P232_S0	The Consolidated VIEs' and MF Properties' primary uses of cash are: (i) the payment of operating expenses; and (ii) the payment of debt service.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S0	On a consolidated basis, cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2010, increased approximately $2.5 million compared to the same period a year earlier mainly due to changes in working capital components.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S1	Cash from investing activities decreased approximately $60.4 million in 2010 as compared to 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S2	The largest change in investing activities relates to $32.0 million in cash proceeds realized in the first quarter of 2009 from the early redemption of the bonds on Ashley Pointe, Woodbridge - Louisville and Woodbridge - Bloomington.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S3	No proceeds from the sale or redemption of investments were realized in 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S4	Restricted cash increased approximately $18.1 million in 2010 due to the TEBS facility requirements as compared to a decrease in restricted cash in 2009 of approximately $7.9 million resulting in an increase in cash utilized of approximately $26.0 million.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S5	Net cash utilized for the acquisition of new investments in bonds, property partnerships, and other assets totaled approximately $31.0 million in 2010 compared to approximately $31.8 million in 2009 resulting in a decrease in cash utilized for investments of approximately $800,000.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S6	An investment sold in 2009 resulted in a $3.5 million increase in 2009 cash which was not repeated in 2010.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S7	Principal payments received resulted in an approximate $300,000 increase year over year.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S8	Cash provided by financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2010, increased approximately $43.9 million compared to the same period a year earlier.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S9	Cash provided by debt financings increased approximately $40.3 million in 2010 as compared to 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S10	Net cash provided by the sale of additional BUCs increased $2.7 million in 2010 over 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S11	Principal payments on debt declined approximately $9.4 million in 2010 as compared to 2009.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S12	Cash used for interest rate derivatives and financing costs increased approximately $5.4 million and cash used for distributions increased approximately $3.1 million, accounting for the remaining change in cash from financing activities.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P233_S13	The main transactions driving the changes in financing cash flows were the TEBS Financing closing in September and the sale of additional BUCs closing in April.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P234_S0	Management utilizes a calculation of CAD as a means to determine the Partnership's ability to make distributions to unitholders.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P234_S1	The General Partner believes that CAD provides relevant information about its operations and is necessary along with net income for understanding its operating results.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P234_S2	To calculate CAD, amortization expense related to debt financing costs and bond reissuance costs, certain income due to the General Partner (defined as Tier 2 income in the Agreement of Limited Partnership), interest rate derivative expense or income (including adjustments to fair value), provision for loan losses, impairments on bonds, losses related to Consolidated VIEs including the cumulative effect of accounting change, and depreciation and amortization expense are added back to the Company's net income (loss) as computed in accordance with GAAP.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P235_S0	There is no generally accepted methodology for computing CAD, and the Partnership's computation of CAD may not be comparable to CAD reported by other companies.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P235_S1	Although the Partnership considers CAD to be a useful measure of its operating performance, CAD should not be considered as an alternative to net income or net cash flows from operating activities which are calculated in accordance with GAAP.
1059142_11_ITEM7_P236_S0	During June 2010, the Company completed a sales transaction whereby four of the MF Properties, the Ohio Properties, were sold to three new ownership entities controlled by an unaffiliated not-for-profit entity (see Note 5).
