1059142_12_ITEM7_P129_S2	The resulting impairment charge of approximately $2.7 million is attributable to the unitholders.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P129_S3	In February 2011, the Partnership foreclosed on the current ownership and will continue to develop the property.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P130_S0	Depreciation and amortization consists primarily of depreciation associated with the MF Properties, amortization associated with in-place lease intangible assets recorded as part of the purchase accounting for the acquisition of MF Properties and deferred finance cost amortization written off upon retirement of the BOA Credit Facility in addition to new amortization of finance costs related to the closing of the TEBS Credit Facility.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P130_S1	The decrease in depreciation and amortization expense from 2009 to 2010 is attributable to a decrease of approximately $96,000 of deferred financing cost amortization and a decrease of approximately $708,000 of in-place lease amortization which are fully amortized.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P130_S2	The remaining difference is directly related to an increase in depreciation expense on the existing MF Properties due to newly capitalized assets.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P131_S0	The decrease in interest expense of $1.7 million in 2010 as compared to 2009 was due to offsetting factors.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P131_S1	Approximately $1.5 million of the decrease was a result of the mark to market adjustment of the Partnership 's derivatives.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P131_S2	These interest rate derivatives do not qualify for hedge accounting and, accordingly, they are carried at fair value, with changes in fair value included in current period earnings within interest expense.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P131_S3	The remaining change in interest expense results from changes in the average outstanding debt throughout the year combined with changes in the Partnership 's cost of borrowing.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P131_S4	The average outstanding debt decreased slightly while the average cost of borrowing increased slightly from approximately 3.5% per annum in 2009 to approximately 3.6% per annum in 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P132_S0	General and administrative expenses increased mainly due to increased professional fees and administration fees.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P132_S1	Professional fees increased approximately $258,000 due mainly to accounting, legal and other professional fees associated with the process the Partnership utilized to respond to a comment letter received by the Partnership from the Securities Exchange Commission in the first quarter of 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P132_S2	Additional professional fees were also incurred for accounting consultation regarding the implementation of new accounting standards in 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P132_S3	Administration fees paid to AFCA 2 increased approximately $335,000 as the Company has a higher level of invested assets and taxable loans in 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P132_S4	Offsetting these expenses was a reduction in reimbursable employee expenses paid to AFCA 2.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P133_S0	Primary sources and uses of funds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P133_S1	Tax-exempt interest earned on the mortgage revenue bonds, including those financing properties held by Consolidated VIEs, represents the Partnership's principal source of cash flow.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P133_S2	The Partnership may also receive cash distributions from equity interests held in MF Properties.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P133_S3	Tax-exempt interest is primarily comprised of base interest payments received on the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P133_S4	Certain of the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds may also generate payments of contingent interest to the Partnership from time to time when the underlying apartment properties generate excess cash flow.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P133_S5	Because base interest on each of the Partnership's mortgage revenue bonds is fixed, the Partnership's cash receipts tend to be fairly constant period to period unless the Partnership acquires or disposes of its investments in tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P133_S6	Changes in the economic performance of the properties financed by tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds with a contingent interest provision will affect the amount of contingent interest, if any, paid to the Partnership.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P134_S0	The Consolidated VIEs' and MF Properties' primary source of cash is net rental revenues generated by their real estate investments.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P135_S0	The economic performance of a multifamily apartment property depends on the rental and occupancy rates of the property and on the level of operating expenses.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P135_S1	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, apartments in the market area in which a property is located.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P135_S2	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and the affordability of single-family homes.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P135_S3	In addition, factors such as government regulation (such as zoning laws), inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems, and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of an apartment property.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P136_S0	The primary uses of cash by apartment properties are the payment of operating expenses and debt service.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P137_S0	Other sources of cash available to the Partnership include debt financing, mortgages and the sale of additional BUCs.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P137_S1	The Company currently has outstanding debt financing of $112.7 million under three separate credit facilities and mortgages of $46.2 million secured by six MF Properties.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P138_S0	The Partnership's principal uses of cash are the payment of distributions to unitholders, interest and principal on debt financing and general and administrative expenses.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P138_S1	The Partnership also uses cash to acquire additional investments.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P138_S2	Distributions to unitholders may increase or decrease at the determination of the General Partner.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P138_S3	The per unit cash available for distribution primarily depends on the amount of interest and other cash received by the Partnership from its portfolio of tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and other investments, the amount of the Partnership's outstanding debt and the effective interest rates paid by the Partnership on this debt, the level of operating and other cash expenses incurred by the Partnership and the number of units outstanding.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P138_S4	During the year ended December 31, 2011, the Partnership generated cash available for distribution of $0.35 per unit.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P138_S5	See Cash Available for Distribution, on a following page within item 7.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P138_S6	As a result, the Partnership was required to supplement its cash available for distribution during 2011 with unrestricted cash and expects to continue to do so until the Partnership is able to complete its current investment plans.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P138_S7	The General Partner believes that upon completion of its current investment plans, the Partnership will be able meet its liquidity requirements, including the payment of expenses, interest on its debt financing, and cash distributions to unitholders at the current level of $0.50 per unit per year without the use of unrestricted cash.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P138_S8	However, if actual results vary from current projections and the actual CAD generated is less than the new regular distribution, such distribution amount may need to be reduced.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P139_S0	The Consolidated VIEs' and MF Properties' primary uses of cash are: (i) the payment of operating expenses; and (ii) the payment of debt service.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P140_S0	The Partnership's operating policy is to use securitizations or other forms of leverage to maintain a level of debt financing between 40% and 60% of the total par value of the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage bond portfolio.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P140_S1	As of December 31, 2011 , the debt outstanding related to the total par value of the Partnerships' total bond portfolio of approximately $197.3 million plus restricted cash results in a leverage ratio of 57%.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P141_S0	The outstanding debt financing arrangements are two TOB facilities with Deutsche Bank and the TEBS financing agreement with Freddie Mac, discussed above (see Note 9).
1059142_12_ITEM7_P141_S1	Additionally, the MF Properties are encumbered by mortgage loans with an aggregate principal balance of approximately $46.2 million.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P141_S2	These mortgage loans mature at various times from May 2012 through November 2013 (see Note 10).
1059142_12_ITEM7_P141_S3	The total debt financing plus mortgage loans of $158.9 million results in a leverage ratio to Total Assets of 53%.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P142_S0	As of September 1, 2010, the Partnership and its Consolidated Subsidiary ATAX TEBS I, LLC, entered into a number of agreements relating to a long-term debt financing facility provided through the securitization of 13 tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds pursuant to Freddie Mac's TEBS program.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P142_S1	The gross proceeds from TEBS Financing were approximately $95.8 million.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P142_S2	After the payment of transaction expenses, the Company received net proceeds from the TEBS Financing of approximately $90.4 million.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P142_S3	The Company applied approximately $49.5 million of these net proceeds to repay the entire outstanding principal of, and accrued interest on, its secured term loan from Bank of America.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P142_S4	The TEBS Financing essentially provides the Company with a long-term variable-rate debt facility at interest rates reflecting prevailing short-term tax-exempt rates.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P142_S5	Under the TEBS Financing, the Company transferred the 13 bonds, with a total outstanding principal amount of approximately $125.6 million, to ATAX TEBS I, LLC, a special purpose entity controlled by the Company (the Sponsor ).
1059142_12_ITEM7_P143_S0	In order to meet Freddie Mac's underwriting requirements with respect to the multifamily apartment properties financed by certain of the Bonds, the Sponsor was required to first place eight of the Bonds, with a total outstanding principal of approximately $70.5 million, into a separate custodial trust with The Bank of New York Mellon Trust Company, N.A. (the Custodial Trust ) that issued senior and subordinated custody receipts ( Custody Receipts ) representing beneficial interests in the Bonds held in the Custodial Trust to the Sponsor.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P143_S1	The subordinated Custody Receipts with a total principal amount of approximately $9.5 million were retained by the Sponsor.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P143_S2	The senior Custody Receipts, with a total principal amount of approximately $61.0 million, along with the remaining five Bonds that were not placed into the Custodial Trust, with a total principal amount of approximately $55.1 million, were then securitized by transferring these assets to Freddie Mac in exchange for the TEBS Certificates issued by Freddie Mac.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P144_S0	The TEBS Certificates represent beneficial interests in the securitized assets held by Freddie Mac.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P144_S1	The Class A TEBS Certificates were issued in an initial principal amount of $95.8 million and were sold through a placement agent to unaffiliated investors.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P144_S2	The Class B TEBS Certificates were issued in an initial principal amount of $20.3 million and were retained by the Sponsor.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P144_S3	The holders of the Class A TEBS Certificates are entitled to receive regular payments of interest from Freddie Mac at a variable rate which resets periodically based on the weekly SIFMA floating index rate plus certain Facility Fees.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P144_S4	As of closing, the SIFMA rate was equal to 0.25% and the total Facility Fees were 1.9%, resulting in a total initial cost of borrowing of 2.15%.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P144_S5	As of December 31, 2011 , the SIFMA rate was equal to .15% resulting in a total cost of borrowing of 2.05%.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P144_S6	As of December 31, 2010 , the SIFMA rate was equal to 0.34% resulting in a total cost of borrowing of 2.24%.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P145_S0	Payment of interest on the Class A TEBS Certificates are made from the interest payments received by Freddie Mac from the Bonds and Senior Custody Receipts held by Freddie Mac on designated interest payment dates prior to any payments of interest on the Class B TEBS Certificates held by the Sponsor.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P145_S1	As the holder of the Class B TEBS Certificates, the Sponsor is not entitled to receive interest payments on the Class B TEBS Certificates at any particular rate, but will be entitled to all payments of principal and interest on the Bonds and Senior Custody Receipts held by Freddie Mac after payment of principal and interest due on the Class A TEBS Certificates and payment of all Facility Fees and associated expenses.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P145_S2	Accordingly, the amount of interest paid to the Sponsor on the Class B TEBS Certificates is expected to vary over time, and could be eliminated altogether, due to fluctuations in the interest rate payable on the Class A TEBS Certificates, Facility Fees, expenses and other factors.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P145_S3	Freddie Mac has guaranteed payment of scheduled principal and interest payments on the Class A TEBS Certificates and also guarantees payment of the purchase price of any Class A TEBS Certificates that are tendered to Freddie Mac in accordance with their terms but which cannot be remarketed to new holders within five business days.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P145_S4	The Sponsor has pledged the Class B TEBS Certificates to Freddie Mac to secure certain reimbursement obligations of the Sponsor to Freddie Mac.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P145_S5	The Company also entered into various subordination and intercreditor agreements with Freddie Mac under which the Company has subordinated its rights and remedies with respect to the taxable mortgage loans made by it to the owners of properties securing certain of the Bonds to the rights of Freddie Mac as the holder of the Bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P146_S0	For financial reporting purposes, the TEBS Financing is presented by the Company as a secured financing.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P147_S0	The TEBS Financing offers several advantages over the Company's previous credit facilities which, over time, are expected to positively impact the generation of CAD.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P148_S0	a lower initial cost of borrowing.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S0	The second and third credit facilities in place at December 31, 2011 are financings which utilize a TOB structure with DB.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S1	In July 2011, the Company closed a $10.0 million financing utilizing a TOB structure with the DB.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S2	This first TOB was structured as a securitization of the Company's $13.4 million Autumn Pines Apartments tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S3	In December 2011, the Company closed a second TOB financing structure in the amount of $7.8 million with DB.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S4	This second TOB was structured as a securitization of the Company's $15.6 million GMF-Warren/Tulane Apartments and GMF-Madison apartments tax-exempt mortgage revenue and taxable mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S5	Under the TOB structure, the Company transfers the related bonds to a custodian and trustee that provide these services on behalf of DB.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S6	The TOB trustee then issued SPEARS and LIFERS.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S7	The SPEARS and LIFERS represent beneficial interests in the securitized asset held by the TOB trustee.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S8	The SPEARS were credit-enhanced by DB and sold through a placement agent to unaffiliated investors.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S9	The gross proceeds from the sale of the SPEARS were remitted to the Company.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S10	The LIFERS were retained by the Company and are pledged to DB to secure certain reimbursement obligations.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P149_S11	The effective interest rate for the two TOB facilities was 1.86% as of December 31, 2011.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P150_S0	The Partnership is authorized to issue additional BUCs to raise additional equity capital to fund investment opportunities.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P150_S1	In April 2010, a Registration Statement on Form S-3 was declared effective by the SEC under which the Partnership may offer up to $200.0 million of additional BUCs from time to time.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P150_S2	In April 2010, the Partnership issued an additional 8,280,000 BUCs through an underwritten public offering at a public offering price of $5.37 per BUC pursuant to this new Registration Statement.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P150_S3	Net proceeds realized by the Partnership from this issuance of these BUCs were approximately $41.7 million after payment of an underwriter's discount and other offering costs of approximately $2.8 million.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P151_S0	Cash distributions made by the Partnership to unitholders may increase or decrease at the determination of the General Partner based on its assessment of the amount of cash available to the Partnership for this purpose.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P151_S1	Beginning with the distribution for the second quarter of 2009, the Partnership's annual distribution was reduced from $0.54 per unit to $0.50 per unit due to the General Partner's determination that higher borrowing costs and other factors would reduce the cash available to the Partnership to make distributions.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P152_S0	On a consolidated basis, cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2011 increased approximately $8.0 million compared to the same period a year earlier mainly due to improved operations as net income adjusted for non-cash items such as depreciation and amortization, asset impairment charges, provisions and derivative mark-to-market changes improved approximately $4.3 million from approximately $7.0 million in 2010 to approximately $11.3 million in 2011.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P152_S1	Changes in working capital components accounted for the remaining improvement in operating cash flow.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P152_S2	Cash used for investing activities improved approximately $16.7 million in 2011 as compared to 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P152_S3	The change in restricted cash from 2010 to 2011 comprises the majority of the decrease in cash used.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P152_S4	The remaining changes in investing activities is the net result of cash used to acquire the Arboretum Apartment and Eagle Village Student Housing properties; the Briarwood Manor, GMF-Madison and GMF-Warren/Tulane tax-exempt and taxable bonds offset by the release of cash upon foreclosure of the DeCordova and Weatherford properties; the retirement of the Clarkson College and Briarwood Manor bonds; and the repayment of a taxable loan by the Foundation for Affordable Housing.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P152_S5	Cash provided by financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2011 decreased approximately $13.8 million compared to 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P152_S6	Financing cash flows in 2011 consisted mainly of cash inflows from additional borrowings offset by distribution payments.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P152_S7	Financing cash flows in 2010 consisted mainly of cash inflows from the sales of BUCs offset by principal payments on debt and distributions.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P153_S0	Management utilizes a calculation of CAD as a means to determine the Partnership's ability to make distributions to unitholders.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P153_S1	The General Partner believes that CAD provides relevant information about its operations and is necessary along with net income for understanding its operating results.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P153_S2	To calculate CAD, amortization expense related to debt financing costs and bond reissuance costs, certain income due to the General Partner (defined as Tier 2 income in the Agreement of Limited Partnership), interest rate derivative expense or income (including adjustments to fair value), provision for loan losses, provision for loss on receivables, impairments on bonds, losses related to Consolidated VIEs including the cumulative effect of accounting change, and depreciation and amortization expense are added back to the Company's net income (loss) as computed in accordance with GAAP.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P154_S0	There is no generally accepted methodology for computing CAD, and the Partnership's computation of CAD may not be comparable to CAD reported by other companies.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P154_S1	Although the Partnership considers CAD to be a useful measure of its operating performance, CAD should not be considered as an alternative to net income or net cash flows from operating activities which are calculated in accordance with GAAP.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P155_S0	In October 2011, the Briarwood Manor bond was called and retired at par plus accured interest for approximately $4.9 million.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P155_S1	This transaction resulted in approximately $445,000 gain reported in the fourth quarter.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P155_S2	This gain meets the definition of Net Residual Proceeds representing Tier 2 income and was therefore distributed 75% to the unitholders and 25% to the General Partner.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P156_S0	Upon redemption of the Clarkson College bond in May 2011, the Company realized approximately $308,000 in contingent interest.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P156_S1	Contingent interest is Tier 2 income and was therefore distributed 75% to the unitholders and 25% to the General Partner.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P157_S0	During June 2010, the Company completed a sales transaction whereby four of the MF Properties, the Ohio Properties, were sold to three new ownership entities controlled by an unaffiliated not-for-profit entity (see Note 3).
1059142_12_ITEM7_P157_S1	Pursuant to the accounting guidance related to property, plant, and equipment for real estate sales, the sale and restructure does not meet the criteria for decrecognition of the properties and full accrual accounting treatment for the resulting gain.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P157_S2	As such, the Company will continue to consolidate the Ohio Properties as if the sale was not completed.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P157_S3	Under the sales agreement, the Ohio properties were sold for a total purchase price of $16.2 million.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P157_S4	Cash received by the selling limited partnerships as part of the sale transaction represents a deferred gain on the sale transaction of approximately $1.8 million.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P157_S5	As the deferred gain on the transaction represents cash paid to the Company and no on-going legal obligations related to the Ohio Properties or potential obligation to repay any amounts exists, the deferred gain is CAD and is shown as an adjustment in the CAD Calculation below.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P157_S6	This gain meets the definition of Net Residual Proceeds representing contingent interest (Tier 2 income) and was therefore distributed 75% to the unitholders and 25% to the General Partner.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P158_S0	The Partnership has made annual cash distribution of $0.50 per unit since 2009.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P158_S1	Since realized CAD per unit was less than $0.50 per unit, the Partnership used approximately $3.9 million and $3.1 million of unrestricted cash to supplement the deficit in 2011 and 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P158_S2	The General Partner believes that upon completion of its current investment plans, the Partnership will be able to generate sufficient CAD to maintain cash distributions to unitholders at the current level of $0.50 per unit per year without the use of other available cash.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P158_S3	However, there is no assurance that the Partnership will be unable to generate CAD at levels in excess of the current annual distribution rate.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P158_S4	In that case, the annual distribution rate per unit may need to be reduced.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P159_S0	The following tables show the calculation of CAD for the years ended December 31, 2011 , 2010 and 2009 .
1059142_12_ITEM7_P160_S0	(1) As described in Note 2 to the consolidated financial statements, Net Interest Income representing contingent interest and Net Residual Proceeds representing contingent interest (Tier 2 income) will be distributed 75% to the unitholders and 25% to the General Partner.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P160_S1	This adjustment represents the 25% of Tier 2 income due to the General Partner.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P160_S2	For the year ended 2011, the Tier II Income is approximately $445K recognized on the Briarwood bond retirement and approximately $308K of contingent interest recognized upon the Clarkson bond retirement.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P160_S3	For the second quarter of 2010, the deferred gain on the sale of the Ohio Properties generated approximately $1.8 million and contingent interest generated approximately $33K of Tier II income.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P160_S4	For 2009, the Tier 2 income distributable to the General Partner was generated by the early redemption of Woodbridge - Bloomington and Woodbridge - Louisville bond investments, the sale of Oak Grove, and contingent interest from Fairmont Oaks and Lake Forest Apartments.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P161_S0	As of December 31, 2011 and 2010 , the Partnership held tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds which are collateralized by multifamily housing projects.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P161_S1	The multifamily housing projects are owned by entities that are not controlled by the Partnership.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P161_S2	The Partnership has no equity interest in these entities and does not guarantee any obligations of these entities.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P161_S3	Some of the ownership entities are deemed to be Consolidated VIEs and are consolidated with the Partnership for financial reporting purposes.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P161_S4	The VIEs that are consolidated with the Partnership do not have off-balance sheet arrangements.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P162_S0	The Partnership does not engage in trading activities involving non-exchange traded contracts.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P162_S1	As such, the Partnership is not materially exposed to any financing, liquidity, market, or credit risk that could arise if it had engaged in such relationships.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P163_S0	The Partnership does not have any relationships or transactions with persons or entities that derive benefits from their non-independent relationships with the Partnership or its related parties other than what is disclosed in Note 12 to the Company's consolidated financial statements.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P164_S0	The Partnership has the following contractual obligations as of December 31, 2011:
1059142_12_ITEM7_P165_S0	As discussed in Note 9 to the financial statements, the amounts maturing in 2012 consist of the paydowns on the TEBS credit facility with Freddie Mac, the TOB credit facilities with Deutsche Bank and payments on the MF Property mortgages.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P165_S1	The Partnership plans to refinance or retire the current maturing mortgage in the second quarter of 2012.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P166_S0	With respect to the financial results of the Partnership's investments in tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and MF Properties, substantially all of the resident leases at the multifamily residential properties, which collateralize the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds, allow, at the time of renewal, for adjustments in the rent payable thereunder, and thus may enable the properties to seek rent increases.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P166_S1	The substantial majority of these leases are for one year or less.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P166_S2	The short-term nature of these leases generally serves to reduce the risk to the properties of the adverse effects of inflation; however, market conditions may prevent the properties from increasing rental rates in amounts sufficient to offset higher operating expenses.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P166_S3	Inflation did not have a significant impact on the Partnership's financial results for the years presented in this report.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P167_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires management of the Company to make a number of judgments, assumptions, and estimates.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P167_S1	The application of these judgments, assumptions and estimates can affect the amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses reported by the Company.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P167_S2	All of the Company's significant accounting policies are described in Note 2.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P167_S3	The Company considers the following to be its critical accounting policies because they involve judgments, assumptions and estimates by management that significantly affect the financial statements.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P167_S4	If these estimates differ significantly from actual results, the impact on our consolidated financial statements may be material.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P168_S0	Accounting for the TEBS and TOB Financing Arrangements The Company evaluated the accounting guidance in regard to the TEBS and TOB Financing arrangements (see Note 9 to the consolidated financial statements) and has determined that the securitization transactions do not meet the accounting criteria for a sale or transfer of financial assets and will, therefore, be accounted for as secured financing transactions.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P168_S1	In accordance with the guidance which outlines the conditions that must be met to derecognize a transferred financial asset, in part, the transferor has surrendered control over transferred assets if and only if the transferor does not maintain effective control over the transferred assets through either of the following:
1059142_12_ITEM7_P169_S0	An agreement that both entitles and obligates the transferor to repurchase or redeem them before their maturity, 2.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P169_S1	The ability to unilaterally cause the holder to return specific assets, other than through a cleanup call, or 3.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P169_S2	An agreement that permits the transferee to require the transferor to repurchase the transferred financial assets at a price that is so favorable to the transferee that it is probable that the transferee will require the transferor to repurchase them.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P170_S0	The TEBS Financing agreements contain certain provisions that allow the Company to (1) cause the return of certain individual bonds under defined circumstances, (2) cause the return of all of the bonds by electing an Optional Series Pool Release or (3) cause the return of any defaulted bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P170_S1	The Optional Series Pool Release is defined in the agreements as two specific dates, September 15, 2017 or September 15, 2020, on which the Company has the option to repurchase all of the securitized bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P170_S2	Given these terms, the Company has concluded that the condition in item 2 above is present in the agreements and, therefore, effective control over the transferred assets has not occurred.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P170_S3	As effective control has not been transferred, the transaction does not meet the conditions to derecognize the assets resulting in the TEBS Financing being presented on the Company's consolidated financial statements as a secured financing.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P170_S4	The TOB Financing agreements contain certain provisions that allow the Company to call the bonds held in the TOB Trusts through their ownership of the residual participating interests ("LIFERS") so effective control has not been transferred resulting in the TOB Financings being presented on the Company's consolidated financial statements as a secured financing.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P171_S0	In addition to evaluating the TEBS Financing as a sale or transfer of financial assets, we have evaluated the securitization trust associated with the TEBS Financing (the TEBS Trust ) under the provisions of the consolidation guidance.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P171_S1	As part of the TEBS Financing, certain bond assets of the Partnership were securitized into the TEBS Trust with Freddie Mac.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P171_S2	The TEBS Trust then issued Class A and B TEBS Certificates.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P171_S3	Other bond assets of the Partnership were securitized into the TOB Trust with Deutsche Bank ( DB ).
1059142_12_ITEM7_P171_S4	The TOB trustee then issued senior floating-rate participating interests ("SPEARS") and LIFERS.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P172_S0	The Partnership has determined that the TEBS Trust is a VIE and the Class B Certificates owned by the Partnership create a variable interest in the TEBS Trust.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P172_S1	It was also determined that the TOB Trusts are a VIE and the LIFERS owned by the Partnership creates a variable interest entity in the TOB Trusts.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P173_S0	In determining the primary beneficiary of the TEBS Trust and the TOB Trusts, the Partnership considered the activities of each of the VIEs which most significantly impact the VIE's economic performance, who has the power to control such activities, the risks which the entity was designed to create, the variability associated with those risks and the interests which absorb such variability.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P174_S0	The Partnership has retained the right, pursuant to the TEBS Financing agreements, to either substitute or reacquire some or all of the securitized bonds at various future dates and under various circumstances.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P174_S1	As a result, the Partnership determined it had retained a controlling financial interest in the TEBS Trust because such actions effectively provide the Partnership with the ability to control decisions pertaining to the VIE's management of interest rate and credit risk.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P174_S2	While in the TEBS Trust, the bond assets may only be used to settle obligations of the trust and the liabilities of the trust do not provide the Class A certificate holders with recourse to the general credit of the Partnership.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P174_S3	The Partnership also determined it was the primary beneficiary of the TOB Trusts as it has the right to call the bonds within the trusts.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P175_S0	The Partnership considered the related party relationship of the entities involved in the VIEs.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P175_S1	It was determined that the Partnership met both of the primary beneficiary criteria and was the most closely associated with the VIEs and, therefore, was determined to be the primary beneficiary under these financing arrangements.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P176_S0	Given these accounting determinations, the TEBS Financing and the associated TEBS Trust are presented as a secured financing within the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P176_S1	The TOB Financings and associated TOB trusts are also presented as a secured financing within the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P177_S0	The Partnership invests in federally tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds which have been issued to provide construction and/or permanent financing of multifamily residential apartments.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P177_S1	The Partnership owns 100% of these bonds and each bond is secured by a first mortgage on the property.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P177_S2	The Partnership has also made taxable loans to the property owners in certain cases which are secured by second mortgages on these properties.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P177_S3	Although each multifamily property financed with tax-exempt mortgage bonds held by the Partnership is owned by a separate entity in which the Partnership has no equity ownership interest, the debt financing provided by the Partnership creates a variable interest in these ownership entities that may require the Partnership to report the assets, liabilities and results of operations of these entities on a consolidated basis under GAAP.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P178_S0	Effective January 1, 2010, the Company adopted new provisions of the consolidation guidance that amended the consolidation guidance applicable to VIEs and required enhanced disclosure to provide more information about the Company's involvement in a VIE.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P179_S0	The Partnership must make an evaluation of these entities to determine if they meet the definition of a VIE.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P180_S0	Generally, a VIE is an entity with one or more of the following characteristics: (a) the total equity investment at risk is not sufficient to permit the entity to finance its activities without additional subordinated financial support; (b) as a group, the holders of the equity investment at risk lack: i. the ability to make decisions about an entity's activities through voting or similar rights; ii.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P180_S1	the obligation to absorb the expected loss of the entity; or iii.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P180_S2	the right to receive the expected residual returns of the entity; or (c) the equity investors have voting rights that are not proportional to their economic interests and substantially all of the entity's activities either involve, or are conducted on behalf of an investor that has disproportionately few voting rights.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P181_S0	The revised accounting standard introduced a more qualitative approach to evaluating VIEs for consolidation and requires the Partnership to perform an analysis to determine whether its variable interests give it controlling financial interest in a VIE.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P181_S1	This analysis identifies the primary beneficiary, the entity that must consolidate the VIE, as the entity that has (1) the power to direct the activities of a VIE that most significantly impact the entity's economic performance and (2) the obligation to absorb losses of the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P181_S2	In adopting this revised accounting standard, the Partnership re-evaluated all of its investments to determine if the property owners were VIEs and, if so, whether the Partnership was the primary beneficiary of the VIE.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P181_S3	The guidance also requires an ongoing assessment of whether an enterprise is the primary beneficiary of the VIE.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P182_S0	Under consolidation guidance, the Partnership must make an evaluation of entities which are secured by the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds owned by the Partnership to determine if they meet the definition of a VIE.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P182_S1	On January 1, 2010, the Partnership determined that eight of the entities financed by tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds owned by the Partnership were held by VIEs.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P182_S2	These VIEs were Ashley Square, Bent Tree, Cross Creek, Fairmont Oaks, Iona Lakes, Lake Forest, DeCordova, and Weatherford.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P182_S3	The Partnership then determined that it was the primary beneficiary of six of these VIEs; Bent Tree, Fairmont Oaks, Iona Lakes and Lake Forest, DeCordova and Weatherford and reported these six properties as Consolidated VIEs during 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P182_S4	As a result of adopting the new guidance on January 1, 2010, the Partnership no longer reports Ashley Square and Cross Creek on a consolidated basis.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P183_S0	In February 2011, the Partnership foreclosed on the bonds secured by DeCordova and Weatherford and one of the Partnership's subsidiaries took 100% ownership interest in these limited liability companies.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P183_S1	As a result, the properties are reported as MF Properties.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P183_S2	In June 2011, the ownership of Iona Lakes became a not-for-profit entity, which created a re-consideration event and resulted in Iona Lakes no longer being reported as a Consolidated VIE beginning June 1, 2011.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P183_S3	At December 31, 2011 , the Partnership determined it is the primary beneficiary of three of the remaining VIEs; Bent Tree, Fairmont Oaks, and Lake Forest and has continued to consolidate these entities.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P183_S4	At December 31, 2011, the Partnership holds four bonds which were purchased after January 1, 2010, Autumn Pines, GMF-Madison Tower, GMF-Warren/Tulane, and Lost Creek.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P183_S5	The evaluation of these entities did not result in required consolidation.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P184_S0	The Partnership does not hold an equity interest in these VIEs and, therefore, the assets of the VIEs cannot be used to settle the general commitments of the Partnership and the Partnership is not responsible for the commitments and liabilities of the VIEs.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P184_S1	The primary risks to the Partnership associated with these VIEs relate to the entities' ability to meet debt service obligations to the Partnership and the valuation of the underlying multifamily apartment property which serves as bond collateral.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P185_S0	Investments in Tax-Exempt Mortgage Revenue Bonds, Other Tax-Exempt Bonds, and Property Loans Valuation - As all of the Company's investments in tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds are classified as available-for-sale securities, they are carried on the balance sheet at their estimated fair values.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P185_S1	The Company owns 100% of each of these bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P185_S2	There is no active trading market for the bonds and price quotes for the bonds are not available.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P185_S3	As a result, the Company bases its estimate of fair value of the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds using discounted cash flow and yield to maturity analysis performed by management.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P185_S4	This calculation methodology encompasses judgment in its application.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P185_S5	If available, management may also consider price quotes on similar bonds or other information from external sources, such as pricing services or broker quotes.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P185_S6	Pricing services, broker quotes and management's analysis provide indicative pricing only.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P186_S0	As of December 31, 2011 , all of the Company's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds were valued using discounted cash flow and yield to maturity analyses performed by management.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P187_S0	Management's valuation encompasses judgment in its application.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P188_S0	The key assumption in management's yield to maturity analysis is the range of effective yields on the individual bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P188_S1	At December 31, 2011 , the range of effective yields on the individual bonds was 6.3% to 9.0%.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P188_S2	Additionally, the Company calculated the sensitivity of the key assumption used in calculating the fair values of these bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P188_S3	Assuming an immediate 10 percent adverse change in the key assumption, the effective yields on the individual bonds would increase to a range of 6.9% to 9.9% and would result in additional unrealized losses on the bond portfolio of approximately $10.7 million.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P188_S4	This sensitivity analysis is hypothetical and is as of a specific point in time.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P188_S5	The results of the sensitivity analysis may not be indicative of actual changes in fair value and should be used with caution.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P189_S0	The estimated future cash flow of each revenue bond depends on the operations of the underlying property and, therefore, is subject to a significant amount of uncertainty in the estimation of future rental receipts, future real estate operating expenses, and future capital expenditures.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P189_S1	Such estimates are affected by economic factors such as the rental markets and labor markets in which the property operates, the current capitalization rates for properties in the rental markets, and tax and insurance expenses.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P189_S2	Different conditions or different assumptions applied to the calculation may provide different results.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P189_S3	The Partnership periodically compares its estimates with historical results to evaluate the reasonableness and accuracy of its estimates and adjusts its estimates accordingly.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P190_S0	Review of securities for other-than-temporary impairment - The Company periodically reviews each of its mortgage revenue bonds for impairment.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P190_S1	The Company evaluates whether a decline in the fair value of a security below its amortized cost is other-than-temporary based on a number of factors including:
1059142_12_ITEM7_P191_S0	Recoveries or additional declines in fair value after the balance sheet date.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P192_S0	While the Company evaluates all available information, it focuses specifically on whether it has the intent to sell the securities prior to the time that their value recovers or until maturity, whether it is likely that the Company will be required to sell the securities before a recovery in value and whether the Company expects to recover the securities' entire amortized cost basis.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P192_S1	The ability to recover the securities' entire amortized cost basis is based on the likelihood of the issuer being able to make required principal and interest payments on the security.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P193_S0	The primary source of repayment of the amortized cost is the cash flows produced by the property which serves as the collateral for the bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P193_S1	The Company utilizes a discounted cash flow model for the underlying property and compares the results of the model to the amortized cost basis of the bond.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P193_S2	The model reflects the cash flows expected to be generated by the underlying property over a ten year period, including an assumed property sale at the end of year ten, discounted using the effective interest rate on the bond in accordance with the accounting guidance on other than temporary impairment of debt securities.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P193_S3	The inputs to these models require management to make numerous subjective assumptions, the most significant of which include:
1059142_12_ITEM7_P194_S0	Revenue and expense projections for the property operations, which result in the estimated net operating income generated over the ten year holding period assumed in the model.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P195_S0	Base year (model year one) assumptions are based on historical financial results and operating budget information.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P196_S0	The capitalization rate utilized to estimate the sales proceeds from an assumed property sale in year ten of the model.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P196_S1	The capitalization rate used in the current year models was 7.0% which the Partnership believes represents a reasonable market rate for multifamily properties.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P197_S0	The revenue, expense and resulting net operating income projections which are the basis for the discounted cash flow model are based on judgment.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P198_S0	Operating results from a multifamily residential property depend on the rental and occupancy rates of the property and the level of operating expenses.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P199_S0	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, apartments in the market areas in which a property is located.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P199_S1	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and interest rates on single-family mortgage loans.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P199_S2	In addition, factors such as government regulation, inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of a property.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P200_S0	If the discounted cash flows from a property are less than the amortized cost of the bond, we believe that there is a strong indication that the cash flows from the property will not support the payment of the required principal and interest on the bond and, accordingly, the bonds are considered other-than-temporarily impaired.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P200_S1	If an other-than-temporary impairment exists, the amortized cost basis of the mortgage bond is written down to its estimated fair value.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P200_S2	The amount of the write-down representing a credit loss is accounted for as a realized loss on the statement of operations.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P200_S3	The amount of the write-down representing a non-credit loss is recorded to other comprehensive income.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P201_S0	The recognition of an other-than-temporary impairment and the potential impairment analysis are subject to a considerable degree of judgment, the results of which when applied under different conditions or assumptions could have a material impact on the financial statements.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P202_S0	If the credit and capital markets deteriorate further or the Company experiences deterioration in the values of its investment portfolio, the Company may incur impairments to its investment portfolio which could negatively impact the Company's financial condition, cash flows, and reported earnings.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P203_S0	Evaluation of property loans for potential losses - In addition to the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds held by the Company, loans have been made to the owners of some of the properties which secure the bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P203_S1	All of these loans are made on a non-recourse basis.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P203_S2	As a result, the repayment of these loans depend on the cash flows generated by the underlying property.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P203_S3	The Company periodically evaluates these loans for potential losses by utilizing the practical expedient method allowed for in the guidance for measuring impairment on a collateral dependent loan.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P203_S4	The Company estimates the fair value of the property and compares the fair value to the outstanding tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds plus any property loans.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P204_S0	The Company utilizes the discounted cash flow model discussed above except that in estimating a property's fair value we evaluate a number of different discounted cash flow models that contain varying assumptions.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P204_S1	The various models may assume multiple revenue and expense scenarios, various capitalization rates and multiple discount rates.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P204_S2	We may also consider other information such as independent appraisals in estimating a property's fair value.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P205_S0	If the estimated fair value of the property after deducting the amortized cost basis of the senior tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond exceeds the principal balance of the property loan then no potential loss is indicated and no allowance for loan loss is needed.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P205_S1	If a potential loss is indicated, an allowance for loan loss is recorded against the outstanding loan amount and a loss is realized.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P206_S0	The determination of the need for an allowance for loan loss is subject to considerable judgment.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P207_S0	Revenue recognition - tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds - Interest on the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds is payable solely from the net cash flow of the underlying properties and reserve funds, if any, set aside pursuant to the bond documents.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P207_S1	These bonds are not the obligations of the state or local housing authorities that issued them and are not backed by any taxing authority.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P208_S0	Base interest income on fully performing tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds is recognized as it is earned.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P208_S1	Base interest income on tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds not fully performing is recognized as it is received.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P208_S2	Past due base interest on tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds, which are or were previously not fully performing, is recognized as it is earned.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P208_S3	The Partnership reinstates the accrual of base interest once the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond's ability to perform is adequately demonstrated.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P208_S4	Contingent interest income, which is only received by the Partnership if the property financed by a tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond that contains a contingent interest provision generates excess available cash flow as set forth in each bond, is recognized when realized or realizable.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P209_S0	Revenue Recognition - investments in real estate - The Partnership's Consolidated VIEs and the MF Properties (see Note 6 to the consolidated financial statements) are lessors of multifamily rental units under leases with terms of one year or less.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P209_S1	Rental revenue is recognized, net of rental concessions, on a straight-line method over the related lease term.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P210_S0	The Partnership's investments in interest rate derivative agreements are accounted for under the guidance that establishes accounting and reporting standards for derivative financial instruments, including certain derivative financial instruments embedded in other contracts, and for hedging activity.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P210_S1	The guidance requires the Partnership to recognize all derivatives as either assets or liabilities in its financial statements and record these instruments at their fair values.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P210_S2	In order to achieve hedge accounting treatment, derivative instruments must be appropriately designated, documented and proven to be effective as a hedge.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P210_S3	The Partnership did not designate its current derivatives as qualifying hedges.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P211_S0	The fair values of the interest rate derivatives at inception are their original cost.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P211_S1	Changes in the fair value of the interest rate derivative agreements are recognized in earnings as interest expense.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P211_S2	The fair value adjustment through earnings can cause a significant fluctuation in reported net income although it has no impact on the Partnership's cash flows.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P212_S0	Although the Company utilizes current price quotes by recognized dealers as a basis for estimating the fair value of its interest rate derivative agreements, the calculation of the fair value involves a considerable degree of judgment.
1059142_12_ITEM7_P213_S0	For a discussion on recently issued accounting pronouncements, please see footnote 17 to the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The Partnership's primary market risk exposures are interest rate risk and credit risk.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The Partnership's exposure to market risks relates primarily to its investments in tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and its debt financing.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The Partnership bases the fair value of the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds, which have a limited market, on a discounted cash flow or yield to maturity analysis performed by the General Partner.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P1_S1	This calculation methodology encompasses judgment in its application.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P1_S2	If available, the General Partner may also consider price quotes on similar bonds or other information from external sources, such as pricing services.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P2_S0	As of December 31, 2011 , all of the Partnership 's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds were valued using management's discounted cash flow and yield to maturity analyses.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Pricing services, broker quotes and management's analyses provide indicative pricing only.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Due to the limited market for the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds, these estimates of fair value do not necessarily represent what the Partnership would actually receive in a sale of the bonds.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P3_S0	If uncertainties in the credit and capital markets continue, the markets deteriorate further, or the Partnership experiences deterioration in the values of its investment portfolio, the Partnership may incur impairments to its investment portfolio which could negatively impact the Partnership 's financial condition, cash flows, and reported earnings.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Interest rates are highly sensitive to many factors, including governmental, monetary and tax policies, domestic and international economic and political considerations and other factors beyond the Partnership's control.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The nature of the Partnership's investment in the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and the debt financing used to finance these investments exposes the Partnership to financial risk due to fluctuations in market interest rates.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P4_S2	The tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds bear base interest at fixed rates and may additionally pay contingent interest which fluctuates based upon the cash flows of the underlying property.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P4_S3	As of December 31, 2011 , the weighted average base rate of the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds was approximately 6.2%.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P4_S4	Accordingly, the interest income generated by the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds is generally fixed, except to the extent the underlying properties generate enough excess cash flow to pay contingent interest.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P5_S0	At December 31, 2011, the Partnership has a $94.9 million TEBS financing agreement that provides for interest at a floating rate equal to weekly SIFMA plus 190 basis points.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P5_S1	As a result, the Partnership's cost of borrowing fluctuates with the weekly SIFMA.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P5_S2	The effective interest rate for this credit facility as of December 31, 2011 was 2.05% per annum.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P5_S3	If the average SIFMA Index Rate, including fees, had increased or decreased by 100 basis points for the year ended December 31, 2011, the interest expense payments on this variable-rate debt financing would have increased or decreased by approximately $950,000.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P6_S0	At December 31, 2011, the Partnership has $17.7 million in two TOB facilities that provide for interest at floating rates based on weekly SIFMA plus an average of 194 basis points.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P6_S1	As a result, the Partnership's cost of borrowing fluctuates with the weekly SIFMA.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The effective interest rate for the two TOB facilities as of December 31, 2011 was 1.86% per annum.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P6_S3	If the average SIFMA Index Rate, including fees, had increased or decreased by 100 basis points for the year ended December 31, 2011, the interest expense payments on this variable-rate debt financing would have increased or decreased by approximately $177,000.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P7_S0	The interest rate of the mortgage financing on the MF Properties fluctuates based on the LIBOR.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P7_S1	Accordingly, the cost of borrowing on the debt will increase as the LIBOR increases.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P7_S2	As of December 31, 2011 , the outstanding balance of the mortgage financing of the MF Properties was $46.2 million.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P7_S3	The weighted average effective interest rate for 2011 on the debt outstanding as of December 31, 2011 was approximately 4.2% per annum.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P7_S4	If the average LIBOR Rate, including fees, had increased or decreased by 100 basis points for the year ended December 31, 2011 , the interest expense payments on this variable-rate debt financing would have increased or decreased by approximately $463,000.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P8_S0	The Partnership is managing its interest rate risk on its debt financing by entering into interest rate cap agreements that cap the amount of interest expense it could pay on its floating rate debt financing as follows:
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P9_S0	In order to mitigate its exposure to interest rate fluctuations on the variable rate TEBS Financing, the Sponsor entered into interest rate cap agreements with Barclays Bank PLC, Bank of New York Mellon and Royal Bank of Canada, each in an initial notional amount of approximately $31.9 million which effectively limits the interest payable by the Company on the TEBS Financing to a fixed rate of 3.0% per annum on the combined notional amounts of the interest rate cap agreements through August 2017.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P9_S1	The interest rate cap plus the Facility Fees payable to Freddie Mac result in a maximum potential cost of borrowing on the TEBS Financing of 4.9% per annum.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P10_S0	In conjunction with the TEBS Financing and the payment of the Bank of America credit facility, the $50.0 million interest rate derivative purchased on June 18, 2009, was terminated.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P10_S1	The $4.5 million interest rate cap agreement with Bank of America relates to the Glynn Place mortgage loan and was not renewed in 2011 when the mortgage was extended as discussed in Note 10.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P10_S2	The following table sets forth certain information regarding the Partnership's interest rate cap agreements at December 31, 2010:
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P11_S0	These interest rate derivatives do not qualify for hedge accounting and, accordingly, they are carried at fair value, with changes in fair value included in current period earnings within interest expense.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P11_S1	Interest rate derivative expense, which is the result of marking the interest rate derivative agreements to fair value, resulted in an increase of approximately $2.1 million in interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2011 , as compared to an increase of approximately $572,000 in interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2010 .
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P12_S0	These interest rate derivatives are presented on the balance sheet in Other Assets.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P12_S1	The carrying value of these derivatives was approximately $1.3 million and $3.4 million as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 , respectively.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P13_S0	The fair value of the Partnership's investments in tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds, which bear fixed base interest rates, is also directly impacted by changes in market interest rates.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P13_S1	An increase in rates will cause the fair value of the bonds to decrease.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P13_S2	Although changes in the fair value of the bonds do not impact earnings or cash flow, they affect total partners' capital and book value per unit.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P13_S3	In addition, if the fair value of the bonds decreases, the Partnership may need to provide additional collateral for its debt financing.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P14_S0	The Partnership's primary credit risk is the risk of default on its portfolio of tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and taxable loans collateralized by the multifamily properties.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P14_S1	The tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds are not direct obligations of the governmental authorities that issued the bonds and are not guaranteed by such authorities or any insurer or other party.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P14_S2	In addition, the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and the associated taxable loans are non-recourse obligations of the property owner.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P14_S3	As a result, the sole source of principal and interest payments (including both base and contingent interest) on the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and the taxable loans is the net rental revenues generated by these properties or the net proceeds from the sale of these properties.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P15_S0	If a property is unable to sustain net rental revenues at a level necessary to pay current debt service obligations on the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond or taxable loan on such property, a default may occur.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P16_S0	A property's ability to generate net rental income is subject to a wide variety of factors, including rental and occupancy rates of the property and the level of operating expenses.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P17_S0	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, apartments in the market area in which a property is located.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P17_S1	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and the affordability of single-family homes.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P17_S2	In addition, factors such as government regulation (such as zoning laws), inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems, and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of an apartment property.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P18_S0	As of December 31, 2011 , based on an accumulation of individual circumstances, the Partnership has identified the Woodland Park tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond for which certain actions were necessary to protect the Partnership's position as a secured bondholder and lender.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P18_S1	As of December 31, 2011 , Woodland Park owes the Partnership approximately $15.7 million under tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and approximately $914,000 under a taxable loan.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P18_S2	This taxable loan has a full reserve recorded against it at December 31, 2011 and 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P18_S3	Based on the impairment evaluation (see Note 2 for discussion of our impairment testing method), the Partnership has concluded that no other-than-temporary impairment of its tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond existed at December 31, 2011 and 2010 .
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P18_S4	However, the evaluation identified the interest receivable on the Woodland Park bond was impaired and an approximate $953,000 allowance for loss on receivables was recorded in 2011.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P18_S5	There was no interest receivable allowance recorded at December 31, 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P18_S6	The Partnership will continue to monitor these investments for changes in circumstances that might warrant an impairment charge.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P19_S0	During the impairment evaluation at December 31, 2011, the Partnership identified an impairment of the Iona Lakes approximate $7.3 million taxable loan as a result of a change in the long-term outlook for this property.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P19_S1	Based on the projected future occupancy rates used in our 2011 discounted cash flow model, a resulting loan loss charge and provision for loan losses of approximately $4.2 million was recorded which is attributable to the unitholders.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P20_S0	Defaults on its tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and taxable loans may reduce the amount of future cash available for distribution to unitholders.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P20_S1	In addition, if a property's net rental income declines, it may affect the market value of the property.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P20_S2	If the market value of a property deteriorates, the amount of net proceeds from the ultimate sale or refinancing of the property may be insufficient to repay the entire principal balance of the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond or taxable loan secured by the property.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P20_S3	In the event of a default on a tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond or taxable loan, the Partnership will have the right to foreclose on the mortgage or deed of trust securing the property.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P20_S4	If the Partnership takes ownership of the property securing a defaulted tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond, it will be entitled to all net rental revenues generated by the property.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P20_S5	However, such amounts will no longer represent tax-exempt interest to the Partnership.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P21_S0	The Partnership's primary method of managing the credit risks associated with its tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and taxable loans is to perform a complete due diligence and underwriting process of the properties securing these mortgage bonds and loans and to carefully monitor the performance of such property on a continuous basis.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P22_S0	As the above information incorporates only those material positions or exposures that existed as of December 31, 2011 , it does not consider those exposures or positions that could arise after that date.
1059142_12_ITEM7A_P22_S1	The ultimate economic impact of these market risks on the Partnership will depend on the exposures that arise during the period, the Partnership's risk mitigating strategies at that time and overall business and economic environment.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P0_S0	To the Partners of America First Tax Exempt Investors, L.P.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of America First Tax Exempt Investors, L.P. and subsidiaries (the "Company") as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 , and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income (loss), partners' capital, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2011 .
1059142_12_ITEM8_P1_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P1_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1059142_12_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, such consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of America First Tax Exempt Investors, L.P. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 , and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2011 , in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P5_S0	As discussed in Note 5, the consolidated financial statements include total tax-exempt investments valued at approximately $135,700,000 (45% of total assets) and $100,600,000 (42% of total assets) as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 , respectively, whose fair values have been estimated by management in the absence of readily determinable fair values.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P5_S1	At December 31, 2011 and 2010 , management's estimates were based on discounted cash flow or yield to maturity analyses performed by management.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P6_S0	As discussed in Note 2, the Company has changed its method of presenting comprehensive income in 2011 due to the adoption of the Financial Accounting Standards Board Accounting Standards Update No. 2011-05, Presentation of Comprehensive Income.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P6_S1	The change in presentation has been applied retrospectively to all periods presented.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P7_S0	As discussed in Note 2, the Company adopted guidance related to the consolidation of Variable Interest Entities effective January 1, 2010.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P8_S0	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on the criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated March 2, 2012 , expressed an unqualified opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting.

1059142_12_ITEM8_P10_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_12_ITEM8_P11_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of the consolidated financial statements.
