1059142_13_ITEM7_P128_S2	The remaining increase is related to increased salary and insurance expenses offset by a reduction in professional fees.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P129_S0	Primary sources and uses of funds.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P129_S1	Tax-exempt interest earned on the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds, including those financing properties held by Consolidated VIEs, represents the Partnership's principal source of cash flow.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P129_S2	The Partnership also earns tax-exempt interest from its PHC Certificates, and MBS and may also receive cash distributions from equity interests held in MF Properties.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P129_S3	Tax-exempt interest is primarily comprised of base interest payments received on the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, and MBS.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P129_S4	Certain of the tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds may also generate payments of contingent interest to the Partnership from time to time when the underlying apartment properties generate excess cash flow.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P129_S5	Because base interest on each of the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and MBS is fixed, the Partnership's cash receipts tend to be fairly constant period to period unless the Partnership acquires or disposes of its investments in tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P129_S6	Changes in the economic performance of the properties financed by tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds with a contingent interest provision will affect the amount of contingent interest, if any, paid to the Partnership.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P130_S0	The Consolidated VIEs' and MF Properties' primary source of cash is net rental revenues generated by their real estate investments.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P131_S0	The economic performance of a multifamily apartment property depends on the rental and occupancy rates of the property and on the level of operating expenses.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P131_S1	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, apartments in the market area in which a property is located.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P131_S2	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and the affordability of single-family homes.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P131_S3	In addition, factors such as government regulation (such as zoning laws), inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems, and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of an apartment property.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P132_S0	The primary uses of cash by apartment properties are the payment of operating expenses and debt service.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P133_S0	Other sources of cash available to the Partnership include debt financing, mortgages, and the sale of additional BUCs.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P133_S1	The Company currently has outstanding debt financing of $177.9 million under eight separate credit facilities and mortgages of $39.1 million secured by five MF Properties.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P134_S0	The Partnership's principal uses of cash are the payment of distributions to unitholders, interest and principal on debt financing and general and administrative expenses.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P134_S1	The Partnership also uses cash to acquire additional investments.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P134_S2	Distributions to unitholders may increase or decrease at the determination of the General Partner.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P134_S3	The per unit cash available for distribution primarily depends on the amount of interest and other cash received by the Partnership from its portfolio of tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds and other investments, the amount of the Partnership's outstanding debt and the effective interest rates paid by the Partnership on this debt, the level of operating and other cash expenses incurred by the Partnership and the number of units outstanding.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P134_S4	During the year ended December 31, 2012 , the Partnership generated cash available for distribution of $0.33 per unit.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P134_S5	See Cash Available for Distribution, on a following page within item 7.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P134_S6	As a result, the Partnership was required to supplement its cash available for distribution during 2012, with unrestricted cash and expects to continue to do so until the Partnership is able to complete its current investment plans.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P134_S7	The General Partner believes that upon completion of its current investment plans, the Partnership will be able meet its liquidity requirements, including the payment of expenses, interest on its debt financing, and cash distributions to unitholders at the current level of $0.50 per unit per year without the use of unrestricted cash.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P134_S8	However, if actual results vary from current projections and the actual CAD generated is less than the new regular distribution, such distribution amount may need to be reduced.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P135_S0	The Consolidated VIEs' and MF Properties' primary uses of cash are: (i) the payment of operating expenses; and (ii) the payment of debt service.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S0	The Partnership's operating policy is to use securitizations or other forms of leverage to maintain a level of debt financing between 40% and 60% of the total par value of the Partnership's tax-exempt mortgage bond portfolio.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S1	As of December 31, 2012 , the total par value of the Partnerships' total bond portfolio is approximately $198.6 million which includes the tax-exempt bonds secured by the Ohio Properties and the Greens Property which are eliminated upon consolidation.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S2	The outstanding debt financing arrangements are one TOB facility with Deutsche Bank and the TEBS financing agreement with Freddie Mac which have an outstanding balance of $103.9 million in total.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S3	This calculates to a leverage ratio of 52%.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S4	The Partnership's operating policy is to use securitizations or other forms of leverage to maintain a level of debt financing between 60% and 80% of the total par value of the Partnership's other tax-exempt investments.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S5	The Partnership also has eight outstanding TOB facilities at December 31, 2012, which have total outstanding borrowings of $74.1 million which are securitizations of its PHC Certificates and MBS.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S6	The par value of its PHC Certificates and MBS is $96.9 million which calculates to a leverage ratio of 76%.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S7	Additionally, the MF Properties are encumbered by mortgage loans with an aggregate principal balance of approximately $39.1 million.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S8	These mortgage loans mature at various times from May 2013 through February 2017 (see Note 12 to the consolidated financial statements).
1059142_13_ITEM7_P136_S9	The debt financing plus mortgage loans total $217.1 million results in a leverage ratio to Partnership Total Assets of 51%.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P137_S0	As of September 1, 2010, the Partnership and its Consolidated Subsidiary ATAX TEBS I, LLC, entered into a number of agreements relating to a long-term debt financing facility provided through the securitization of 13 tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds pursuant to Freddie Mac's TEBS program.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P137_S1	The gross proceeds from TEBS Financing were approximately $95.8 million.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P137_S2	After the payment of transaction expenses, the Company received net proceeds from the TEBS Financing of approximately $90.4 million.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P137_S3	The Company applied approximately $49.5 million of these net proceeds to repay the entire outstanding principal of, and accrued interest on, its secured term loan from Bank of America.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P137_S4	The TEBS Financing essentially provides the Company with a long-term variable-rate debt facility at interest rates reflecting prevailing short-term tax-exempt rates.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P137_S5	Under the TEBS Financing, the Company transferred the 13 bonds, which have a total outstanding principal amount of approximately $123.6 million at December 31, 2012, to ATAX TEBS I, LLC, a special purpose entity controlled by the Company (the Sponsor ).
1059142_13_ITEM7_P138_S0	The securitization of these tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds was executed through the issuance of two classes of Certificates.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P138_S1	The Class A TEBS Certificates were issued in an initial principal amount of $95.8 million and were sold through a placement agent to unaffiliated investors.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P138_S2	The Class B TEBS Certificates were issued in an initial principal amount of $20.3 million and were retained by the Sponsor.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P138_S3	The holders of the Class A TEBS Certificates are entitled to receive regular payments of interest from Freddie Mac at a variable rate which resets periodically based on the weekly Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association ( SIFMA ) floating index rate plus certain Facility Fees.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P138_S4	As of closing, the SIFMA rate was equal to 0.25% and the total Facility Fees were 1.9%, resulting in a total initial cost of borrowing of 2.15%.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P138_S5	As of December 31, 2012 , the SIFMA rate was equal to .13% resulting in a total cost of borrowing of 2.03% on the approximate $94.0 million outstanding balance.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P138_S6	As of December 31, 2011 , the SIFMA rate was equal to 0.15% resulting in a total cost of borrowing of 2.05% on the approximate $94.9 million outstanding balance.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P139_S0	Payment of interest on the Class A TEBS Certificates are made from the interest payments received by Freddie Mac from the Bonds and Senior Custody Receipts held by Freddie Mac on designated interest payment dates prior to any payments of interest on the Class B TEBS Certificates held by the Sponsor.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P139_S1	As the holder of the Class B TEBS Certificates, the Sponsor is not entitled to receive interest payments on the Class B TEBS Certificates at any particular rate, but will be entitled to all payments of principal and interest on the Bonds and Senior Custody Receipts held by Freddie Mac after payment of principal and interest due on the Class A TEBS Certificates and payment of all Facility Fees and associated expenses.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P139_S2	Accordingly, the amount of interest paid to the Sponsor on the Class B TEBS Certificates is expected to vary over time, and could be eliminated altogether, due to fluctuations in the interest rate payable on the Class A TEBS Certificates, Facility Fees, expenses and other factors.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P139_S3	Freddie Mac has guaranteed payment of scheduled principal and interest payments on the Class A TEBS Certificates and also guarantees payment of the purchase price of any Class A TEBS Certificates that are tendered to Freddie Mac in accordance with their terms but which cannot be remarketed to new holders within five business days.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P139_S4	The Sponsor has pledged the Class B TEBS Certificates to Freddie Mac to secure certain reimbursement obligations of the Sponsor to Freddie Mac.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P139_S5	The Company also entered into various subordination and intercreditor agreements with Freddie Mac under which the Company has subordinated its rights and remedies with respect to the taxable mortgage loans made by it to the owners of properties securing certain of the Bonds to the rights of Freddie Mac as the holder of the Bonds.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P140_S0	For financial reporting purposes, the TEBS Financing is presented by the Company as a secured financing.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P140_S1	The TEBS Financing offers several advantages over the Company's previous credit facilities which, over time, are expected to positively impact the generation of CAD.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P140_S2	These advantages include: a longer term thereby addressing the previous refinancing risks, better balance sheet leverage thereby providing additional funds for investment, and a lower initial cost of borrowing.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P141_S0	In July 2011, the Company executed a Master Trust Agreement with Duetsche Bank ("DB") which allows the Company to execute multiple TOB structures upon the approval and agreement of terms by DB.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P141_S1	Under each TOB structure issued through the Master Trust Agreement, the TOB trustee issues senior floating-rate participation interests ("SPEARS"), and residual participation interests ("LIFERS").
1059142_13_ITEM7_P141_S2	These SPEARS and LIFERS represent beneficial interests in the securitized asset held by the TOB trustee.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P141_S3	The Company will purchase the LIFERS from each of these TOB Trusts which will grant them certain rights to the securitized assets.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P141_S4	Under each TOB structure, the asset is transferred to a custodian and trustee that provide these services on behalf of DB.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P142_S0	The Master Trust Agreement with DB has covenants that the Company is required to maintain compliance, the most restrictive of which at December 31, 2012, is that cash available to distribute for the trailing twelve months must be at least two times trailing twelve month interest expense.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P142_S1	The Company was in compliance with all of these covenants as of December 31, 2012.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P142_S2	If the Company were to be out of compliance with any of these covenants, it would trigger a termination event of the financing facilities.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P143_S0	In November and December 2012, the Company purchased the LIFERS issued by the trustee over five different MBS TOB Trusts for approximately $6.5 million which are securitizations of mortgage-backed securities with a par value of approximately $31.6 million.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P143_S1	The LIFERS entitle the Company to all principal and interest payments received by the MBS TOB Trusts on the mortgage-backed securities after payments due to the holders of the SPEARS and trust costs.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P143_S2	The Company is reporting the MBS TOB Trusts on a consolidated basis as it has determined it is the primary beneficiary of these variable interest entities.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P143_S3	The MBS TOB Trusts also issued SPEARS of approximately $25.1 million to unaffiliated investors which is the outstanding amount at December 31, 2012.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P143_S4	The SPEARS represent senior interests in the MBS TOB Trusts and some have been credit enhanced by DB.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P144_S0	In July 2012, the Company purchased the PHC Certificate LIFERS issued by the trustee over the PHC TOB Trusts for approximately $16.0 million and pledged the LIFERS to the trustee to secure certain reimbursement obligations of the Company as the holder of LIFERS.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P144_S1	The LIFERS entitle the Company to all principal and interest payments received by the PHC TOB Trusts on the $65.3 million of PHC Certificates held by it after payments due to the holders of the SPEARS and trust costs.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P144_S2	The Company is reporting the PHC TOB Trust on a consolidated basis as it has determined it is the primary beneficiary of these variable interest entities.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P144_S3	The PHC TOB Trusts also issued SPEARS of approximately $49.0 million to unaffiliated investors which is the outstanding amount at December 31, 2012.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P144_S4	The SPEARS represent senior interests in the PHC TOB Trusts and have been credit enhanced by DB.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P145_S0	In July 2011, the Company closed a $10 million financing utilizing the TOB structure with the securitization of the Company's $13.4 million Autumn Pines Apartments tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P145_S1	In December 2011, the Company closed a second $7.8 million TOB financing structured as a securitization of the Company's $15.6 million GMF-Warren/Tulane Apartments and GMF-Madison apartments tax-exempt mortgage revenue and taxable mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P145_S2	The SPEARS were credit-enhanced by DB and sold through a placement agent to unaffiliated investors and the gross proceeds from their sale were remitted to the Company.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P145_S3	The LIFERS were retained by the Company and are pledged to DB to secure certain reimbursement obligations.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P145_S4	In May 2012, the Company retired the $7.8 million TOB financing structure when the GMF-Warren/Tulane and GMF-Madison Tower tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds were sold.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P145_S5	At December 31, 2012, the Company owed $9.8 million on the Autumn Pines TOB financing facility and at December 31, 2011, the Company owed $17.7 million on both TOB facilities.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P146_S0	As a result, the TOB trusts essentially provide the Company with a secured variable rate debt facility at interest rates that reflect the prevailing short-term tax-exempt rates paid by the TOB trusts on the SPEARS.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P146_S1	Payments made to the holders of the SPEARS and the amount of trust fees essentially represent the Company's effective cost of borrowing on the net proceeds it received from the sale of the SPEARS.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P146_S2	The holders of the SPEARS are entitled to receive regular payments from the TOB trusts at a variable rate established by a third party remarketing firm that is expected to be similar to the weekly SIFMA floating index rate.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P146_S3	Payments on the SPEARS will be made prior to any payments on the LIFERS held by the Company.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P146_S4	The Company is accounting for these transactions as secured financing arrangements.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P147_S0	The following table summarizes the amounts outstanding under each TOB Trust and the variable interest rate as of December 31, 2012:

1059142_13_ITEM7_P148_S2	In May 2012, the Partnership issued an additional 12,650,000 BUCs through an underwritten public offering at a public offering price of $5.06 per BUC.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P148_S3	Net proceeds realized by the Partnership from this issuance of these BUCs were approximately $60 million after payment of an underwriter's discount and other offering costs of approximately $4.0 million.

1059142_13_ITEM7_P148_S5	Net proceeds realized by the Partnership from this issuance of these BUCs were approximately $41.6 million after payment of an underwriter's discount and other offering costs of approximately $2.8 million.
1059142_13_ITEM7_P148_S6	There was no equity raise completed in 2011.
