1059142_15_ITEM7_P246_S3	Inflation did not have a significant impact on the Partnership s financial results for the years presented in this report.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P247_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires management of the Company to make a number of judgments, assumptions, and estimates.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P247_S1	The application of these judgments, assumptions, and estimates can affect the amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses reported by the Company.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P247_S2	All of the Company s significant accounting policies are described in Note 2 to the Company s consolidated financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P247_S3	The Company considers the following to be its critical accounting policies because they involve judgments, assumptions and estimates by management that significantly affect the financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P247_S4	If these estimates differ significantly from actual results, the impact on our consolidated financial statements may be material.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P248_S0	Accounting for the TEBS and TOB Financing Arrangements The Company has evaluated the accounting guidance in regard to the M31 and M24 TEBS and TOB financing arrangements (see Note 11 to the Company s consolidated financial statements) and has determined that the securitization transactions do not meet the accounting criteria for a sale or transfer of financial assets and will, therefore, be accounted for as a secured financing transactions.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P248_S1	More specifically, the guidance on transfers and servicing sets forth the conditions that must be met to de-recognize a transferred financial asset.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P248_S2	This guidance provides, in part, that the transferor has surrendered control over transferred assets if and only if the transferor does not maintain effective control over the transferred assets through any of the following:
1059142_15_ITEM7_P249_S0	An agreement that both entitles and obligates the transferor to repurchase or redeem them before their maturity, 2.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P249_S1	The ability to unilaterally cause the holder to return specific assets, other than through a cleanup call, or 3.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P249_S2	An agreement that permits the transferee to require the transferor to repurchase the transferred financial assets at a price that is so favorable to the transferee that it is probable that the transferee will require the transferor to repurchase them.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P250_S0	The M31 and M24 TEBS Financing agreements contain certain provisions that allow the Company to (1) cause the return of certain individual bonds under defined circumstances, (2) cause the return of all of the bonds by electing an Optional Series Pool Release or (3) cause the return of any defaulted bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P250_S1	The Optional Series Pool Release is defined in the agreements closed in 2010 as two specific dates, September 15, 2017, or September 15, 2020, on which the Company has the option to repurchase all of the securitized bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P250_S2	The Optional Series Pool Release is defined in the agreements closed in 2014 as two specific dates, July 15, 2019 or July 15, 2024, on which the Company has the option to repurchase all of the securitized bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P250_S3	Given these terms, the Company has concluded that the condition in item 2 above is present in the agreements and, therefore, effective control over the transferred assets has not occurred.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P250_S4	As effective control has not been transferred, the transaction does not meet the conditions to de-recognize the assets resulting in the M31 and M24 TEBS Financing being presented on the Company s consolidated financial statements as a secured financing.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P250_S5	The TOB Financing agreements contain certain provisions that allow the Company to call the bonds held in the TOB Trusts through their ownership of the LIFERS so effective control has not been transferred resulting in the TOB Financings being presented on the Company s consolidated financial statements as secured financings.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P251_S0	In addition to evaluating the M31 and M24 TEBS Financings as a sale or transfer of financial assets, we have evaluated the securitization trusts associated with the TEBS financing facilities (the M31 TEBS Trust and M24 TEBS Trust ) under the provisions of consolidation guidance.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P251_S1	As part of the M31 and M24 TEBS Financings, certain bond assets of the Partnership were securitized into the M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts with Freddie Mac.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P251_S2	The M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts then issued Class A and B TEBS Certificates.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P251_S3	Other Company investments are securitized into TOB Trusts with Deutsche Bank AG ( DB ).
1059142_15_ITEM7_P252_S0	The TOB trustee then issued SPEARS and LIFERS.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P252_S1	The Partnership has determined that the M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts are VIEs and the Class B Certificates owned by the Partnership create a variable interest in the M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P252_S2	It was also determined that the TOB Trusts are VIEs and the LIFERS owned by the Company create a variable interest entity in the TOB Trusts.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P253_S0	In determining the primary beneficiary of the M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts and TOB Trusts, the Partnership considered the activities of each of the VIEs which most significantly impact the VIE s economic performance, who has the power to control such activities, the risks which the entity was designed to create, the variability associated with those risks and the interests which absorb such variability.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P254_S0	The Partnership has retained the right, pursuant to the M31 and M24 TEBS Financing agreements, to either substitute or reacquire some or all of the securitized bonds at various future dates and under various circumstances.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P254_S1	As a result, the Partnership determined it had retained a controlling financial interest in the M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts because such actions effectively provide the Partnership with the ability to control decisions pertaining to the VIE s management of interest rate and credit risk.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P254_S2	While in the M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts, the bond assets may only be used to settle obligations of the trusts and the liabilities of the trusts do not provide the Class A certificate holders with recourse to the general credit of the Partnership.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P255_S0	The Partnership also determined it was the primary beneficiary of the TOB Trusts as it has the right to cause each TOB trust to sell the securitized asset in each specific TOB Trust.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P255_S1	If the securitized assets were sold, the extent to which the VIE will be exposed to gains or losses from changes in the fair market value of the securitized assets would result from decisions made by the Partnership.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P256_S0	It was determined that the Partnership met both of the primary beneficiary criteria and was the most closely associated with the VIE and, therefore, was determined to be the primary beneficiary under these financing arrangements.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P256_S1	Given these accounting determinations, the M31 and M24 TEBS Financing facilities and the associated M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts are presented as secured financing within the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P256_S2	The TOB Financings and associated TOB trusts are also presented as a secured financing within the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P257_S0	The Partnership invests in mortgage revenue bonds which have been issued to provide construction and/or permanent financing of Residential Properties.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P257_S1	The Partnership generally owns 100% of these bonds and each bond is secured by a first mortgage on the property.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P257_S2	The Partnership has also made taxable property loans to the property owners in certain cases which are secured by second mortgages on these properties.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P258_S0	Although each multifamily and student housing property financed with mortgage revenue bonds held by the Partnership is owned by a separate entity in which the Partnership has no equity ownership interest, the debt financing provided by the Partnership creates a variable interest in these ownership entities that may require the Partnership to report the assets, liabilities and results of operations of these entities on a consolidated basis under GAAP.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P259_S0	Under the consolidation accounting guidance (effective January 1, 2010), the Partnership must make an evaluation of these entities to determine if they meet the definition of a VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P260_S0	Generally, a VIE is an entity with one or more of the following characteristics: (a) the total equity investment at risk is not sufficient to permit the entity to finance its activities without additional subordinated financial support; (b) as a group, the holders of the equity investment at risk lack: i. the ability to make decisions about an entity s activities through voting or similar rights; ii.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P260_S1	the obligation to absorb the expected loss of the entity; or iii.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P260_S2	the right to receive the expected residual returns of the entity; or (c) the equity investors have voting rights that are not proportional to their economic interests and substantially all of the entity s activities either involve, or are conducted on behalf of an investor that has disproportionately few voting rights.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P261_S0	The guidance requires the Partnership to perform an analysis to determine whether its variable interests give it controlling financial interest in a VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P261_S1	This analysis identifies the primary beneficiary, the entity that must consolidate the VIE, as the entity that has (1) the power to direct the activities of a VIE that most significantly impact the entity s economic performance and (2) the obligation to absorb losses of the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P261_S2	In adopting this revised accounting standard, the Partnership re-evaluated all of its investments to determine if the property owners were VIEs and, if so, whether the Partnership was the primary beneficiary of the VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P261_S3	The guidance also requires an ongoing assessment of whether an enterprise is the primary beneficiary of the VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P262_S0	Under consolidation guidance, the Partnership must make an evaluation of entities which are secured by the mortgage revenue bonds owned by the Partnership to determine if they meet the definition of a VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P262_S1	In December 2013, the ownership of Lake Forest became a not-for-profit entity, which created a re-consideration event and resulted in Lake Forest no longer being reported as a Consolidated VIE beginning December 1, 2013.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P262_S2	No changes in the VIEs have occurred subsequent to that date.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P262_S3	At December 31, 2013, the Partnership determined it is the primary beneficiary of two of the VIEs, Bent Tree, and Fairmont Oaks, and has continued to consolidate these entities.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P262_S4	At December 31, 2014, the Partnership held multiple mortgage revenue bonds which were purchased after January 1, 2010; the evaluation of these entities did not result in required consolidation.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P263_S0	The Partnership does not hold an equity interest in these VIEs and, therefore, the assets of the VIEs cannot be used to settle the general commitments of the Partnership and the Partnership is not responsible for the commitments and liabilities of the VIEs.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P263_S1	The primary risks to the Partnership associated with these VIEs relate to the entities ability to meet debt service obligations to the Partnership and the valuation of the underlying multifamily property which serves as bond collateral.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P264_S0	Investments in Mortgage Revenue Bonds and Property Loans Valuation - As all of the Company s investments in mortgage revenue bonds are classified as available-for-sale securities, they are carried on the balance sheet at their estimated fair values.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P264_S1	The Company generally owns 100% of each of these bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P264_S2	There is no active trading market for the bonds and price quotes for the bonds are not available.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P264_S3	As a result, the Company bases its estimate of fair value of the mortgage revenue bonds using discounted cash flow and yield to maturity analysis performed by management.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P264_S4	This calculation methodology encompasses judgment in its application.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P264_S5	If available, management may also consider price quotes on similar bonds or other information from external sources, such as pricing services or broker quotes.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P264_S6	Pricing services, broker quotes and management s analysis provide indicative pricing only.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P265_S0	As of December 31, 2014 , all of the Company s mortgage revenue bonds were valued using discounted cash flow and yield to maturity analyses performed by management.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P266_S0	Management s valuation encompasses judgment in its application.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P267_S0	The key assumption in management s yield to maturity analysis is the range of effective yields on the individual bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P267_S1	At December 31, 2014 , the range of effective yields on the individual bonds was 4.7% to 8.3% per annum.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P267_S2	Additionally, the Company calculated the sensitivity of the key assumption used in calculating the fair values of these bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P267_S3	Assuming an immediate ten percent adverse change in the key assumption, the effective yields on the individual bonds would increase to a range of 5.1% to 9.1% per annum and would result in additional unrealized losses on the bond portfolio of approximately $26.2 million.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P267_S4	This sensitivity analysis is hypothetical and is as of a specific point in time.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P267_S5	The results of the sensitivity analysis may not be indicative of actual changes in fair value and should be used with caution.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P268_S0	The estimated future cash flow of each revenue bond depends on the operations of the underlying property and, therefore, is subject to a significant amount of uncertainty in the estimation of future rental receipts, future real estate operating expenses, and future capital expenditures.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P268_S1	Such estimates are affected by economic factors such as the rental markets and labor markets in which the property operates, the current capitalization rates for properties in the rental markets, and tax and insurance expenses.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P268_S2	Different conditions or different assumptions applied to the calculation may provide different results.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P268_S3	The Partnership periodically compares its estimates with historical results to evaluate the reasonableness and accuracy of its estimates and adjusts its estimates accordingly.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P269_S0	Review of securities for other-than-temporary impairment - The Company periodically reviews each of its mortgage revenue bonds for impairment.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P269_S1	The Company evaluates whether a decline in the fair value of a security below its amortized cost is other-than-temporary based on a number of factors including:
1059142_15_ITEM7_P270_S0	Recoveries or additional declines in fair value after the balance sheet date.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P271_S0	While the Company evaluates all available information, it focuses specifically on whether it has the intent to sell the securities prior to the time that their value recovers or until maturity, whether it is likely that the Company will be required to sell the securities before a recovery in value and whether the Company expects to recover the securities entire amortized cost basis.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P271_S1	The ability to recover the securities entire amortized cost basis is based on the likelihood of the issuer being able to make required principal and interest payments on the security.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P272_S0	The primary source of repayment of the amortized cost is the cash flows produced by the property which serves as the collateral for the bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P272_S1	The Company utilizes a discounted cash flow model for the underlying property and compares the results of the model to the amortized cost basis of the bond.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P272_S2	The model reflects the cash flows expected to be generated by the underlying property over a ten year period, including an assumed property sale at the end of year ten, discounted using the effective interest rate on the bond in accordance with the accounting guidance on other than temporary impairment of debt securities.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P272_S3	The inputs to these models require management to make numerous subjective assumptions, the most significant of which include:
1059142_15_ITEM7_P273_S0	Revenue and expense projections for the property operations, which result in the estimated net operating income generated over the ten year holding period assumed in the model.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P274_S0	Base year (model year one) assumptions are based on historical financial results and operating budget information.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P275_S0	The capitalization rate utilized to estimate the sales proceeds from an assumed property sale in year ten of the model.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P275_S1	The capitalization rate used in the current year models ranged between 4.3% and 7.5% which the Partnership believes represents a reasonable range given the current market for multifamily and student housing properties.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P276_S0	The revenue, expense and resulting net operating income projections which are the basis for the discounted cash flow model are based on judgment.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P277_S0	Operating results from a multifamily, student, or senior citizen residential property depend on the rental and occupancy rates of the property and the level of operating expenses.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P278_S0	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, apartments in the market areas in which a property is located.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P279_S0	Net operating income from the commercial property depends on the number of cancer patients which utilize the cancer therapy center and the ability to hire and retain key employees to provide the related cancer treatment.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P279_S1	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and interest rates on single-family mortgage loans.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P279_S2	In addition, factors such as government regulation, inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of a property.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P280_S0	If the discounted cash flows from a property are less than the amortized cost of the bond, we believe that there is a strong indication that the cash flows from the property will not support the payment of the required principal and interest on the bond and, accordingly, the bonds are considered other-than-temporarily impaired.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P280_S1	If an other-than-temporary impairment exists, the amortized cost basis of the mortgage revenue bond is written down to its estimated fair value.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P280_S2	The amount of the write-down representing a credit loss is accounted for as a realized loss on the statement of operations.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P280_S3	The amount of the write-down representing a non-credit loss is recorded to other comprehensive income.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P281_S0	The recognition of an other-than-temporary impairment and the potential impairment analysis are subject to a considerable degree of judgment, the results of which when applied under different conditions or assumptions could have a material impact on the financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P282_S0	If the credit and capital markets deteriorate further or the Company experiences deterioration in the values of its investment portfolio, the Company may incur impairments to its investment portfolio which could negatively impact the Company s financial condition, cash flows, and reported earnings.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P283_S0	Evaluation of property loans for potential losses - In addition to the mortgage revenue bonds held by the Company, loans have been made to the owners of some of the properties which secure the bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P283_S1	All of these loans are made on a non-recourse basis.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P283_S2	As a result, the repayment of these loans depend on the cash flows generated by the underlying property.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P283_S3	The Company periodically evaluates these loans for potential losses by utilizing the practical expedient method allowed for in the guidance for measuring impairment on a collateral dependent loan.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P283_S4	The Company estimates the fair value of the property and compares the fair value to the outstanding mortgage revenue bonds plus any property loans.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P284_S0	The Company utilizes the discounted cash flow model discussed above except that in estimating a property s fair value we evaluate a number of different discounted cash flow models that contain varying assumptions.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P284_S1	The various models may assume multiple revenue and expense scenarios, various capitalization rates and multiple discount rates.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P284_S2	We may also consider other information such as independent appraisals in estimating a property s fair value.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P285_S0	If the estimated fair value of the property after deducting the amortized cost basis of the senior mortgage revenue bond exceeds the principal balance of the property loan then no potential loss is indicated and no allowance for loan loss is needed.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P285_S1	If a potential loss is indicated, an allowance for loan loss is recorded against the outstanding loan amount and a loss is realized.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P286_S0	The determination of the need for an allowance for loan loss is subject to considerable judgment.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P287_S0	Investment in PHC Certificates Valuation - As all of the Company s investments in PHC Certificates are classified as available-for-sale securities, they are carried on the balance sheet at their estimated fair values.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P287_S1	Due to the limited market for the PHC Certificates, these estimates of fair value do not necessarily represent what the Company would actually receive for the sale of the PHC certificates.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P287_S2	The estimates of the fair values of these PHC certificates are based on a yield to maturity analysis which begins with the current market yield rate for a AAA rated tax-free municipal bond for a term consistent with the weighted-average life of each of the Public Housing Capital Fund trusts adjusted largely for unobservable inputs the General Partner believes would be used by market participants.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P287_S3	Management s valuation encompasses judgment in its application and pricing as determined by pricing services, when available, is compared to Management s estimates.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P287_S4	The PHC Certificates are AA and BBB rated by S P. At December 31, 2014, the range of effective yields on the individual PHC certificates was 4.2% to 5.4% per annum.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P287_S5	Additionally, the Company calculated the sensitivity of the key assumption used in calculating the fair values of these PHC certificates which is the yield for a new issuance of a similarly structured security.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P287_S6	Assuming a ten percent adverse change in this key assumption, the effective yields on the individual PHC certificates would increase to a range of 4.7% to 6.0% per annum and would result in additional unrealized losses on the PHC Certificates of approximately $2.3 million.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P287_S7	This sensitivity analysis is hypothetical and is as of a specific point in time.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P287_S8	The results of the sensitivity analysis may not be indicative of actual changes in fair value and should be used with caution.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P288_S0	The Company periodically reviews each class of PHC Certificates for impairment.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P288_S1	The Company evaluates whether a decline in the fair value of a PHC Certificate below its amortized cost is other-than-temporary based on a number of factors including:
1059142_15_ITEM7_P289_S0	A decrease in the ratio of annual appropriations received by the Public Housing Authority from the HUD Capital Fund Program compared to the required principal and interest payments due on the loans payable by the Public Housing Authority to the three separate TOB Trusts with DB ( PHC Trusts ).
1059142_15_ITEM7_P290_S0	Investment in Mortgage-Backed Securities Valuation - The Company values each MBS security based upon prices obtained from a third party pricing service, which are indicative of market activity.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P290_S1	The valuation methodology of the Company s third party pricing service incorporates commonly used market pricing methods, incorporates trading activity observed in the market place, and other data inputs.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P290_S2	The methodology also considers the underlying characteristics of each security, which are also observable inputs, including: coupon; maturity date; loan age; reset date; collateral type; geography; and prepayment speeds.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P291_S0	Management analyzes pricing data received from the third party pricing service by comparing it to valuation information obtained from at least one other third party pricing service and ensuring they are within a tolerable range of difference which the Company estimates as 7.5%.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P291_S1	Management also looks at observations of trading activity in the market place when available.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P291_S2	At December 31, 2014, the range of effective yields on the individual MBS was 3.7% to 5.2% per annum.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P291_S3	Additionally, the Company calculated the sensitivity of the key assumption used in calculating the fair values of the MBS which is the effective yield on new issuances of similarly rated MBS.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P291_S4	Assuming a ten percent adverse change in that key assumption, the effective yields on the MBS would increase to a range of 4.1% to 5.8% per annum and would result in additional unrealized losses on the bond portfolio of approximately $806,000.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P292_S0	This sensitivity analysis is hypothetical and is as of a specific point in time.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P292_S1	The results of the sensitivity analysis may not be indicative of actual changes in fair value and should be used with caution.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P293_S0	The Company periodically reviews each MBS security for impairment.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P293_S1	The Company evaluates whether a decline in the fair value of an MBS below its amortized cost is other-than temporary based on a number of factors including the duration and severity of the decline in fair value and the Company s intent and ability to hold the security until its value recovers.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P293_S2	Each MBS security has been rated either AAA or AA by either S P or Moody s.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P293_S3	A downgrade in rating for and MBS or new issuances of similar MBS with ratings by S P or Moody s below the A rating would be a factor in concluding that an impairment is other than temporary.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P294_S0	Revenue recognition - mortgage revenue bonds - Interest on the Partnership s mortgage revenue bonds is payable solely from the net cash flow of the underlying properties and reserve funds, if any, set aside pursuant to the bond documents.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P294_S1	These bonds are not the obligations of the state or local housing authorities that issued them and are not backed by any taxing authority.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P295_S0	Base interest income on fully performing mortgage revenue bonds is recognized as it is earned.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P295_S1	Base interest income on mortgage revenue bonds not fully performing is recognized as it is received.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P295_S2	Past due base interest on mortgage revenue bonds, which are or were previously not fully performing, is recognized as it is earned.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P295_S3	The Partnership reinstates the accrual of base interest once the mortgage revenue bond s ability to perform is adequately demonstrated.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P295_S4	Contingent interest income, which is only received by the Partnership if the property financed by a mortgage revenue bond that contains a contingent interest provision generates excess available cash flow as set forth in each bond, is recognized when realized or realizable.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P296_S0	Revenue recognition - investments in real estate, MBS, and PHC Certificates - The Partnership s Consolidated VIEs and the MF Properties (see Note 8 to the Company s consolidated financial statements) are lessors of multifamily rental units under leases with terms of one year or less.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P296_S1	Rental revenue is recognized, net of rental concessions, on a straight-line method over the related lease term.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P297_S0	Interest income on the MBS and PHC Certificates is recognized as it is earned.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P298_S0	The Partnership s investments in interest rate derivative agreements are accounted for under the guidance that establishes accounting and reporting standards for derivative financial instruments, including certain derivative financial instruments embedded in other contracts, and for hedging activity.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P298_S1	The guidance requires the Partnership to recognize all derivatives as either assets or liabilities in its financial statements and record these instruments at their fair values.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P298_S2	In order to achieve hedge accounting treatment, derivative instruments must be appropriately designated, documented and prove to be effective as a hedge.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P298_S3	The Partnership did not designate its current derivatives as qualifying hedges.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P299_S0	The fair values of the interest rate derivatives at inception are their original cost.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P299_S1	Changes in the fair value of the interest rate derivative agreements are recognized in earnings as interest expense.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P299_S2	The fair value adjustment through earnings can cause a significant fluctuation in reported net income although it has no impact on the Partnership s cash flows.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P300_S0	Although the Company utilizes current price quotes by recognized dealers as a basis for estimating the fair value of its interest rate derivative agreements, the calculation of the fair value involves a considerable degree of judgment.
1059142_15_ITEM7_P301_S0	For a discussion on recently issued accounting pronouncements, please see footnote 19 to the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The Partnership s primary market risk exposures are interest rate risk and credit risk.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The Partnership s exposure to market risks relates primarily to its investments in mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, MBS, and its debt financing.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The fair value of the Partnership s mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, and MBS are also directly impacted by changes in market interest rates.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P1_S1	An increase in rates will cause the fair value of these investments to decrease.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P1_S2	Although changes in the fair value of the assets do not impact earnings or cash flow, they affect total partners capital and book value per unit.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P1_S3	In addition, if the fair value of the mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, and MBS decreases, the Partnership may need to provide additional collateral for its debt financing secured by these assets.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The Partnership bases the fair value of the mortgage revenue bonds and PHC Certificates, which have a limited market, on a discounted cash flow or yield to maturity analysis performed by the General Partner.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P2_S1	This calculation methodology encompasses judgment in its application.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P2_S2	If available, the General Partner may also consider price quotes on similar bonds or other information from external sources, such as pricing services.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P3_S0	As of December 31, 2014 , all of the Partnership s mortgage revenue bonds were valued using management s discounted cash flow or yield to maturity analyses.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The PHC Certificates were valued using management s yield to maturity analyses and the mortgage-backed securities were priced using third-party pricing services.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P3_S2	Pricing services, broker quotes, and management s analyses provide indicative pricing only.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P3_S3	Due to the limited market for the mortgage revenue bonds and PHC Certificates, these estimates of fair value do not necessarily represent what the Partnership would actually receive in a sale of the bonds and the PHC Certificates.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P4_S0	If uncertainties in the credit and capital markets continue, the markets deteriorate further, or the Partnership experiences deterioration in the values of its investment portfolio, the Partnership may incur impairments to its investment portfolio which could negatively impact the Partnership s financial condition, cash flows, and reported earnings.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P5_S0	Interest rates are highly sensitive to many factors, including governmental, monetary and tax policies, domestic and international economic and political considerations and other factors beyond the Partnership s control.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The nature of the Partnership s mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, MBS, and the debt financing used to finance these assets exposes the Partnership to financial risk due to fluctuations in market interest rates.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P5_S2	The mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, and MBS all bear base interest at fixed rates.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P5_S3	The mortgage revenue bonds may additionally pay contingent interest which fluctuates based upon the cash flows of the underlying property.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P5_S4	As of December 31, 2014 , the weighted average base rate of the mortgage revenue bonds reported in the consolidated financial statements was approximately 6.0% per annum, the weighted average base rate of the PHC Trust Certificates was approximately 5.0% per annum and the weighted average coupon rate of the MBS was approximately 5.0% per annum.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P6_S0	At December 31, 2014, the Partnership has approximately $94.7 million borrowed under the M31 TEBS Financing agreement and approximately $74.4 million M24 TEBS Financing agreement that provides for interest at a floating rate equal to weekly SIFMA plus 142 basis points and 190 basis points, respectively.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P6_S1	As a result, the Partnership s cost of borrowing fluctuates with the weekly SIFMA.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The effective interest rate for these credit facilities as of December 31, 2014 was approximately 1.5% per annum and approximately 2.0% per annum, respectively.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P6_S3	If the average SIFMA Index Rate, including fees, had increased or decreased by 100 basis points for the year ended December 31, 2014 , the interest expense payments on this variable-rate debt financing would have increased or decreased by approximately $1.7 million.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P7_S0	At December 31, 2014, the Partnership has approximately $174.3 million in TOB facilities that provide for interest at floating rates based on weekly SIFMA plus a fee stack.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P7_S1	As a result, the Partnership s cost of borrowing fluctuates with the weekly SIFMA.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P7_S2	The effective interest rate for the TOB facilities as of December 31, 2014 was approximately 3.3% per annum.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P7_S3	If the average SIFMA Index Rate, including fees, had increased or decreased by 100 basis points for the year ended December 31, 2014 , the interest expense payments on this variable-rate debt financing would have increased or decreased by approximately $1.9 million.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P8_S0	The interest rate of the mortgage financing on the MF Properties fluctuates based on the LIBOR.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P8_S1	Accordingly, the cost of borrowing on the debt will increase as the LIBOR increases.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P8_S2	As of December 31, 2014, the outstanding balance of the mortgage financing of the MF Properties was $76.7 million.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P8_S3	The weighted average effective interest rate for 2014 on the debt outstanding as of December 31, 2014 was approximately 3.9% per annum.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P8_S4	If the average LIBOR Rate, including fees, had increased or decreased by 100 basis points for the year ended December 31, 2014, the interest expense payments on this variable-rate debt financing would have increased or decreased by approximately $767,000.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P9_S0	The Partnership is managing its interest rate risk on its debt financing by entering into interest rate cap agreements that cap the amount of interest expense it could pay on its floating rate debt financing as follows:
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P10_S0	In July 2014, to mitigate its exposure to interest rate fluctuations on the variable rate M31 TEBS Financing, the Company entered into interest rate cap agreements with Barclays Bank PLC, the Royal Bank of Canada, and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, each in an initial notional amount of approximately $31.6 million, which effectively limits the interest payable by the Company on the Class A M31 TEBS Certificates to a fixed rate of 3.0% per annum on the combined notional amounts of the interest rate cap agreements through August 15, 2019.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P10_S1	The interest rate cap plus the Facility Fees payable to Freddie Mac result in a maximum potential cost of borrowing on the M31 TEBS Financing facility of 4.4% per annum.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P11_S0	In February 2014, the Company entered into two interest rate cap agreements with SMBC Capital Markets, Inc. for a notional amount of $70.0 million with an effective start date of March 1, 2014.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P11_S1	These agreements effectively limit the interest component of the TOB financing correlated with the SIFMA index to a maximum of 1.0% on $70.0 million of the outstanding borrowings on the MBS TOB financing facilities and the PHC Certificates TOB financing facilities through a three year term ending March 1, 2017.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P12_S0	In September 2010, the Company entered into interest rate cap agreements in connection with M24 TEBS Financing with Barclays Bank PLC, Bank of New York Mellon and Royal Bank of Canada, each in an initial notional amount of approximately $31.9 million which effectively limits the interest payable by the Company on the M24 TEBS Financing facility to a fixed rate of 3.0% per annum on the combined notional amounts of the interest rate cap agreements through August 2017.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P12_S1	The interest rate cap plus the Facility Fees payable to Freddie Mac result in a maximum potential cost of borrowing on the M24 TEBS Financing facility of 4.9% per annum.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P13_S0	The following table sets forth certain information regarding the Partnership s interest rate cap agreements at December 31, 2014:
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P14_S0	These interest rate derivatives do not qualify for hedge accounting and, accordingly, they are carried at fair value, with changes in fair value included in current period earnings within interest expense.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P14_S1	Interest rate derivative expense, which is the result of marking the interest rate derivative agreements to fair value, resulted in an increase of approximately $2.0 million in interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2014 , as compared to an increase of approximately $284,000 in interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P15_S0	These interest rate derivatives are presented on the balance sheet in Other Assets.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P15_S1	The carrying value of these derivatives was approximately $268,000 and $888,000 million as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P16_S0	The Partnership s primary credit risk is the risk of default on its portfolio of mortgage revenue bonds and taxable property loans collateralized by the Residential Properties.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P16_S1	The mortgage revenue bonds are not direct obligations of the governmental authorities that issued the bonds and are not guaranteed by such authorities or any insurer or other party.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P16_S2	In addition, the mortgage revenue bonds and the associated taxable property loans are non-recourse obligations of the property owner.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P16_S3	As a result, the sole source of principal and interest payments (including both base and contingent interest) on the mortgage revenue bonds and the taxable property loans is the net rental revenues generated by these properties or the net proceeds from the sale of these properties.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P17_S0	If a property is unable to sustain net rental revenues at a level necessary to pay current debt service obligations on the Partnership s mortgage revenue bond or taxable property loan on such property, a default may occur.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P18_S0	A property s ability to generate net rental income is subject to a wide variety of factors, including rental and occupancy rates of the property and the level of operating expenses.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P19_S0	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, multifamily residential properties in the market area in which a property is located.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P19_S1	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and the affordability of single-family homes.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P19_S2	In addition, factors such as government regulation (such as zoning laws), inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems, and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of a multifamily residential property.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P20_S0	The Company also has credit risk in its investment in PHC Certificates, which hold custodial receipts evidencing loans made to a number of public housing authorities.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P20_S1	Principal and interest on these loans are payable by the respective public housing authorities solely out of annual appropriations to be made to the public housing authorities by HUD under HUD s Capital Fund Program.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P20_S2	If Congress fails to continue to make annual appropriations for the Capital Fund Program at or near current levels, or there is a delay in the approval of appropriations, the public housing authorities may not have funds from which to pay principal and interest on the loans underlying the PHC Certificates.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P21_S0	Defaults on its mortgage revenue bonds, taxable property loans, or the public housing authorities loans backing the PHC Certificates may reduce the amount of future cash available for distribution to shareholders.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P21_S1	In addition, if a property s net rental income declines, it may affect the market value of the property.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P21_S2	If the market value of a property deteriorates, the amount of net proceeds from the ultimate sale or refinancing of the property may be insufficient to repay the entire principal balance of the mortgage revenue bond or taxable property loan secured by the property.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P22_S0	In the event of a default on a mortgage revenue bond or taxable property loan, the Partnership will have the right to foreclose on the mortgage or deed of trust securing the property.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P22_S1	If the Partnership takes ownership of the property securing a defaulted mortgage revenue bond, it will be entitled to all net rental revenues generated by the property.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P22_S2	If such an event occurs, such amounts may not provide tax-exempt income to the Partnership.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P23_S0	The Partnership s primary method of managing the credit risks associated with its mortgage revenue bonds and taxable property loans is to perform a complete due diligence and underwriting process of the properties securing these mortgage revenue bonds and loans and to carefully monitor the performance of such property on a continuous basis.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P24_S0	The Company s primary method of managing the credit risk associated with the PHC Certificates is to monitor the rating report issued at least annually by a rating agency for each of three PHC Certificates.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P25_S0	As the above information incorporates only those material positions or exposures that existed as of December 31, 2014 , it does not consider those exposures or positions that could arise after that date.
1059142_15_ITEM7A_P25_S1	The ultimate economic impact of these market risks on the Partnership will depend on the exposures that arise during the period, the Partnership s risk mitigating strategies at that time and overall business and economic environment.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P0_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of America First Multifamily Investors, L.P. and subsidiaries (the "Company") as of December 31, 2014 and 2013, and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income, partners capital, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2014.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P0_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P0_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the financial statements based on our audits.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P1_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1059142_15_ITEM8_P1_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P2_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P2_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P2_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P3_S0	In our opinion, such consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of America First Multifamily Investors, L.P. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2014 and 2013, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2014, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P4_S0	As discussed in Notes 5, 6 and 9, the consolidated financial statements include total investments valued at approximately $521,000,000 (70% of total assets) and $351,500,000 (66% of total assets) as of December 31, 2014 and 2013, respectively, whose fair values have been estimated by management in the absence of readily determinable fair values.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P4_S1	At December 31, 2014 and 2013, management s estimates were based on discounted cash flows or yield to maturity analyses performed by management.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P5_S0	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2014, based on the criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated March 5, 2015, expressed an unqualified opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P6_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P7_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P8_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P9_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P10_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P11_S0	America First Multifamily Investors, L.P. (the Partnership ) was formed on April 2, 1998, under the Delaware Revised Uniform Limited Partnership Act for the purpose of acquiring, holding, selling and otherwise dealing with a portfolio of mortgage revenue bonds which have been issued to provide construction and/or permanent financing for affordable multifamily and student housing (collectively Residential Properties ) and commercial properties.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P11_S1	The Partnership expects and believes the interest earned on these bonds is excludable from gross income for federal income tax purposes.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P11_S2	As a result, most of the income earned by the Partnership is exempt from federal income taxes.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P12_S0	Our general partner is America First Capital Associates Limited Partnership Two ( AFCA 2 or General Partner ).
1059142_15_ITEM8_P12_S1	The Partnership will terminate on December 31, 2050, unless terminated earlier under provisions of its Agreement of Limited Partnership.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P13_S0	Principles of Consolidation The Company refers to the Partnership and the consolidated VIEs (defined below).
1059142_15_ITEM8_P14_S0	The consolidated financial statements of the Company reported in this Form 10-K include the financial position and results of operations of the Partnership, the MF Properties owned by various limited partnerships in which one of the Partnership s wholly-owned subsidiaries (each a Holding Company ) holds a 99% limited partner interest, two entities in which the Partnership does not hold an ownership interest but which own multifamily properties financed with mortgage revenue bonds held by the Partnership and which are treated as variable interest entities ( VIEs ) of which the Partnership has been determined to be the primary beneficiary (the Consolidated VIEs ).
1059142_15_ITEM8_P14_S1	The Consolidated Subsidiaries of the Partnership consist of:
1059142_15_ITEM8_P15_S0	Financing ( M24 TEBS Financing ) with Freddie Mac (Note 11).
1059142_15_ITEM8_P16_S0	ATAX TEBS II, LLC, a special purpose entity owned and controlled by the Partnership, created in 2014 to hold mortgage revenue bonds in order to facilitate the second TEBS financing ( M31 TEBS Financing ) with Freddie Mac (Note 11).
1059142_15_ITEM8_P17_S0	Nine multifamily residential properties, including multifamily, student, and senior citizen housing ( MF Properties ) which are either wholly or majority owned by subsidiaries of the Partnership.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P18_S0	Under the consolidation guidance, the Partnership must make an evaluation of the entities which own the Residential Properties and commercial property financed with mortgage revenue bonds it holds to determine if these entities meet the definition of a VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P19_S0	Generally, a VIE is an entity with one or more of the following characteristics: (a) the total equity investment at risk is not sufficient to permit the entity to finance its activities without additional subordinated financial support; (b) as a group, the holders of the equity investment at risk lack (i) the ability to make decisions about an entity s activities through voting or similar rights, (ii) the obligation to absorb the expected losses of the entity, or (iii) the right to receive the expected residual returns of the entity; or (c) the equity investors have voting rights that are not proportional to their economic interests and substantially all of the entity s activities either involve, or are conducted on behalf of, an investor that has disproportionately few voting rights.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P20_S0	The guidance requires the Partnership to perform an analysis to determine whether its variable interests give it a controlling financial interest in a VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P20_S1	This analysis identifies the primary beneficiary, the entity that must consolidate the VIE, as the entity that has (1) the power to direct the activities of a VIE that most significantly impact the entity s economic performance and (2) the obligation to absorb losses of the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P20_S2	Upon adoption of this revised accounting standard, the Partnership re-evaluated all of its investments to determine if the property owners are VIEs and, if so, whether the Partnership is the primary beneficiary of the VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P20_S3	The guidance also requires ongoing assessments of whether an enterprise is the primary beneficiary of a VIE.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P20_S4	As a result, changes to the Consolidated VIEs may occur in the future based on changes in circumstances.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P21_S0	The accounting guidance on consolidations is complex and requires significant analysis and judgment.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P22_S0	Stand-alone financial information of the Partnership reported in this Form 10-K includes only the financial position and results of operation of the Partnership and the MF Properties without the consolidation of the VIEs.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P22_S1	In the Company s consolidated financial statements, all transactions and accounts between the Partnership, the MF Properties and the VIEs have been eliminated in consolidation.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P23_S0	The General Partner does not believe that the consolidation of the VIEs for reporting under generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America ( GAAP ) impacts the Partnership s tax status, amounts reported to Beneficial Unit Certificate ( BUC ) holders on IRS Form K-1, the Partnership s ability to distribute income to unitholders which it believes to be tax-exempt, the current level of quarterly distributions or the tax-exempt status of the underlying mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P24_S0	Acquisition Accounting Pursuant to the guidance on acquisition accounting, the Company allocates the contractual purchase price of a property acquired to the land, building, and leases in existence as of the date of acquisition based on their relative fair values.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P24_S1	The building is valued as if vacant.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P25_S0	The estimated valuation of in-place leases is calculated by applying a risk-adjusted discount rate to the projected cash flow deficit at each property during an assumed lease-up period for these properties.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P25_S1	This allocated cost is amortized over the average remaining term of the leases and is included in the statement of operations under depreciation and amortization expense.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P26_S0	The acquisition related costs to acquire a property are expensed as incurred.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P27_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents Cash and cash equivalents include highly liquid securities and investments in federally tax-exempt securities with maturities of three months or less when purchased.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P28_S0	Concentration of Credit Risk The Company maintains the majority of its unrestricted cash balances at two financial institutions.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P28_S1	The balances insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is equal to $250,000 at each institution.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P28_S2	At various times the cash balances exceeded the $250,000 limit.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P28_S3	The Company is also exposed to risk on its short-term investments in the event of non-performance by counterparties.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P28_S4	The Company does not anticipate any non-performance.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P28_S5	This risk is minimized significantly by the Company s portfolio being restricted to investment grade securities.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P29_S0	Restricted Cash Restricted cash, which is legally restricted to use, is comprised of resident security deposits, required maintenance reserves, escrowed funds, restricted compensating balances, and property rehabilitation.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P29_S1	At December 31, 2014 , certain of our credit facilities require restricted cash balances as additional collateral.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P29_S2	Specifically, the 2014 and 2010 tax exempt bond securitization ( TEBS ) financing facilities, discussed below, required approximately $7.3 million , the three tender option bonds ( TOB ) trusts ( TOB Trusts ) secured by the Public Housing Capital Fund Trust Certificates ( PHC Certificates ) financing facilities ( PHC TOB Trusts ) required approximately $400,000 , and the TOB Trusts secured by mortgage backed securities ( MBS ) financing facilities ( MBS TOB Trusts ) required approximately $2.1 million held in restricted cash.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P30_S0	Interest Receivable Subsequent to the issuance of the Company s financial statements on Form 10-K for the period ended December 31, 2013, certain amounts included in the Consolidated Balance Sheet have been restated to correct an error related to the presentation of interest receivable on taxable loans.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P30_S1	Such correction recorded the loan loss reserve related to interest receivable against the interest receivable line of the consolidated balance sheet rather than against the other assets line, which includes the principle amount of taxable loans.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P30_S2	This correction resulted in a decrease in interest receivable and an increase in other assets of approximately $6.2 million .
1059142_15_ITEM8_P30_S3	This correction did not have an impact on total assets as reported in the Consolidated Balance Sheets and did not have an impact on the Consolidated Statements of Operations for all periods presented.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P30_S4	The statement of cash flows has also been restated to reflect this adjustment for all periods presented.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P31_S0	Investment in Mortgage Revenue Bonds and Other Mortgage Revenue Bonds The Company accounts for its investments in mortgage revenue bonds and other mortgage revenue bonds under the guidance for accounting for certain investments in debt and equity securities.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P31_S1	The guidance requires investments in securities to be classified as one of the following: 1) held-to-maturity, 2) available-for-sale, or 3) trading securities.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P31_S2	All of the Company s investments in mortgage revenue bonds and other mortgage revenue bonds are classified as available-for-sale, and are reported at estimated fair value with the net unrealized gains or losses reflected in other comprehensive income.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P31_S3	Unrealized gains and losses do not affect the cash flow of the bonds, distributions to unitholders, or the characterization of the interest income of the financial obligation of the underlying collateral.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P32_S0	There is no active trading market for the bonds and price quotes for the bonds are not available.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P32_S1	As a result, the Company bases its estimate of fair value of the mortgage revenue bonds using discounted cash flow or yield to maturity analyses performed by management.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P32_S2	This calculation methodology encompasses a significant amount of management judgment in its application.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P32_S3	If available, management may also consider price quotes on similar bonds or other information from external sources, such as pricing services or broker quotes.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P32_S4	Pricing services, broker quotes and management s analyses provide indicative pricing only.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P33_S0	The Company periodically reviews each of its mortgage revenue bonds for impairment.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P33_S1	The Company evaluates whether unrealized losses are considered to be other-than-temporary based on a number of factors including:
1059142_15_ITEM8_P34_S0	Recoveries or additional declines in fair value after the balance sheet date.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P35_S0	While the Company evaluates all available information, it focuses specifically on whether it has the intent to sell the securities prior to the time that their value recovers or until maturity, whether it is likely that the Company will be required to sell the securities before a recovery in value and whether the Company expects to recover the securities entire amortized cost basis.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P35_S1	The ability to recover the securities entire amortized cost basis is based on the likelihood of the issuer being able to make required principal and interest payments on the security.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P36_S0	The primary source of repayment of the amortized cost is the cash flows produced by the property which serve as the collateral for the bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P36_S1	The Company utilizes a discounted cash flow model for the underlying property that serves as collateral on the bond and compares the results of the model to the amortized cost basis of the bond.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P36_S2	These models reflect the cash flows expected to be generated by the underlying properties over a ten year period, including an assumed property sale at the end of year ten, discounted using the effective interest rate on the bonds in accordance with the accounting guidance on other-than-temporary impairment of debt securities.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P36_S3	The inputs to these models require management to make assumptions, the most significant of which include:
1059142_15_ITEM8_P37_S0	Revenue and expense projections for the property operations, which result in the estimated net operating income generated over the ten year holding period assumed in the model.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P38_S0	Base year (model year one) assumptions are based on historical financial results and operating budget information.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P39_S0	The capitalization rate utilized to estimate the sales proceeds from an assumed property sale in year ten of the model.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P39_S1	The capitalization rate used in the current year models ranged between 4.3% and 7.5% which the Company believes represents a reasonable range given the current market for Residential Properties.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P40_S0	The revenue, expense and resulting net operating income projections which are the basis for the discounted cash flow model are based on judgment.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P41_S0	Operating results from a multifamily, student, or senior citizen residential property depend on the rental and occupancy rates of the property and the level of operating expenses.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P41_S1	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of and demand for multifamily residential properties in the market areas in which a property is located.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P41_S2	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and interest rates on single-family mortgage loans.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P42_S0	Net operating income from the commercial property depends on the number of cancer patients which utilize the cancer therapy center and the ability to hire and retain key employees to provide the related cancer treatment.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P42_S1	In addition, factors such as government regulation, inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of a property.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P43_S0	If the discounted cash flows from a property are less than the amortized cost of the bond, the Company believes that there is a strong indication that the cash flows from the property will not support the payment of the required principal and interest on the bond and, accordingly, the bonds are considered other-than-temporarily impaired.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P43_S1	If an other-than-temporary impairment exists, the amortized cost basis of the mortgage revenue bond is written down to its estimated fair value.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P43_S2	The amount of the write-down representing a credit loss is accounted for as a realized loss on the statement of operations.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P43_S3	The amount of the write-down representing a non-credit loss is recorded to other comprehensive income.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P43_S4	The difference between the amortized cost basis and the discounted cash flows using the effective interest rate represents the credit loss.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P43_S5	Any residual decline in value would be considered the interest related loss or non-credit loss.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P44_S0	The recognition of an other-than-temporary impairment and the potential impairment analysis are subject to a considerable degree of judgment, the results of which when applied under different conditions or assumptions could have a material impact on the financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P45_S0	If the Company experiences deterioration in the values of its investment portfolio, the Company may incur impairments to its investment portfolio which could negatively impact the Company s financial condition, cash flows, and reported earnings.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P46_S0	The Company owns some mortgage revenue bonds which were purchased at a discount or premium.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P46_S1	The discount or premium on an investment is amortized on an effective yield method and the result is realized in investment income in the current period.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P47_S0	The Company eliminates the mortgage revenue bonds and the associated interest income and interest receivable when it consolidates the underlying real estate collateral in accordance with implementation of the consolidation guidance for variable interest entities.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P48_S0	When the Partnership invests in a mortgage revenue bond which is collateralized by a multifamily or student housing property, the Partnership will evaluate the entity which owns the property financed by the mortgage revenue bond to determine if it is a VIE as defined by the guidance on consolidations.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P49_S0	The guidance on consolidations is a complex standard that requires significant analysis and judgment.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P49_S1	If it is determined that the entity is a VIE, the Partnership will then evaluate if it is the primary beneficiary of such VIE, by determining whether the Partnership will absorb the majority of the VIE s expected losses, receive a majority of the VIE s residual returns, or both.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P49_S2	If the Partnership determines itself to be the primary beneficiary of the VIE, then the assets, liabilities and financial results of the related multifamily or student housing property will be consolidated in the Partnership s financial statements.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P49_S3	As a result of such consolidation, the debt financing provided by the Partnership to such consolidated VIE will be eliminated as part of the consolidation process.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P49_S4	However, the Partnership will continue to receive interest and principal payments on such debt and these payments will retain their characterization as either mortgage revenue bond or taxable interest for income tax reporting purposes.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P50_S0	Since the Partnership has no legal ownership of the VIEs, creditors of the VIEs have no recourse to the Partnership.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P51_S0	Effective December 1, 2013, the ownership of Lake Forest became a not-for-profit entity, a reconsideration event.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P51_S1	As a result of the change in ownership, Lake Forest ceased to be reported as a Consolidated VIE (Note 4).
1059142_15_ITEM8_P52_S0	The Company accounts for its investments in PHC Certificates and MBS under the guidance for accounting for certain investments in debt and equity securities.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P52_S1	The guidance requires investments in securities to be classified as one of the following: 1) held-to-maturity, 2) available-for-sale, or 3) trading securities.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P52_S2	All of the Company s PHC Certificates and MBS investments are classified as available-for-sale, and are reported at estimated fair value with the net unrealized gains or losses reflected in other comprehensive income.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P52_S3	Unrealized gains and losses do not affect the cash flow of the bonds, distributions to unitholders, or the characterization of the interest income of the financial obligation of the underlying collateral.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P53_S0	There is no active trading market for the PHC Certificates and price quotes are not available.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P54_S0	The estimates of the fair values of the PHC Certificates are based on a yield to maturity analysis which begins with the current market yield rate for a AAA rated tax-free municipal bond for a term consistent with the weighted-average life of each of the Public Housing Capital Fund trusts adjusted largely for unobservable inputs the General Partner believes would be used by market participants.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P54_S1	Management s valuation encompasses judgment in its application and pricing as determined by pricing services, when available, is compared to Management s estimates.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P55_S0	The Company periodically reviews each class of PHC Certificates for impairment.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P55_S1	The Company evaluates whether a decline in the fair value of a PHC Certificate below its amortized cost is other-than temporary based on a number of factors including:
1059142_15_ITEM8_P56_S0	Volatility of the fair value of the security.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P57_S0	The Company values each MBS security based upon prices obtained from a third party pricing service, which are indicative of market activity.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P57_S1	The valuation methodology of the Company s third party pricing service incorporates commonly used market pricing methods, incorporates trading activity observed in the market place, and other data inputs.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P57_S2	The methodology also considers the underlying characteristics of each security, which are also observable inputs, including: coupon; maturity date; loan age; reset date; collateral type; geography; and prepayment speeds.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P58_S0	Management analyzes pricing data received from the third party pricing service by comparing it to valuation information obtained from at least one other third party pricing service and ensuring they are within a tolerable range of difference which the Company estimates as 7.5% .
1059142_15_ITEM8_P58_S1	Management also looks at observations of trading activity in the market place when available.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P58_S2	The Company periodically reviews each MBS security for impairment.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P58_S3	The Company evaluates whether a decline in the fair value of a security below its amortized cost is other-than-temporary based on a number of factors including the duration and severity of the decline in fair value and the Company s intent and ability to hold the security until its value recovers.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P58_S4	Each MBS security has been rated either AAA or AA by either S P or Moody s.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P58_S5	A downgrade in rating for each MBS or new issuances of similar MBS with ratings by S P or Moody s below the A rating would be a factor in concluding that an impairment is other-than-temporary.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P59_S0	Investments in Real Estate The Company s investments in real estate are carried at cost less accumulated depreciation.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P59_S1	Depreciation of real estate is based on the estimated useful life of the related asset, generally 19 - 40 years on multifamily, student housing, and senior citizen residential apartment buildings and five to 15 years on capital improvements and is calculated using the straight-line method.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P59_S2	Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred, while improvements, renovations, and replacements are capitalized.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P59_S3	The Company also holds land held for investment and development which is reported at cost.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P60_S0	Management reviews each property and land held for investment and development for impairment at least annually and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of a property may not be recoverable.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P60_S1	The review of recoverability is based upon comparing the net book value of each real estate property to the sum of its estimated undiscounted future cash flows.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P61_S0	If impairment exists due to the inability to recover the carrying value of a property, an impairment loss is recorded to the extent that the carrying value of the property exceeds its estimated fair value.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P62_S0	Taxable Property Loans In addition to the mortgage revenue bonds held by the Company, taxable property loans have been made to the owners of some of the properties which secure the bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P62_S1	The repayment of these taxable property loans is dependent largely on the value of the property or its cash flows which collateralize the loans.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P62_S2	The Company periodically evaluates these loans for potential losses by estimating the fair value of the property which collateralize the loans and comparing the fair value to the outstanding mortgage revenue bonds plus any taxable property loans.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P63_S0	The Company utilizes the discounted cash flow model discussed above except that in estimating a property fair value we evaluate a number of different discounted cash flow ( DCF ) models that contain varying assumptions.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P63_S1	The various models may assume multiple revenue and expense scenarios, various capitalization rates, and multiple discount rates.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P63_S2	The Company may also consider other information such as independent appraisals in estimating a property fair value.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P64_S0	If the estimated fair value of the property after deducting the amortized cost basis of the senior mortgage revenue bond exceeds the principal balance of the taxable property loan then no potential loss is indicated and no allowance for loan loss is recorded.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P64_S1	If a potential loss is indicated, an allowance for loan loss is recorded against the outstanding loan amount and a loss is realized.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P65_S0	The determination of the need for an allowance for loan loss is subject to considerable judgment.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P65_S1	For the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013, the Company recognized a provision for loan losses of approximately $75,000 and $168,000 , respectively.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P65_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2012, the Company did not recognize any provision for loan losses (Note 9).
1059142_15_ITEM8_P66_S0	Accounting for Tax Exempt Bond Securitization ( TEBS ) and Tender Option Bond ( TOB ) Financing Arrangements The Company has evaluated the accounting guidance in regard to the M31 and M24 TEBS and TOB Financing arrangements (Note 11) and has determined that the securitization transactions do not meet the accounting criteria for a sale or transfer of financial assets and will, therefore, be accounted for as a secured financing transactions.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P66_S1	More specifically, the guidance on transfers and servicing sets forth the conditions that must be met to de-recognize a transferred financial asset.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P66_S2	This guidance provides, in part, that the transferor has surrendered control over transferred assets if and only if the transferor does not maintain effective control over the transferred assets through any of the following:
1059142_15_ITEM8_P67_S0	An agreement that both entitles and obligates the transferor to repurchase or redeem them before their maturity, 2.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P67_S1	The ability to unilaterally cause the holder to return specific assets, other than through a cleanup call, or 3.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P67_S2	An agreement that permits the transferee to require the transferor to repurchase the transferred financial assets at a price that is so favorable to the transferee that it is probable that the transferee will require the transferor to repurchase them.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P68_S0	The M31 and M24 TEBS Financing agreements contain certain provisions that allow the Company to (1) cause the return of certain individual bonds under defined circumstances, (2) cause the return of all of the bonds by electing an Optional Series Pool Release or (3) cause the return of any defaulted bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P68_S1	The Optional Series Pool Release is defined in the agreements closed in 2010 as two specific dates, September 15, 2017, or September 15, 2020, on which the Company has the option to repurchase all of the securitized bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P68_S2	The Optional Series Pool Release is defined in the agreements closed in 2014 as two specific dates, July 15, 2019 or July 15, 2024, on which the Company has the option to repurchase all of the securitized bonds.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P68_S3	Given these terms, the Company has concluded that the condition in item 2 above is present in the agreements and, therefore, effective control over the transferred assets has not occurred.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P68_S4	As effective control has not been transferred, the transaction does not meet the conditions to de-recognize the assets resulting in the M31 and M24 TEBS Financing being presented on the Company s consolidated financial statements as a secured financing.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P68_S5	The TOB Financing agreements contain certain provisions that allow the Company to call the bonds held in the TOB Trusts through their ownership of the residual participating interests ( LIFERS ) so effective control has not been transferred resulting in the TOB Financings being presented on the Company s consolidated financial statements as secured financings.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P69_S0	In addition to evaluating the M31 and M24 TEBS Financings as a sale or transfer of financial assets, we have evaluated the securitization trusts associated with the TEBS Financing facilities (the M31 TEBS Trust and M24 TEBS Trust ) under the provisions of consolidation guidance.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P69_S1	As part of the M31 and M24 TEBS Financings, certain bond assets of the Partnership were securitized into the M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts with Freddie Mac.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P69_S2	The M31 and M24 TEBS Trusts then issued Class A and B TEBS Certificates.
1059142_15_ITEM8_P69_S3	Other Company investments are securitized into TOB Trusts with Deutsche Bank AG ( DB ).
1059142_15_ITEM8_P69_S4	The TOB trustee then issued senior floating-rate participating interests ( SPEARS ) and LIFERS.
