1059142_16_ITEM1_P36_S0	(1) See Item 7, "Cash Available for Distribution" section of the Company's report.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P37_S0	The following table presents information regarding the financing activities of the Partnership for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014:
1059142_16_ITEM1_P38_S0	(1) See Item 7A, "Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk" section of the Company's report.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P39_S0	Management and Employees We are managed by our General Partner which is controlled by its general partner, the Burlington Capital Group LLC ( Burlington ).
1059142_16_ITEM1_P39_S1	The persons acting as the Board of Managers and executive officers of Burlington act as our directors and executive officers.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P39_S2	Certain services are provided to us by other employees of Burlington and we reimburse Burlington for its allocated share of these salaries and benefits.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P39_S3	We are not charged, and do not reimburse Burlington, for the services performed by executive officers of Burlington.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P39_S4	As of December 31, 2015, we had no employees.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P40_S0	Competition We compete with private investors, lending institutions, trust funds, investment partnerships, and other entities with objectives similar to ours for the acquisition of mortgage revenue bonds and other investments.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P40_S1	This competition could reduce the availability of mortgage revenue bonds for acquisition and reduce the interest rate that issuers pay on these bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P41_S0	Because we hold mortgage revenue bonds secured by Residential Properties, a commercial property, and hold an interest in the MF Properties, we may be considered to be in competition with other real estate in the same geographic areas.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P41_S1	In each city in which the properties financed by the mortgage revenue bonds owned by us or MF Properties are located, such properties compete with a substantial number of other multifamily rental properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P41_S2	Multifamily rental properties also compete with single-family housing that is either owned or leased by potential tenants.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P41_S3	To compete effectively, the multifamily, student, and senior citizen residential properties financed or owned by us must offer quality apartments at competitive rental rates.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P41_S4	In order to maintain occupancy rates and attract quality tenants, the Residential Properties and MF Properties may also offer rental concessions, such as free rent to new tenants for a stated period.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P41_S5	These Residential Properties and MF Properties also compete by offering quality apartments in attractive locations and that provide tenants with amenities such as recreational facilities, garages and pleasant landscaping.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P42_S0	We believe each of the MF Properties, the Residential Properties, and the commercial property are in compliance, in all material respects, with federal, state and local regulations regarding hazardous waste and other environmental matters.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P42_S1	We are not aware of any environmental contamination at any of these properties that would require any material capital expenditure by the underlying properties, and therefore the Partnership, for the remediation thereof.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P43_S0	We are classified as a partnership for federal income tax purposes and accordingly, there is no provision for income taxes.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P43_S1	The distributive share of our income, deductions and credits is included in each Unitholder s income tax return.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P43_S2	We hold interests in all of the MF Properties except the Suites on Paseo through a subsidiary which is a C corporation for income tax purposes.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P43_S3	This subsidiary files a separate income tax return.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P43_S4	Therefore, we are only subject to income taxes on these investments to the extent we receive dividends from the subsidiary.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P44_S0	We consolidate separate legal entities who record and report income taxes based upon their individual legal structure which may include corporations, limited partnerships, and limited liability companies.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P44_S1	The Bent Tree and Fairmont Oaks Consolidated VIEs results of operations were reported as discontinued operations for all periods as presented in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) reporting purposes and are separate legal entities for all years presented.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P44_S2	The Lake Forest Consolidated VIE results of operations were reported for GAAP reporting purposes as a separate legal entity in 2013.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P45_S0	Form K-1, our ability to distribute income to Unitholders which we believe is tax-exempt, the current level of quarterly distributions, or the tax-exempt status of the underlying mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P46_S0	All financial information in this Annual Report on Form 10-K presented on the basis of Accounting Principles Generally Accepted in the United States of America, is that of the Partnership and the VIEs on a consolidated basis.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P46_S1	All references to we, us, and the Partnership in this document mean America First Multifamily Investors, L.P.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P46_S2	As used in this document, the Company refers to the Partnership, its wholly-owned subsidiaries, and its Consolidated VIEs as discussed in Notes 2, 4, 8, 10, 21, and 22 to the Company's consolidated financial statements.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P47_S0	We are a Delaware limited partnership.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P47_S1	Our general partner is AFCA 2, whose general partner is Burlington.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P48_S0	mortgage revenue bonds, mortgage-backed securities, and real estate properties, including multifamily, student and senior citizen housing.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S0	Burlington maintains it s principal executive offices at 1004 Farnam Street, Suite 400, Omaha, Nebraska 68102, and its telephone number is (402) 444-1630.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S1	We do not have any employees of our own.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S2	Employees of Burlington, acting through our general partner, are responsible for our operations and we reimburse Burlington for the allocated salaries and benefits of these employees and for other expenses incurred in running our business operations.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S3	In connection with our operation, AFCA 2 is entitled to an administrative fee in an amount equal to 0.45% per annum of the principal amount of the revenue bonds, other tax-exempt investments, other investments, and taxable property loans held by us.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S4	When the administrative fee is payable by a property owner, it is subordinated to the payment of all base interest to us on the mortgage revenue bond on that property.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S5	Our Amended and Restated LP Agreement provides that the administrative fee will be paid directly by us with respect to any investments for which the administrative fee is not payable by the property owner or a third party.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S6	In addition, our Amended and Restated LP Agreement provides that we will pay the administrative fee to the General Partner with respect to any foreclosed mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S7	AFCA 2 may also earn mortgage placement fees in connection with the identification and evaluation of additional investments that we acquire.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S8	In addition, an affiliate of AFCA 2, Farnam Capital Advisors, LLC ( FCA ), acts as an origination advisor and consultant to the borrowers when mortgage revenue bonds and financing facilities are acquired by the Company.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S9	Any fees will be paid by the owners of the properties financed by the acquired mortgage revenue bonds out of bond proceeds or by the Partnership.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P49_S10	The amount of fees, if any, will be subject to negotiation between AFCA 2, its affiliate, and such property owners.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P50_S0	Properties Management is an affiliate of Burlington that is engaged in the management of multifamily, student and senior citizen residential properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P50_S1	Properties Management earns a fee paid out of property revenues.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P50_S2	Properties Management may also seek to become the manager of multifamily, student and senior citizen residential properties financed by additional mortgage revenue bonds acquired by us, subject to negotiation with the owners of such properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P50_S3	If we acquire ownership of any property through foreclosure of a revenue bond, Properties Management may provide property management services for such property and, in such case, earn a fee payable out of property revenues.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P51_S0	Our sole limited partner is America First Fiduciary Corporation Number Five, a Nebraska corporation.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P52_S0	BUCs represent assignments by the sole limited partner of its rights and obligations as a limited partner to outside third party investors.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P52_S1	Because each such outside third party effectively holds a share of the sole limited partner s rights and obligations as a limited partner, BUCs are also referred to herein as shares or units for purposes of calculating amounts per BUC, and the holders thereof are referred to as Unitholders.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P53_S0	Our annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and press releases are available free of charge at www.ataxfund.com as soon as reasonably practical after they are filed with the SEC.
1059142_16_ITEM1_P53_S1	The information on the website is not incorporated by reference into this Form 10-K.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Cash distributions from us may change depending on the amount of cash available for distribution.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Currently cash distributions are made to its Unitholders at an annual rate of $0.50 per unit.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P0_S2	The amount of the cash per unit distributed by us may increase or decrease at the determination of AFCA 2 based on its assessment of the amount of cash available to us for this purpose.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P0_S3	During the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014, we generated Cash Available for Distribution of $0.53 and $0.40 per unit, respectively.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P0_S4	For the year ended December 31, 2014, the difference between the $0.50 cash distribution paid and the $0.40 per unit cash available for distribution ( CAD ) reported represented return of capital to Unitholders for the 2014 year.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Although we may supplement our cash available for distribution with unrestricted cash, unless we are able to increase our cash receipts through completion of our current investment plans, we may need to reduce the level of cash distributions per unit from the current level.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P1_S1	In addition, there is no assurance that we will be able to maintain our current level of annual cash distributions per unit even if we complete our current investment plans.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Any change in our distribution policy could have a material adverse effect on the market price of our units.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The receipt of interest and principal payments on our mortgage revenue bonds will be affected by the economic results of the underlying Residential Properties and a commercial prope rty.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Although our mortgage revenue bonds are issued by state or local housing authorities, they are not obligations of these governmental entities and are not backed by any taxing authority.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Instead, each of these revenue bonds is backed by a non-recourse loan made to the owner of the underlying Residential Properties and commercial property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P2_S3	Because of the non-recourse nature of the underlying mortgage loans, the sole source of cash to pay base and contingent interest on the mortgage revenue bond, and to ultimately pay the principal amount of the bond, is the net cash flow generated by the operation of the financed property and the net proceeds from the ultimate sale or refinancing of the property, (except in cases where a property owner has provided a limited guarantee of certain payments).
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P2_S4	This makes our investments in these mortgage revenue bonds subject to risks usually associated with direct investments in multifamily real estate.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P3_S0	If a property is unable to sustain net cash flow at a level necessary to pay its debt service obligations on our mortgage revenue bond on the property, a default may occur.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Net cash flow and net sale proceeds from a particular property are applied only to debt service payments of the particular mortgage revenue bond secured by that property and are not available to satisfy debt service obligations on other mortgage revenue bonds that we hold.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P4_S0	In addition, the value of a property at the time of its sale or refinancing will be a direct function of its perceived future profitability.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Therefore, the amount of base and contingent interest that we earn on our mortgage revenue bonds, and whether or not we will receive the entire principal balance of the bonds as and when due, will depend to a large degree on the economic results of the underlying properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The net cash flow from the operation of a property may be affected by many things, such as the number of tenants, the rental and fee rates, operating expenses, the cost of repairs and maintenance, taxes, government regulation, competition from other similar multifamily, student, or senior citizen residential properties, mortgage rates for single-family housing, and general and local economic conditions.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P5_S1	In most of the markets in which the properties financed by our mortgage revenue bonds are located, there is significant competition from other multifamily and single-family housing that is either owned or leased by potential tenants.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Low mortgage interest rates and federal tax credits make single-family housing more accessible to persons who may otherwise rent apartments.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P5_S3	The value of the properties is the only source of repayment of our mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The principal of most of our mortgage revenue bonds does not fully amortize over their terms.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P6_S1	This means that all or some of the balance of the mortgage loans underlying these bonds will be repaid as a lump-sum balloon payment at the end of the term.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P6_S2	The ability of the property owners to repay the mortgage loans with balloon payments is dependent upon their ability to sell the properties securing our mortgage revenue bonds or obtain adequate refinancing.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P6_S3	The mortgage revenue bonds are not personal obligations of the property owners, and we rely solely on the value of the properties securing these bonds for security.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P6_S4	Similarly, if a mortgage revenue bond goes into default, our only recourse is to foreclose on the underlying property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P6_S5	If the value of the underlying property securing the bond is less than the outstanding principal balance and accrued interest on the bond, we will incur a loss.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P7_S0	In the event a property securing a mortgage revenue bond is not sold prior to the maturity or refinancing of the bond, any contingent interest payable from the net sale or refinancing proceeds of the underlying property will be determined on the basis of the appraised value of the underlying property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Real estate appraisals represent only an estimate of the value of the property being appraised and are based on subjective determinations, such as the extent to which the properties used for comparison purposes are comparable to the property being evaluated and the rate at which a prospective purchaser would capitalize the cash flow of the property to determine a purchase price.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Accordingly, such appraisals may result in us realizing less contingent interest from a mortgage revenue bond than we would have realized had the underlying property been sold or refinanced.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P8_S0	There is additional credit risk when we make a taxable loan on a property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P8_S1	The taxable property loans that we make to owners of the Residential Properties that secure mortgage revenue bonds held by us are non-recourse obligations of the property owner.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P8_S2	As a result, the sole source of principal and interest payments on these taxable property loans is the net cash flow generated by these properties or the net proceeds from the sale or refinance of these properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P9_S0	The net cash flow from the operation of a property may be affected by many things as discussed above.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P9_S1	In addition, any payment of principal and interest on a taxable property loan on a particular property will be subordinate to payment of all principal and interest (including contingent interest) on the mortgage revenue bond secured by the same property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P9_S2	As a result, there may be a higher risk of default on the taxable property loans than on the associated mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P10_S0	If a property is unable to sustain net cash flow at a level necessary to pay current debt service obligations on the taxable property loan on such property, a default may occur.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P10_S1	While these taxable property loans are secured by the underlying properties, in general, we do not expect to pursue foreclosure or other remedies against a property upon default of a taxable property loan if the property is not in default on the mortgage revenue bonds financing the property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P11_S0	There are risks associated with our strategy of acquiring ownership interests in MF Properties in anticipation of future bond financings of these projects.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P11_S1	To facilitate our investment strategy of acquiring additional mortgage revenue bonds secured by Residential Properties, we may acquire ownership positions in MF Properties that we expect to ultimately sell as part of a syndication of LIHTCs after the expiration of the compliance period relating to existing LIHTCs issued with respect to the MF Properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Our plan is to provide mortgage revenue bond financing to the new property owners at the time of a syndication of new LIHTCs in connection with a rehabilitation of these MF Properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The market for LIHTC syndications may be negatively affected from time to time by economic and market conditions.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P12_S1	For this and other reasons, we may not be able to sell our interest in these MF Properties after the applicable LIHTC compliance period.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P12_S2	In addition, the value of our interest in these MF Properties will be affected by the economic performance of the MF Properties and other factors generally affecting the value of residential rental properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P12_S3	As a result, we may incur a loss upon the sale of our interest in an MF Property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P12_S4	In addition, we may not be able to acquire mortgage revenue bonds on the MF Properties even if we are able to sell our interests in the MF Properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P12_S5	During the time we own an interest in an MF Property, any net income we receive from these these MF Properties will not be exempt from federal or state income taxation.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P12_S6	Any future issuances of additional units could cause their market value to decline.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P13_S0	We may issue additional units from time to time in order to raise additional equity capital.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P13_S1	The issuance of additional units could cause dilution of the existing units and a decrease in the market price of the units.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P13_S2	In addition, if additional units are issued but we are unable to invest the additional equity capital in assets that generate what we expect and believe to be tax-exempt income at levels at least equivalent to our existing assets, the amount of cash available for distribution on a per unit basis may decline.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We may suffer adverse consequences from changing interest rates.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We have financed the acquisition of some of our assets using variable-rate debt financing.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P14_S2	The interest that we pay on these financings fluctuates with specific interest rate indices.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P14_S3	All of our mortgage revenue bonds bear interest at fixed rates and, notwithstanding the contingent interest feature on some of these bonds, the amount of interest we earn on these bonds will not increase with a general rise in interest rates.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P14_S4	Accordingly, an increase in our interest expense due to an increase in the applicable interest rate index used for our variable rate debt financing will reduce the amount of cash we have available for distribution to Unitholders and may affect the market value of our units.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our use of derivatives is designed to mitigate some but not all of the exposure to the negative impact of a higher cost of borrowing.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P15_S1	An increase in interest rates could also decrease the market value of our mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P15_S2	A decrease in the market value of our mortgage revenue bonds could also decrease the amount we could realize on the sale of our investments and would thereby decrease the amount of funds available for distribution to our Unitholders.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P15_S3	During periods of low prevailing interest rates, the interest rates we earn on new mortgage revenue bonds that we acquire may be lower than the interest rates on our existing portfolio of mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P15_S4	To the extent we finance the acquisition of additional mortgage revenue bonds through the issuance of additional units or from the proceeds from the sale of existing mortgage revenue bonds and we earn a lower interest rate on these additional mortgage revenue bonds, the amount of cash available for distribution on a per unit basis may be reduced.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P16_S0	We are subject to various risks associated with our derivative agreements.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P16_S1	We use derivative instruments to mitigate some, but not all, of the risks to which we are exposed as a result of changing interest rates.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P16_S2	There is no assurance that these instruments will fully insulate us from the interest rate risks to which we are exposed.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P16_S3	In addition, there are costs associated with these derivative instruments and these costs may not ultimately exceed the losses we would have suffered, if any, had these instruments not been in place.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P16_S4	There is also a risk that the counterparty to such an instrument will be unable to perform its obligations to us.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P16_S5	If a liquid secondary market does not exist for these instruments, we may be required to maintain a derivative position until exercise or expiration, which could result in losses to us.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P16_S6	In addition, we are required to record the fair value of these derivative instruments on our financial statements by recording changes in their values as interest earnings or expense.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P16_S7	This can result in significant period to period volatility in our reported net income over the term of these instruments.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P17_S0	There are risks associated with debt financing programs that involve securitization of our mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, and MBS Securities.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P17_S1	We have obtained debt financing through the securitization of our mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, and MBS Securities and may obtain this type of debt financing in the future.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P18_S0	The trust or other entity receives all of the interest payments from its underlying mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, and MBS Securities from which it pays interest on the senior secur ity at a variable or fixed rate.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P18_S1	As the holder of the residual interest, we are entitled to any remaining interest received by the trust holding the securitized asset after it has paid the full amount of interest due on the senior security and all of the e xpenses of the trust, including various fees to the trustee, remarketing agents, credit providers, and liquidity providers.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Specific risks generally associated with these asset securitization programs include the following: Changes in short-term interest rates can adversely affect the cost of an asset securitization financing.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P20_S0	The interest rate payable on the senior securities resets periodically based on the weekly Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association ( SIFMA ) floating index usually tied to interest rates on short-term instruments.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P20_S1	In addition, because the senior securities may typically be tendered back to the trust, causing the trust to remarket the senior securities from time to time, an increase in interest rates may require an increase to the interest rate paid on the senior securities in order to successfully remarket these securities.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Any increase in interest rate payable on the senior securities will result in more of the underlying interest being used to pay interest on the senior securities leaving less interest available to us.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P20_S3	As a result, higher short-term interest rates will reduce, and could even eliminate, our return on a residual interest in this type of financing.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P20_S4	Payments on the residual interests in these financing structures are subordinate to payments on the senior securities and to payment of trust expenses and there are no party guarantees to the payment of any amounts under the residual interests.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P21_S0	We hold a residual interest (known as Class B interests in the TEBS Financing facilities with Freddie Mac and residual participating interests ( LIFER s) in the TOB financing facilities) in the securitization trusts established for the debt financing facilities.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P21_S1	These residual interests are subordinate to the senior securities sold to investors.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P21_S2	As a result, none of the interest received by such a trust will be paid to us as the holder of a residual interest until all payments currently due on the senior securities have been paid in full and other trust expenses satisfied.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P21_S3	As the holder of a residual certificate in these trusts, we can look only to the assets of the trust remaining after payment of these senior obligations for payment on the residual certificates.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P21_S4	No third party guarantees the payment of any amount on the residual certificates.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Termination of an asset securitization financing can occur for a number of reasons which could cause us to lose the assets and other collateral we pledged for such financing.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S1	In general, the trust or other special purpose entity formed for an asset securitization financing can terminate for a number of different reasons relating to problems with the assets or problems with the trust itself.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S2	Problems with the assets that could cause the trust to collapse include payment or other defaults or a determination that the interest on the assets is taxable.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S3	Problems with a trust include a downgrade in the investment rating of the senior securities that it has issued, a ratings downgrade of the liquidity provider for the trust, increases in short term interest rates in excess of the interest paid on the underlying assets, an inability to remarket the senior securities or an inability to obtain credit or liquidity for the trust.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S4	In each of these cases, the trust will be collapsed and the mortgage revenue bonds and other collateral held by the trusts will be sold.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S5	If the proceeds from the sale of the trust collateral are not sufficient to pay the principal amount of the senior securities with accrued interest and the other expenses of the trusts then we will be required, through our guarantee of the trusts, to fund any such shortfall.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S6	As a result, we, as holder of the residual interest in the trust, may not only lose our investment in the residual certificates but could also realize additional losses in order to fully repay trust obligations to the senior securities.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S7	An insolvency or receivership of the program sponsor could impair our ability to recover the assets and other collateral pledged by it in connection with a bond securitization financing.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S8	In the event the sponsor of an asset securitization financing program becomes insolvent, it could be placed in receivership.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S9	In that situation, it is possible that we would not be able to recover the investment assets and other collateral it pledged in connection with the securitization financing or that it would not receive all or any of the payments due from the trust or other special purpose entity on the residual interest held by us in such trust or other entity.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P22_S10	Conditions in the credit markets may increase our cost of borrowing or may make financing difficult to obtain, each of which may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and business.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Economic conditions in international and domestic credit markets have been, and remain, challenging.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Tighter credit conditions and slower economic growth combined with continued concerns about the systemic impact of high unemployment, low wage growth, restricted availability of credit, and overall business and consumer confidence have contributed to a slow economic recovery and it is unclear when and how quickly conditions and markets will improve.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P23_S2	As a result of these economic conditions, the cost and availability of credit has been, and may continue to be, adversely affected in all markets in which we operate.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P24_S0	markets generally and the strength of counterparties specifically has led many lenders and institutional investors to reduce, and in some cases, cease, providing funding to borrowers.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P24_S1	As a result, our access t o debt and equity financing may be adversely affected.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P24_S2	If these market and economic conditions continue, they may limit our ability to replace or renew maturing debt financing on a timely basis and may impair our access to capital markets to meet our liqui dity and growth requirements which may have an adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Federal regulations adopted under the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010 may require us to unwind our tender option bond financing facilities.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S0	On December 10, 2013, U.S. regulators finalized the Volcker Rule adopted under the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010, which limits the ability of banking entities to sponsor or invest in certain types of covered funds (such as private equity funds and hedge funds) or to engage in certain types of proprietary trading in the U.S.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S1	The Volcker Rule restricts banking entities from acquiring or retaining an ownership interest in, sponsoring, or having certain relationships with certain covered funds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S2	As currently structured, TOB Trusts like those used as part of our TOB financing program with DB, fit within the definition of covered funds and will be affected by the Volcker Rule.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S3	The Volcker Rule does not apply to Freddie Mac or more specifically, the M33, M31 and M24 TEBS Financing facilities with Freddie Mac.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S4	The regulators specifically noted that banks will need to evaluate if TOB Trusts are, in fact, covered funds and if so, whether an exception to the definition is available.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S5	The regulators declined to provide a specific exclusion from the definition of covered funds for TOB financing programs.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S6	The preamble also notes that participation in a TOB transaction is not prohibited per se, but is subject to the same restrictions on other covered funds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S7	The effective date for the Volcker Rule was April 1, 2014, however the rule provides for a phase in period during which time banks need to make good faith efforts to have full compliance with the rule by July 21, 2015.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S8	The Federal Reserve has extended this conformance period until July 21, 2016, and has announced it intends to grant a further extension until July 21, 2017, provided that the interest in the covered fund was established prior to December 31, 2013.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S9	At this time, industry participants are working together to modify the structure of TOBs generally so that they qualify for one of the exceptions contained in the Volcker Rule.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S10	As discussed elsewhere in this document, we had approximately $216.5 million and $174.3 million of outstanding debt financing under our TOB program with DB as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S11	If DB terminates its participation in the TOB program, we would need to find another source of financing to replace the DB TOB financing.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S12	We may not, however, be able to secure such replacement financing and if we can get replacement financing, such financing may be on terms less favorable than those offered by DB.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S13	Any changes to our TOB financing program with DB required by the Volcker Rule could have an adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S14	Any downgrade, or perceived potential of a downgrade, of U.S. sovereign credit ratings or the credit ratings of the U.S. Government-sponsored entities (or GSEs) by the various credit rating agencies may materially adversely affect our business.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S15	Our TEBS Financing facilities are an integral part of our business strategy and those financings are dependent upon an investment grade rating of Freddie Mac.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S16	If Freddie Mac were downgraded to below investment grade, it would have a negative effect on our ability to finance our bond portfolio on a longer term basis and could negatively impact Cash Available for Distribution and our ability to continue distributions at current levels.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P26_S17	The federal conservatorship of Freddie Mac and related efforts, along with any changes in laws and regulations affecting the relationship between Freddie Mac and the U.S. Government, may materially adversely affect our business.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P27_S0	The problems faced by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac commencing in 2008 resulting in their being placed into federal conservatorship and receiving significant U.S. Government support have sparked serious debate among federal policy makers regarding the continued role of the U.S. Government in providing liquidity and credit enhancement for mortgage loans.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P28_S0	In 2011, the Obama administration proposed a plan to wind down the government-sponsored enterprises ( GSEs ), and both houses of Congress are considering legislation to reform the GSEs, their functions and their missions.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P28_S1	The future roles of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are likely to be reduced (perhaps significantly) and the nature of their guarantee obligations could be considerably limited relative to historical measurements.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Alternatively, it is still possible that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac could be dissolved entirely or privatized, and, as mentioned above, the U.S. Government could determine to stop providing liquidity support of any kind to the mortgage market.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Any changes to the nature of the GSEs or their guarantee obligations could have broad adverse implications for the market and our business, operations and financial condition.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P29_S1	If Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac were to be eliminated, or their structures were to change radically (i.e., limitation or removal of the guarantee obligation), our ability to utilize TEBS Financings facilities could be materially and adversely impacted.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Our mortgage revenue bonds and PHC Certificates are illiquid assets and their va lue may decrease.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Our mortgage revenue bonds and PHC Certificates are relatively illiquid, and there is no existing trading market for them.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P31_S1	As a result, there are no market makers, price quotations, or other indications of a developed trading market for these mortgage revenue bonds and PHC Certificates.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P31_S2	In addition, no rating has been issued on any of the existing mortgage revenue bonds and we do not expect to obtain ratings on mortgage revenue bonds we may acquire in the future.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P31_S3	Accordingly, any buyer of these mortgage revenue bonds would need to perform its own due diligence prior to a purchase.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P31_S4	As a result, our ability to sell our mortgage revenue bonds and PHC Certificates, and the price we may receive upon their sale, will be affected by the number of potential buyers, the number of similar securities on the market at the time and a number of other market conditions.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P31_S5	As a result, such a sale could result in a loss to us.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P31_S6	Delay, reduction, or elimination of appropriations from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development can result in payment defaults on our investments in PHC Trusts.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P32_S0	We have acquired interests, LIFERS, in three PHC TOB Trusts, which, in turn, hold PHC Certificates that have been issued by three PHC Trusts which hold custodial receipts evidencing loans made to a number of public housing authorities.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P32_S1	Principal and interest on these loans are payable by the respective public housing authorities solely out of annual appropriations to be made to the public housing authorities by HUD under HUD s Capital Fund Program.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P32_S2	Annual appropriations for the Capital Fund Program must be determined by Congress each year, and there is no assurance that Congress will continue to make such appropriations at current levels or at all.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P32_S3	If Congress fails to continue to make annual appropriations for the Capital Fund Program at or near current levels, or there is a delay in the approval of appropriations, the public housing authorities may not have funds from which to pay principal and interest on the loans underlying the PHC Certificates.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P32_S4	The failure of public housing authorities to pay principal and interest on these loans will reduce or eliminate the payments received by us from the PHC TOB Trusts.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P32_S5	A reduction in the rating of PHC Certificates and MBS Securities below investment grade would result in the liquidation of the investment in that TOB Trust Our investment in PHC Certificates and MBS Securities are made pursuant to the provision of our Amended and Restated LP Agreement that allows investment in securities that are not mortgage revenue bonds backed by multifamily housing projects provided that these alternative securities are rated investment grade in one of the four highest rating categories by at least one nationally recognized securities rating agency and provide what we expect and believe to be tax-exempt income.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P32_S6	In the event the investment rating of any of the PHC Certificates held by a PHC TOB Trust or any of the MBS Securities was reduced to less than investment grade, the trustee of the TOB Trust has no obligation to divest of that securitized asset.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P32_S7	Accordingly, we would be required to liquidate our LIFERS in that TOB Trust or liquidate the TOB Trust entirely.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P33_S0	The TOB Trusts have no obligation to purchase the LIFERS and there is no established trading market for the LIFERS.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P33_S1	Likewise, if we liquidate the TOB Trust, any downgrade in the investment rating of the PHC Certificates or MBS Securities will likely decrease the value of the investment.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P33_S2	As a result, we may not be able to divest our position in these LIFERS or terminate the TOB Trusts without incurring a material loss.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P33_S3	Prepayment rates on the mortgage loans underlying our MBS Securities may materially adversely affect our profitability or result in liquidity shortfalls that could require us to sell assets in unfavorable market conditions.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Our MBS Securities are secured by pools of mortgages on residential properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P34_S1	In general, the mortgages which collateralize our MBS Securities may be prepaid at any time without penalty.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Prepayments on our MBS Securities result when homeowners/mortgagees satisfy (i.e., pay off) the mortgage upon selling or refinancing their mortgaged property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P35_S1	When we acquire a particular MBS, we anticipate that the underlying mortgage loans will prepay at a projected rate which, together with expected coupon income, provides us with an expected yield on such MBS.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P35_S2	If we purchase assets at a premium to par value, and borrowers prepay their mortgage loans faster than expected, the corresponding prepayments on the MBS Securities may reduce the expected yield on such securities because we will have to amortize the related premium on an accelerated basis.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P35_S3	Conversely, if we purchase assets at a discount to par value, when borrowers prepay their mortgage loans slower than expected, the decrease in corresponding prepayments on the MBS Securities may reduce the expected yield on such securities because we will not be able to accrete the related discount as quickly as originally anticipated.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Prepayment rates on loans are influenced by changes in mortgage and market interest rates and a variety of economic, geographic, and other factors, all of which are beyond our control.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P36_S1	Consequently, such prepayment rates cannot be predicted with certainty and no strategy can completely insulate us from prepayment or other such risks.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P37_S0	In periods of declining interest rates, prepayment rates on mortgage loans generally increase.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P37_S1	If general interest rates decline at the same time, the proceeds of such prepayments received during such periods are likely to be reinvested by us in assets yielding less than the yields on the assets that were prepaid (to the extent such assets are available for us to reinvest in).
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P37_S2	In addition, the market value of our MBS Securities may, because of the risk of prepayment, benefit less than other fixed-income securities from declining interest rates.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P38_S0	The rent restrictions and occupant income limitations imposed on properties financed by our mortgage revenue bonds and on our MF Properties may limit the revenues of such properties .
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P38_S1	All of the Residential Properties securing our mortgage revenue bonds and the MF Properties in which our subsidiaries hold indirect interests are subject to certain federal, state and/or local requirements with respect to the permissible income of their tenants.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P38_S2	Since federal rent subsidies are not generally available on these properties, rents must be charged on a designated portion of the units at a level to permit these units to be continuously occupied by low or moderate income persons or families.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P38_S3	As a result, these rents may not be sufficient to cover all operating costs with respect to these units and debt service on the applicable mortgage revenue bond.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P38_S4	This may force the property owner to charge rents on the remaining units that are higher than they would be otherwise and may, therefore, exceed competitive rents.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P38_S5	This may adversely affect the occupancy rate of a property securing an investment and the property owner s ability to service its debt.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P39_S0	The properties financed by certain of our mortgage revenue bonds are not completely insured against damages from hurricanes and other major storms.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Two of the multifamily housing properties financed by mortgage revenue bonds held by us are located in an area prone to damage from hurricanes and other major storms.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P39_S2	The current insurable value of these two properties is approximately $29.7 million.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Due to the significant losses incurred by insurance companies in recent years due to damages from hurricanes, many property and casualty insurers now require property owners to assume the risk of first loss on a larger percentage of their property s value.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P40_S1	In general, the current insurance policies on the property financed by us that is located in an area rated for hurricane and storm exposure carry a five percent deductible on the insurable value of the properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P40_S2	As a result, if either of these properties were damaged in a hurricane or other major storm, the amount of uninsured losses could be significant and the property owner may not have the resources to fully rebuild the property, which could result in a default on the mortgage revenue bonds secured by the property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P40_S3	In addition, the damages to a property may result in all or a portion of the rental units not being rentable for a period of time.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P40_S4	Unless a property owner carries rental interruption insurance, this loss of rental income would reduce the cash flow available to pay base or contingent interest on our mortgage revenue bonds collateralized by these properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P40_S5	The properties securing our revenue bonds or the MF Properties may be subject to liability for environmental contamination which could increase the risk of default on such bonds or loss of our investment.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P41_S0	The owner or operator of real property may become liable for the costs of removal or remediation of hazardous substances released on its property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Various federal, state and local laws often impose such liability without regard to whether the owner or operator of real property knew of, or was responsible for, the release of such hazardous substances.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P42_S0	We cannot assure you that the properties that secure our mortgage revenue bonds or the MF Properties, in which our subsidiaries hold indirect interests, will not be contaminated.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P42_S1	The costs associated with the remediation of any such contamination may be significant and may exceed the value of a property or result in the property owner defaulting on the revenue bond secured by the property or otherwise result in a loss of our investment in a property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P43_S0	If we acquire ownership of Residential Properties we will be subject to all of the risks normally associated with the ownership of commercial real estate.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P43_S1	We may acquire ownership of Residential Properties financed by mortgage revenue bonds held by us in the event of a default on such bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P43_S2	We may also acquire indirect ownership of MF Properties on a temporary basis in order to facilitate the eventual acquisition by us of mortgage revenue bonds on these MF Properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P43_S3	In either case, during the time we own an MF Property, we will generate taxable income or losses from the operations of such property rather than tax exempt interest.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P43_S4	In addition, we will be subject to all of the risks normally associated with the operation of commercial real estate including declines in property value, occupancy and rental rates, increases in operating expenses, and the ability to refinance if needed.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P43_S5	We may also be subject to government regulations, natural disasters and environmental issues, any of which could have an adverse effect on our financial results and ability to make distributions to Unitholders.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P44_S0	There are a number of risks related to the construction of Residential Properties that may affect the mortgage revenue bonds issued to finance these properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P45_S0	We may invest in mortgage revenue bonds secured by residential housing properties which are still under construction.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P45_S1	Construction of such properties generally takes approximately twelve to eighteen months.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P46_S0	The principal risk associated with construction lending is that construction of the property will be substantially delayed or never completed.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P46_S1	This may occur for a number of reasons including (i) insufficient financing to complete the project due to underestimated construction costs or cost overruns; (ii) failure of contractors or subcontractors to perform under their agreements; (iii) inability to obtain governmental approvals; (iv) labor disputes; and (v) adverse weather and other unpredictable contingencies beyond the control of the developer.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P47_S0	some of these risks by obtai ning construction completion guarantees from developers, agreements of construction lenders to purchase our bonds if construction is not completed on time, and/or payment and performance bonds from contractors, we may not be able to do so in all cases or s uch guarantees or bonds may not fully protect us in the event a property is not completed.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P47_S1	In other cases, we may decide to forego certain types of available security if we determine that the security is not necessary or is too expensive to obtain in relat ion to the risks covered.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P48_S0	If a property is not completed, or costs more to complete than anticipated, it may cause us to receive less than the full amount of interest owed to us on the mortgage revenue bond financing such property or otherwise result in a default under the mortgage loan that secures our mortgage revenue bond on the property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P48_S1	In such case, we may be forced to foreclose on the incomplete property and sell it in order to recover the principal and accrued interest on our mortgage revenue bond a nd we may suffer a loss of capital as a result.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P48_S2	Alternatively, we may decide to finance the remaining construction of the property, in which event we will need to invest additional funds into the property, either as equity or as a taxable property loan.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P48_S3	An y return on this additional investment would be taxable.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P48_S4	Also, if we foreclose on a property, we will no longer receive interest on the bond issued to finance the property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P48_S5	The overall return to us from our investment in such property is likely to be less than if the construction had been completed on time or within budget.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P49_S0	There are a number of risks related to the lease-up of newly constructed or renovated properties that may affect the mortgage revenue bonds issued to finance these properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P50_S0	We may acquire mortgage revenue bonds issued to finance properties in various stages of construction or renovation.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P50_S1	As construction or renovation is completed, these properties will move into the lease-up phase.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P50_S2	The lease-up of these properties may not be completed on schedule or at anticipated rent levels, resulting in a greater risk that these investments may go into default than investments secured by mortgages on properties that are stabilized or fully leased-up.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P50_S3	The underlying property may not achieve expected occupancy or debt service coverage levels.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P50_S4	While we may require property developers to provide us with a guarantee covering operating deficits of the property during the lease-up phase, we may not be able to do so in all cases or such guarantees may not fully protect us in the event a property is not leased up to an adequate level of economic occupancy as anticipated.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P51_S0	We have assumed certain potential liabilities relating to recapture of tax credits on MF Properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P51_S1	We have acquired indirect interests in several MF Properties that generated LIHTCs for the previous investors in these properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P51_S2	When we acquire an interest in an MF Property, it generally must agree to reimburse the prior partners for any liabilities they incur due to a recapture of LIHTCs that result from the failure to operate the MF Property in a manner consistent with the laws and regulations relating to LIHTCs after we acquired our interest in the MF Property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P51_S3	The amount of this recapture liability can be substantial and could negatively impact the financial performance of the MF Property.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P52_S0	We are not registered under the Investment Company Act.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P52_S1	We are not required to register as an investment company under the Investment Company Act of 1940, as amended (the Investment Company Act ) because we operate under an exemption therefrom.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P52_S2	As a result, none of the protections of the Investment Company Act (such as provisions relating to disinterested directors, custody requirements for securities, and regulation of the relationship between a fund and its advisor) will be applicable to us.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P53_S0	We engage in transactions with related parties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P54_S0	Each of the executive officers of Burlington and four of the managers of Burlington hold equity positions in Burlington.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P54_S1	A subsidiary of Burlington acts as our General Partner and manages our investments and performs administrative services for us and earns certain fees that are either paid by the properties financed by our mortgage revenue bonds or by us.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P54_S2	Another subsidiary of Burlington provides on-site management for some of the Residential Properties that underlie our mortgage revenue bonds and each of our MF Properties and earns fees from the property owners based on the gross revenues of these properties.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P54_S3	The owners of the limited-purpose corporations which own two of the Residential Properties financed with mortgage revenue bonds and taxable property loans held by us are employees of Burlington who are not involved in our operation or management and who are not executive officers or managers of Burlington.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P54_S4	These two Residential Properties are Bent Tree and Fairmont Oaks, which were sold during 2015.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P54_S5	Because of these relationships, our agreements with Burlington and its subsidiaries are related-party transactions.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P54_S6	By their nature, related-party transactions may not be considered to have been negotiated at arm s length.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P54_S7	These relationships may also cause a conflict of interest in other situations where we are negotiating with Burlington.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P55_S0	Unitholders may incur tax liability if any of the interest on our mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, or MBS Securities is determined to be taxable.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P56_S0	earned on the mortgage revenue bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P56_S1	Failure to comply with such requirements may cause interest on the related issue of bonds to be includable in gross income for federal inc ome tax purposes retroactive to the date of issuance, regardless of when such noncompliance occurs.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P57_S0	Should the interest income on a mortgage revenue bond be deemed to be taxable, the bond documents include a variety of rights and remedies that we have conc luded would help mitigate the economic impact of taxation of the interest income on the affected bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P57_S1	Under such circumstances, we would enforce any and all of such rights and remedies as set forth in the related bond documents as well as any other right s and remedies available under applicable law.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P57_S2	In addition, in the event the tax-exemption of interest income on any mortgage revenue bond is challenged by the IRS, we would participate in the tax and legal proceedings to contest any such challenge and wou ld, under appropriate circumstances, appeal any adverse final determinations.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P58_S0	The loss of tax-exemption for any particular issue of bonds would not, in and of itself, result in the loss of tax-exemption for any unrelated issue of bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P58_S1	However, the loss o f such tax-exemption could result in the distribution to our Unitholders of taxable income relating to such bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P59_S0	Certain of our mortgage revenue bonds bear interest at rates which include contingent interest.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P59_S1	Payment of the contingent interest depends on the amount of net cash flow generated by, and net proceeds realized from a sale of, the property securing the bond.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P59_S2	Due to this contingent interest feature, an issue may arise as to whether the relationship between the property owner and us is that of debtor and creditor or whether we are engaged in a partnership or joint venture with the property owner.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P59_S3	If the IRS were to determine that these mortgage revenue bonds represented an equity investment in the underlying property, the interest paid to us could be viewed as a taxable return on such investment and would not qualify as tax-exempt interest for federal income tax purposes.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P59_S4	In addition, we have, and may in the future, obtain debt financing through asset securitization programs in which we place mortgage revenue bonds, PHC Certificates, and MBS Securities into trusts and are entitled to a share of the interest received by the trust on these bonds after the payment of interest on senior securities and related expenses issued by the trust, it is possible that the characterization of our residual interest in such a securitization trust could be challenged and the income that we receive through these instruments could be treated as ordinary taxable income includable in our gross income for federal tax purposes.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P60_S0	Not all of the income received by us is exempt from taxation.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P60_S1	We have made, and may make in the future, taxable property loans to the owners of Residential Properties that collateralize our investments.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P60_S2	The interest income earned by us on these taxable property loans is subject to federal and state income taxes.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P60_S3	In addition, if we acquire direct or indirect interests in real estate, either through foreclosure of a property securing a mortgage revenue bond or a taxable property loan or through the acquisition of an MF Property, any income we receive from the property will be taxable income from the operation of real estate.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P60_S4	In that case, the taxable income received by us will be allocated to our Unitholders and will represent taxable income to them regardless of whether an amount of cash equal to such allocable share of this taxable income is actually distributed to Unitholders.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P61_S0	If we were determined to be an association taxable as a corporation, it will have adverse economic consequences for us and our Unitholders.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P61_S1	We have determined to be treated as a partnership for federal income tax purposes.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P61_S2	The purpose of this determination is to eliminate federal and state income tax liability for us and allow us to pass through our interest which we expect and believe to be tax-exempt to our Unitholders so that they are not subject to federal tax on this income.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P61_S3	If our treatment as a partnership for tax purposes is successfully challenged, we would be classified as an association taxable as a corporation.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P61_S4	This would result in the Partnership being taxed on its taxable income, if any, and, in addition, would result in all cash distributions made by us to Unitholders being treated as taxable dividend income to the extent of our earnings and profits.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P61_S5	The payment of these dividends would not be deductible by us.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P61_S6	The listing of our units for trading on the NASDAQ causes us to be treated as a publicly traded partnership under Section 7704 of the Internal Revenue Code.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P62_S0	A publicly traded partnership is generally taxable as a corporation unless 90% or more of its gross income is qualifying income.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P62_S1	Qualifying income includes interest, dividends, real property rents, gain from the sale or other disposition of real property, gain from the sale or other disposition of capital assets held for the production of interest or dividends, and certain other items.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P62_S2	We expect and believe that substantially all of our gross income will continue to be tax-exempt interest income on our mortgage revenue bonds, but there can be no assurance that will be the case.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P62_S3	While we believe that all of this interest income is qualifying income, it is possible that some or all of our income could be determined not to be qualifying income.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P62_S4	In such a case, if more than ten percent of our annual gross income in any year is not qualifying income, we will be taxable as a corporation rather than a partnership for federal income tax purposes.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P62_S5	We have not received, and do not intend to seek, a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service regarding our status as a partnership for tax purposes.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P63_S0	To the extent we generate taxable income; Unitholders will be subject to income taxes on this income, whether or not they receive cash distributions.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P63_S1	As a partnership, our Unitholders will be individually liable for income tax on their proportionate share of any taxable income realized by us, whether or not we make cash distributions.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P63_S2	There are limits on the ability of our Unitholders to deduct Partnership losses and expenses allocated to them.
1059142_16_ITEM1A_P63_S3	The ability of Unitholders to deduct their proportionate share of the losses and expenses generated by us will be limited in certain cases, and certain transactions may result in the triggering of the Alternative Minimum Tax for Unitholders who are individuals.
1059142_16_ITEM2_P0_S0	Each of the Partnership s mortgage revenue bonds are collateralized by the Residential Properties and commercial properties.
1059142_16_ITEM2_P0_S1	The Partnership does not hold title or any other interest in these properties, other than the mortgages securing the bonds.
1059142_16_ITEM2_P1_S0	At December 31, 2015, our wholly-owned subsidiary held interests in one entity that owns an MF Property, Northern View.
1059142_16_ITEM2_P1_S1	Our wholly-owned subsidiary owns six MF Properties, Arboretum, DeCordova, Eagle Village, Weatherford, The 50/50, and Woodland Park.
1059142_16_ITEM2_P1_S2	In addition, the Partnership owns The Suites on Paseo directly.

1059142_16_ITEM5_P3_S0	Unregistered Sale of Equity Securities The Partnership did not sell any of its units in 2015, 2014, or 2013 which were not registered under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P0_S0	receivables, impairments on assets, deferred gain and rela ted interest, bond discount amortization net of cash received, losses related to Consolidated VIEs, and depreciation and amortization expense on MF Property assets are added back to our net income (loss) as computed in accordance with GAAP.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P1_S0	We use CAD as a supplemental measurement of our ability to pay distributions.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P1_S1	We believe CAD provides relevant information about our operations and is necessary along with net income (loss) for understanding its operating results.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P2_S0	We utilize a calculation of CAD as a means to determine our ability to make distributions to Unitholders.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P2_S1	We believe CAD provides relevant information about our operations and is necessary along with net income for understanding our operating results.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P3_S0	Net income is the GAAP measure most comparable to CAD.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P4_S0	There is no generally accepted methodology for computing CAD, and our computation of CAD may not be comparable to CAD reported by other companies.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P4_S1	Although we consider CAD to be a useful measure of our operating performance, CAD is a non-GAAP measure and should not be considered as an alternative to net income or net cash flows from operating activities which are calculated in accordance with GAAP, or any other measures of financial performance or liquidity presented in accordance with GAAP.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P4_S2	The following sets forth a reconciliation of our net income (loss) as determined in accordance with GAAP and our CAD for the periods set forth.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P5_S0	(1) As described in Note 3 to the consolidated financial statements, Net Interest Income representing contingent interest and Net Residual Proceeds representing contingent interest (Tier 2 income) will be distributed 75% to the Unitholders and 25% to the General Partner.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P5_S1	This adjustment represents the 25% of Tier 2 income due to the General Partner.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P6_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2015, the Consolidated VIEs were sold and we realized approximately $4.8 million of contingent interest and 25% of Tier 2 income due to the General Partner of approximately $1.2 million.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P6_S1	In addition, we reported the sale of Glynn Place and The Colonial which resulted in an approximately $1.2 million and $3.4 million gain, respectively, and 25% of Tier 2 income due to the General Partner was approximately $297,000 and $854,000, respectively.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P7_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2014, we realized the sale of the Autumn Pines bond which resulted in an approximate $873,000 gain and Tier 2 income due to the Partner of approximately $218,000, realized the redemption of the Lost Creek bond which resulted in an approximate $2.8 million gain and Tier 2 income due to the General Partner of approximately $709,000, and received contingent interest from Ashley Square generating $10,000 of Tier 2 income due to the General Partner.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P8_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2013, we realized approximately $1.9 million in Tier 2 income from the Iona Lakes mortgage revenue bond redemption.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P8_S1	We determined that approximately $1.8 million gain from the sale of the Ohio Properties was Tier 2 income in 2010, the year in which the Ohio Properties were sold to the unaffiliated not-for-profit.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P8_S2	As such, 25% of that gain was distributed to AFCA 2 in 2010 and there was no Tier 2 income reported in 2013 related to the Ohio Properties.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P9_S0	For the year ended 2012, the Tier 2 income is approximately $557,000 recognized on the Arbors at Hickory Ridge mortgage revenue bond re-structuring, $668,000 recognized on the GMF-Madison and GMF-Warren/Tulane mortgage revenue bond sale and $1.4 million recognized on the sale of the MF Properties.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P10_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2011, the Tier 2 income is approximately $445,000 recognized on the Briarwood mortgage revenue bond retirement and approximately $308,000 of contingent interest recognized upon the Clarkson mortgage revenue bond retirement.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P11_S0	(2) The developer income amount represents cash received by us for developer and construction management services performed on The 50/50 mixed-use project in Lincoln, Nebraska.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P11_S1	The 50/50 is accounted for as an MF property and the cash received for The 50/50 s development have been eliminated within the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P11_S2	For purposes of CAD, we treat these fees as if received from an unconsolidated entity.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P12_S0	(3) We sold the Greens of Pine Glen (the Greens Property ) in conjunction with the purchase of mortgage revenue bonds secured by the property.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P12_S1	The sales price approximated the 2009 property purchase price and therefore the gain from the sale of the property related entirely to depreciation recapture.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P12_S2	For this reason, we concluded that the gain should be excluded from the calculation of CAD.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P12_S3	(4) In July 2013, we recognized the sale of the Greens Property.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P12_S4	We were required to follow the deposit method of accounting and had to defer the gain until sufficient equity was invested by the new unaffiliated owners (which occurred in July 2013).
1059142_16_ITEM6_P13_S0	Mortgage interest income of approximately $135,000 was received by us between October 2012 and December 31, 2012 and reported in 2012 CAD, and as such, the amount was reversed in the first nine months of the 2013 CAD calculation.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P13_S1	As such, approximately $135,000 of CAD is being reversed out in the 2013 calculation of CAD.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P13_S2	(5) The recognition of the sale of the Ohio Properties allowed us to 1) realize approximately $4.2 million of interest income on the mortgage revenue bonds, 2) recognize approximately $1.1 million of taxable interest income on taxable property loans receivable we held with the Ohio Properties, and 3) realize a $250,000 guarantee fee from the general partner owner of the Ohio Properties all in 2013.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P13_S3	See Note 10 to the Company s consolidated financial statements for additional details.
1059142_16_ITEM6_P14_S0	Mortgage interest income of $3.5 million of the $4.2 million had been previously received by us and reported in CAD, and as such, the amount was reversed in the 2013 CAD calculation.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	In this Management s Discussion and Analysis, all references to we, us, and the Partnership refer to America First Multifamily Investors, L.P. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries at December 31, 2015.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	The Company refers to the Partnership and the Consolidated VIEs.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	We were formed for the primary purpose of acquiring a portfolio of mortgage revenue bonds that are issued by state and local housing authorities to provide construction and/or permanent financing for affordable multifamily and student housing, the Residential Properties, and commercial properties in their market areas.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	The Company includes the assets, liabilities, and results of operations of the Partnership, its wholly-owned subsidiaries and two other consolidated entities in which we do not hold an ownership interest and which are treated as VIEs of which we have been determined to be the primary beneficiary, the Consolidated VIEs.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P1_S2	Bent Tree and Fairmont Oaks, the two Consolidated VIEs, are presented as discontinued operations for all periods presented.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P1_S3	All significant transactions and accounts between us and the Consolidated VIEs have been eliminated in consolidation.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P1_S4	See Note 2 to the Company s consolidated financial statements for additional details.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	As of December 31, 2015, we owned 64 mortgage revenue bonds with an aggregate outstanding principal amount of $534.7 million.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S1	Sixty-two of these bonds were issued by various state and local housing authorities in order to provide construction and/or permanent financing for 44 Residential Properties containing a total of 8,041 rental units located in the states of California, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Louisiana, Maryland, Minnesota, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, South Carolina, Tennessee, and Texas.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S2	Two of the bonds properties located in Texas are not operational and are under construction and two bonds are collateralized by commercial real estate located in Tennessee.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S3	Each of the sixty-two mortgage revenue bonds are secured by mortgages or deeds of trust on the financed Residential Properties.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S4	Two mortgage revenue bonds are secured by ground, facility, and equipment of a commercial ancillary health care facility.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S5	As of December 31, 2014, we owned 55 mortgage revenue bonds with an aggregate outstanding principal amount of $424.2 million.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S6	These bonds were issued by various state and local housing authorities in order to provide construction and/or permanent financing for 35 Residential Properties containing a total of 6,527 rental units located in the states of California, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Louisiana, Maryland, Minnesota, North Carolina, Ohio, South Carolina, Tennessee, and Texas.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S7	Three of the bonds properties located in Texas are not operational and are under construction and two bonds are collateralized by commercial real estate located in Tennessee.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S8	Each of the fifty-one mortgage revenue bonds are secured by mortgages or deeds of trust on the financed Residential Properties.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P2_S9	Two mortgage revenue bonds are secured by ground, facility, and equipment of a commercial ancillary health care facility.

1059142_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	We did not include Glynn Place and The Colonial beyond their August and May 2015 sale dates, respectively.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P16_S2	The increase in net income for 2015, as compared to 2014 is attributable, for the most part, to a gain of approximately $4.6 million reported on the sale of Glynn Place and The Colonial in 2015.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P16_S3	Excluding these 2015 gains the majority of the increase in the loss 2015 as compared to 2014 was attributable to the property operations after the completion of The 50/50 MF Property in August 2014 and the Suites on Paseo was added to the MF Properties in September 2015.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	During 2015, The 50/50 MF Property began to accrue real estate taxes and the Suites on Paseo incurred one time acquisition and accrued expenses.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P17_S1	The increase in revenue and a decrease in loss from continuing operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to the year ended December 31, 2013 can be attributed to the completion and lease up of The 50/50 in 2014.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P17_S2	We reported gains of approximately $3.2 million from the recognition of the sale of the Ohio Properties and Greens Property for the year ended December 31, 2013.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P17_S3	See Notes 8, 10, and 21 to the Company s consolidated financial statements for additional details.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	In April 2015, the property owners entered into brokerage contracts to sell Bent Tree and Fairmont Oaks, the Consolidated VIEs.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	As a result, these entities met the criteria for discontinued operations presentation and have been classified as such in the Company s consolidated financial statements for all periods presented.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P18_S2	The sales of the Consolidated VIEs were closed in the fourth quarter of 2015 with the gains and results of operations of the Consolidated VIEs reported as part of the discontinued operations in net income for all periods presented.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P18_S3	The Company reported gains of approximately $3.2 million related to the sale of the Consolidated VIEs as discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1059142_16_ITEM7_P18_S4	No net income or loss from these properties operations or sale accrued to the Unitholders or the General Partner during 2015.

1059142_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	In July 2015, due to certain restrictions imposed by the Volcker Rule, we restructured eight of the existing TOB Trust structures with DB by entering into a new Master Trust Agreement and related documents to create Term TOB Trusts.
