1059142_18_ITEM7_P0_S0	In this Management s Discussion and Analysis, all references to we, us, and the Partnership refer to America First Multifamily Investors, L.P. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries at December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P0_S1	The Company refers to the Partnership and the Consolidated VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P1_S0	We were formed for the primary purpose of acquiring a portfolio of MRBs that are issued by state and local housing authorities to provide construction and/or permanent financing for affordable multifamily and student housing, the Residential Properties, and commercial properties in their market areas.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P1_S1	The Company includes the assets, liabilities, and results of operations of the Partnership, its wholly-owned subsidiaries and two other consolidated entities for which we do not hold an ownership interest and which are treated as VIEs of which we have been determined to be the primary beneficiary, the Consolidated VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P1_S2	Bent Tree and Fairmont Oaks, the two Consolidated VIEs, are presented as discontinued operations for all periods presented.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P1_S3	All significant transactions and accounts between us and the Consolidated VIEs have been eliminated in consolidation.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P1_S4	See Note 2 to the Company s consolidated financial statements for additional details.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P2_S0	Executive Summary The Partnership was formed for the primary purpose of acquiring a portfolio of MRBs that are issued by state and local housing authorities to provide construction and/or permanent financing for affordable multifamily and student housing (collectively Residential Properties ) and commercial properties in their market areas.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P2_S1	We expect and believe the interest received on these bonds is excludable from gross income for federal income tax purposes.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P3_S0	We may also invest in other types of securities that may or may not be secured by real estate to the extent allowed by the America First Multifamily Investors, L.P. First Amended and Restated Agreement of Limited Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P3_S1	We may acquire interests in multifamily, student, and senior citizen apartment properties ( MF Properties ) to position ourselves for future investments in bonds issued to finance these properties and which we expect and believe will generate tax-exempt interest.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P3_S2	At December 31, 2017, we have four reportable segments: (1) Mortgage Revenue Bond Investments, (2) MF Properties, (3) Public Housing Capital Fund Trust, and (4) Other Investments.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P3_S3	In the first quarter of 2016, the Partnership sold its remaining three mortgage-backed securities ( MBS Securities ).
1059142_18_ITEM7_P3_S4	The sale of the Partnership s MBS Securities eliminated the MBS Securities Investment reportable segment.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P3_S5	In addition to the reportable segments, the Company also separately reports its consolidation and elimination information because it does not allocate certain items to the segments.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P3_S6	See Notes 2 and 26 to the Company s consolidated financial statements for additional details.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P3_S7	As of December 31, 2017, we owned 87 MRBs with an aggregate outstanding principal amount of $719.8 million.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P4_S0	The majority of these bonds were issued by various state and local housing authorities in order to provide construction and/or permanent financing for 63 Residential Properties containing a total of 10,666 rental units located in 14 states in the United States.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P4_S1	Each MRB for the Residential Properties is secured by a mortgage or deed of trust.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P4_S2	One MRB is secured by a mortgage on the ground, facilities, and equipment of a commercial ancillary health care facility in Tennessee.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P4_S3	As of December 31, 2016, we owned 83 mortgage revenue bonds with an aggregate outstanding principal amount of $648.4 million.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P4_S4	The majority of these bonds were issued by various state and local housing authorities in order to provide construction and/or permanent financing for 58 Residential Properties containing a total of 9,968 rental units located in 15 states in the United States.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P5_S0	Each mortgage revenue bond for the Residential Properties is secured by a mortgage or deed of trust on the Residential Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P6_S0	One MRB is secured by ground, facility, and equipment of a commercial ancillary health care facility in Tennessee.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P61_S0	Discussion of the Residential Properties Securing our Mortgage Revenue Bond Holdings and MF Properties as of December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015 The following tables outline information regarding the Residential Properties on which we hold MRBs as investments.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P61_S2	The narrative discussion that follows provides a brief operating analysis of each category for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P62_S0	Non-Consolidated Properties - Stabilized The owners of the following properties either do not meet the definition of a VIE and/or we have evaluated and determined we are not the primary beneficiary of the VIE.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P62_S1	As a result, we do not report the assets, liabilities and results of operations of these properties on a consolidated basis.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P62_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2017, these Residential Properties have met the stabilization criteria (see footnote 3 below the table).
1059142_18_ITEM7_P62_S3	Debt service on our MRBs for the non-consolidated stabilized properties was current on December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P62_S4	The amounts presented below were obtained from records provided by the property owners and their related property management service providers.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P63_S0	Physical occupancy is defined as the total number of units occupied divided by total units at the date of measurement.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P64_S0	Economic occupancy is defined as the net rental income received divided by the maximum amount of rental income to be derived from each property.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P64_S1	This statistic is reflective of rental concessions, delinquent rents and non-revenue units such as model units and employee units.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P65_S0	measurement while economic occupancy is a measurement over the period presented.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P65_S1	Therefore, economic occupancy for a period may exceed the actual occupancy at any point in time.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P66_S0	A property is considered stabilized once it reaches 90% occupancy for 90 days and an achievement of 1.15 times debt service coverage ratio on amortizing debt service.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P67_S0	We hold approximately $17.6 million of MRBs secured by the Ohio Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P67_S1	The Ohio Properties are: Crescent Village, located in Cincinnati, Ohio, Willow Bend, located in Columbus (Hilliard), Ohio and Postwoods, located in Reynoldsburg, Ohio.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P68_S0	Previous period results are not available.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P69_S0	The property relates to a forward bond purchase commitment that was executed in the fourth quarter of 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P69_S1	The property was considered stabilized when the MRB was acquired.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P70_S0	The MRB associated with the property was redeemed as of December 31, 2017, so the number of units and occupancy are not applicable as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S0	Overall physical occupancy increased from 2016 to 2017 primarily due to the stabilization of the Columbia Gardens, Willow Run, Heights at 515 and Crossing at 1415 properties during 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S1	Overall physical occupancy for the stabilized Residential Properties increased from 2015 to 2016 primarily due to the stabilization of the Concord at Gulfgate, Concord at Little York, Concord at Williamcrest, Bruton Apartments and Decatur Angle properties during 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S2	Physical occupancy also increased due to the addition of the Companion at Thornhill property during 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S3	Overall economic occupancy increased from 2016 to 2017 primarily due to the stabilization of the Columbia Gardens, Willow Run, Heights at 515 and Crossing at 1415 properties during 2017 and continued ramp up of occupancy at Bruton Apartments and Decatur Angle.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S4	Overall economic occupancy decreased slightly from 2015 to 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S5	The decrease is due primarily to the recent stabilization of Bruton Apartments and Decatur Angle during 2016, which had no comparable prior year information.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S6	Non-Consolidated Properties - Not Stabilized The owners of the following properties either do not meet the definition of a VIE or we have evaluated and determined we are not the primary beneficiary of the VIE.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S7	As a result, we do not report the assets, liabilities and results of operations of these properties on a consolidated basis.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S8	For the year ended December 31, 2017, these Residential Properties have not met the stabilization criteria (see footnote 3 below the table).
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S9	On December 31, 2017, debt service on our MRBs for the non-consolidated properties that are not stabilized was current.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P71_S10	The amounts presented below were obtained from records provided by the property owners and their related property management service providers.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P72_S0	Physical occupancy is defined as the total number of units occupied divided by total units at the date of measurement.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P73_S0	Economic occupancy is defined as the net rental income received divided by the maximum amount of rental income to be derived from each property.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P73_S1	This statistic is reflective of rental concessions, delinquent rents and non-revenue units such as model units and employee units.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P74_S0	Physical occupancy is a point in time measurement while economic occupancy is a measurement over the period presented.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P74_S1	Therefore, economic occupancy for a period may exceed the actual occupancy at any point in time.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P75_S0	(3) During 2017, these properties were under construction or renovation.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P75_S1	As such, these properties are not considered stabilized as they have not met the criteria for stabilization.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S0	Stabilization is generally defined as 90% occupancy for 90 days and an achievement of 1.15 times debt service coverage ratio on amortizing debt service.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S1	(4) Previous period occupancy numbers are not available as these were new investments in 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S2	Properties indicating n/a in 2016 did not have financial information available for 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S3	(5) Previous period occupancy numbers are not available as these were new investments in 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S4	Physical occupancy decreased from 2016 to 2017 Primarily due to the addition of the Avistar at Copperfield, Avistar at Wilcrest and Avistar at Wood Hollow during 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S5	These properties are currently undergoing major rehabilitations and will likely experience an increase in occupancy during 2018 as rehabilitations are completed.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S6	Economic occupancy increased from 2016 to 2017 due to new MRBs related to rehabilitation projects in California in 2017 and in December 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S7	These properties had higher than normal occupancy for projects of this type due to a strong local market for multifamily housing.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S8	Physical and economic occupancy increased from 2015 to 2016 primarily due to the addition of non-stabilized Residential Properties with high occupancy in 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S9	These new Residential Properties may show a decline in physical and economic occupancy in the near term as the properties go through substantial rehabilitations.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S10	Properties At December 31, 2017, we owned three MF Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S11	We report the assets, liabilities, and results of operations of these properties on a consolidated basis.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S12	For the year ended December 31, 2017, all MF Properties have met the stabilization criteria (see footnote 3 below the table).
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S13	The MF properties are encumbered by mortgage loans with an aggregate principal balance of $35.8 million at December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P76_S14	Debt service on our mortgage payables was current at December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P77_S0	The amounts presented below were obtained from records provided by property management service providers.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P78_S0	Total revenue is defined as net rental revenue plus other income from the properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P79_S0	Economic occupancy is presented for December 31, 2015 and 2014 and is defined as the net rental income received divided by the maximum amount of rental income to be derived from each property.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P79_S1	This statistic is reflective of rental concessions, delinquent rents and non-revenue units such as model units and employee units.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P79_S2	Actual occupancy is a point in time measurement while economic occupancy is a measurement over the period presented.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P79_S3	Therefore, economic occupancy for a period may exceed the actual occupancy at any point in time.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P80_S0	Stabilization is generally defined as 90% occupancy for 90 days and an achievement of 1.15 times debt service coverage ratio on amortizing debt service for all MF Properties that are not student housing residential properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P80_S1	Suites on Paseo, Eagle Village, Northern View, and The 50/50 MF Property are student housing residential properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P81_S0	The overall increase in physical occupancy from 2016 to 2017 is due to a sharp increase in occupancy at The 50/50 during 2017, which is due to marketing and pricing changes implemented by the Partnership and Properties Management for fall 2017 lease-up.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P81_S1	The overall decrease in physical occupancy from 2015 to 2016 is due to declining occupancy at the 50/50 MF Property during 2016 and the addition of Jade Park with a physical occupancy that is lower than the average of other MF Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P81_S2	The overall increase in economic occupancy is a result of higher occupancy at the Suite on Paseo in 2017 as compared to 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P81_S3	This was somewhat offset by lower economic occupancy at The 50/50 due to the poor fall 2016 lease-up.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P81_S4	The overall decrease in economic occupancy from 2015 to 2016 is due declining occupancy at The 50/50 MF Property during 2016 and the addition of Jade Park with an economic occupancy that is lower than the average of other MF Properties.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P99_S0	Discussion of the Total Expenses for the Year Ended December 31, 2017 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2016 Real estate operating expenses .
1059142_18_ITEM7_P99_S1	Real estate operating expenses associated with the MF Properties is comprised principally of real estate taxes, property insurance, utilities, property management fees, repairs and maintenance, and salaries and related employee expenses of on-site employees.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P99_S2	A portion of real estate operating expenses is fixed in nature, thus a decrease in physical and economic occupancy would result in a reduction in operating margins.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P99_S3	Conversely, as physical and economic occupancy increase, the fixed nature of these expenses will increase operating margins as these real estate operating expenses would not increase at the same rate as rental revenues.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P99_S4	The overall decrease in real estate operating expenses was due to the following factors:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P100_S0	An increase of approximately $628,000 in real estate operating expenses at The 50/50 and Suites on Paseo MF Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P100_S1	The increase at The 50/50 are related to one-time expenses incurred in 2017 and not expected to recur in future periods.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P100_S2	The increase at Suites on Paseo relates primarily to a one-time refund of real estate taxes in 2016 that did not recur in 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P101_S0	The impairment of securities for 2017 relates to the PHC Certificates.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P101_S1	There were no such impairment charges in 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P102_S0	Impairment charge on real estate assets .
1059142_18_ITEM7_P102_S1	The impairment charge in 2016 is related to land held for development in St. Petersburg, FL.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P102_S2	There were no such impairment charges in 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P103_S0	Depreciation results primarily from the MF Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P104_S0	Amortization consists of in-place lease intangible assets recorded as part of the acquisition-method of accounting.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P104_S1	The overall decrease in real estate operating expenses was due to the following factors:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P105_S0	A decrease of approximately $1.5 million in expenses related to the sales of the Northern View in March 2017, sales of the Residences of Weatherford, Residences of DeCordova and Eagle Village in November 2017, and sales of the Arboretum and Woodland Park in 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P106_S0	The overall increase in amortization of deferred financing costs in 2017 is due to $463,000 of increased amortization related to Term A/B Trust Financings.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P106_S1	The increase is due primarily to the addition of new Term A/B Trusts in September 2016 and February 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P107_S0	The net increase in interest expense between 2017 and 2016 is due to the following factors:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P108_S0	An increase of approximately $185,000 in expense related to market to market adjustments on derivative financial instruments, net of cash paid.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P109_S0	The overall increase in general and administrative expenses is due an approximately $1.3 million increase in salary, benefits and restricted unit award compensation expense, an approximately $858,000 increase in additional administrative fees on new investments in 2016 and 2017, offset by a decrease of approximately $287,000 in board and professional expenses.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P110_S0	Discussion of the Total Expenses for the Year Ended December 31, 2016 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2015 Real estate operating expenses .
1059142_18_ITEM7_P110_S1	Real estate operating expenses associated with the MF Properties is comprised principally of real estate taxes, property insurance, utilities, property management fees, repairs and maintenance, and salaries and related employee expenses of on-site employees.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P110_S2	A portion of real estate operating expenses is fixed in nature, thus a decrease in physical and economic occupancy would result in a reduction in operating margins.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P110_S3	Conversely, as physical and economic occupancy increase, the fixed nature of these expenses will increase operating margins as these real estate operating expenses would not increase at the same rate as rental revenues.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P121_S1	The Company reported income from discontinued operations of approximately $3.7 million, inclusive of gains of sale of Consolidated VIEs of approximately $3.2 million, for the year ended December 31, 2015.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P121_S4	Liquidity and Capital Resources The Partnership s principal source of cash flow includes:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P122_S0	Cash flow, net of expenses, from general Partnership operations.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P123_S0	Additional sources of cash flow may include:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P124_S0	Interest income is primarily comprised of fixed rate base interest payments received on our MRB s and PHC Certificates that provide consistent cash receipts throughout the year.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P124_S1	Certain MRB s may also generate payments of contingent interest to us from time to time when the underlying Residential Properties generate excess net cash flow from operations, excess proceeds from refinancing or from the sale of the property.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P124_S2	For additional details, see Item 8, Cash Flows from Operating and Investing Activities sections of the Partnership s consolidated statement of cash flows.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P124_S3	Similarly, the economic performance of MF Properties will affect the amount of cash distributions, if any, received by the Partnership from ownership of these properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P124_S4	The economic performance of the MF Properties depends on the rental and occupancy rates of the property and on the level of operating expenses.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P125_S0	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, apartments in the market where the property is located.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P125_S1	This, in turn, is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and the affordability of single-family homes.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P125_S2	In addition, factors such as government regulation (such as zoning laws), inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems, and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of an apartment property.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P125_S3	For discussion related to economic risk, see Item 1A, Risk Factors in the Partnership s report.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P125_S4	Other sources of cash available to the Partnership include:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P126_S0	At December 31, 2017, the Partnership had borrowed the following amounts:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P127_S0	Mortgages payable and other secured financing, net - $35.5 million.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P128_S0	In addition, at December 31, 2017, the Partnership had issued approximately 9.5 million Series A Preferred Units at a subscription price of $10.00 per unit.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P128_S1	We issued approximately 5.4 million Series A Preferred Units during the year ended December 31, 2017 for gross proceeds of approximately $53.6 million.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P128_S2	The offering of the Series A Preferred Units was terminated effective as of October 25, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P128_S3	In December 2017, the Partnership initiated an at the market offering to sell up to $75.0 million of BUCs at prevailing market prices on the date of sale.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P128_S4	The Partnership sold 161,383 BUCs under the program for net proceeds of approximately $806,000, net of issuance costs, during the year ended December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P129_S0	Our principal uses of cash are (i) general, administrative and operating expenses, (ii) interest and principal payable on the unsecured and secured lines of credit, (iii) interest and principal payable on the debt financing and mortgages payable and other secured financing, and (iv) payment of distributions to Series A Preferred Unitholders and BUC holders.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P129_S1	We also use cash to acquire additional investments.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P130_S0	The MF Properties primary uses of cash were for operating expenses.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P130_S1	We also use cash for general and administrative expenses.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P130_S2	For additional details, see Item 1A, Risk Factors and Item 8, Cash Flows from Operating Activities section of the Company s consolidated statements of cash flows.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S0	We maintain two unsecured lines of credit: an operating and a revolving line of credit.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S1	Our operating line of credit allows for the advance of up to $10.0 million to be used for general operations.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S2	We are required to make prepayments of the principal to reduce outstanding principal balance on the operating line to zero for fifteen consecutive days during each calendar quarter.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S3	We fulfilled this requirement during the quarter ended December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S4	In addition, we have fulfilled this requirement for the first quarter of 2018.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S5	Our $50.0 million revolving line of credit may be utilized for the purchase of multifamily real estate and taxable or tax-exempt MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S6	Advances on the line of credit are due on the 270 th day following the advance date but may be extended by making certain payments for up to an additional 270 days.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S7	Our $20.0 million secured term line of credit was used to finance the purchase of MRBs and matured in March 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S8	The secured line of credit was closed and is not available for use by the Partnership at December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S9	We anticipate paying off the balances on our revolving line of credit by entering into fixed-rate debt financing arrangements, to be secured with the previously acquired MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P131_S10	See Notes 15 and 16 of the Partnership s consolidated financial statements for additional details.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P132_S0	Our debt financing arrangements consist of various secured financing transactions to leverage our portfolio of MRBs and other investments.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P132_S1	The financing arrangements generally involve the securitization of MRBs and other investments into trusts whereby we retain beneficial interests in the trusts that provide certain rights to the underlying investment assets.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P132_S2	The remaining beneficial interests are sold to unaffiliated parties with the proceeds being received by the Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P132_S3	The beneficial interests held by unaffiliated parties require periodic interest payments that may be fixed or variable, depending on the terms of the arrangement, and scheduled principal payments.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P132_S4	Our mortgages payable and other secured financing arrangements are used to leverage our MF Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P132_S5	The mortgages and other secured financing are entered into with financial institutions and are secured by security interests in the MF Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P132_S6	The mortgages and other secured financing bear interest that may be fixed or variable, depending on the terms of the arrangement, and scheduled principal payments.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P132_S7	We anticipate refinancing all financing arrangements coming due in 2018 with similar arrangements of terms greater than one year.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P132_S8	See Notes 17 and 18 to the Partnership s consolidated financial statements for additional details on the maturity of the debt obligations at December 31, 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P133_S0	Distributions to the Series A Preferred Unitholders, if declared by the General Partner, are paid at a fixed rate of 3.0% annually.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P133_S1	The Series A Preferred Units are non-cumulative, non-voting and non-convertible.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P134_S0	Distributions to the BUC holders may increase or decrease at the determination of the General Partner.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P134_S1	The per Unit cash available for distribution primarily depends on the amount of interest and other cash received by us from our portfolio of MRBs and other investments, the amount of our outstanding debt and the effective interest rates paid by us on this debt, the level of operating and other cash expenses incurred by us, and the number of Units outstanding.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P135_S0	Leverage Ratio We utilize leverage to enhance rates of return to our Unitholders.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P135_S1	We use target ratios for each type of financing obligation utilized by us to manage an overall leverage constraint, as established by the Board of Managers (the Board ) of Burlington, which is the general partner of the Partnership s general partner.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P135_S2	During the third quarter of 2017, the Board approved an increase in the overall leverage constraint to 75%.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P135_S3	The amount of leverage utilized is dependent upon several factors, including the assets being leveraged, the leverage program utilized, constraints of market collateral calls and the liquidity and marketability of the underlying collateral of the asset being leveraged.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P136_S0	We define our leverage ratio as total outstanding debt divided by total assets using the carrying value of the MRBs, PHC Certificates, initial finance costs and the MF Properties at cost.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P136_S1	At December 31, 2017, our overall leverage ratio was approximately 64%.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P137_S0	In fiscal 2017, we generated $48.8 million of cash, which was the net result of $17.1 million provided by operating activities, $21.5 million used in investing activities, and $53.2 million provided by financing activities.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P138_S0	Cash provided by operating activities totaled $17.1 million in 2017, as compared to $15.2 million generated in 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P138_S1	The increase was mainly driven by a decrease in interest receivable of $2.2 million.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P139_S0	Cash used in investing activities totaled $21.5 million in 2017, as compared to $83.1 million in 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P139_S1	The change is due to an increase in principal payments and redemption proceeds received on MRBs of $45.3 million, a decrease in cash used to purchase MRBs of $9.3 million, and a decrease in property loan advances of $5.7 million.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P140_S0	Cash provided by financing activities totaled $53.2 million in 2017, as compared to $71.5 million in 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P140_S1	The change is due to a net increase in payments on lines of credit of $52.5 million.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P140_S2	This change is offset by an increase in net cash from debt financings of $18.5 million and an increase in proceeds from the issuance of Series A Preferred Units of $12.8 million.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P140_S3	We believe our cash balance and cash provided by the sources discussed herein will be sufficient to pay, or refinance, our debt obligations and to meet our liquidity needs over the next 12 months.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P141_S0	The Partnership believes that CAD provides relevant information about the Partnership s operations and is necessary, along with net income, for understanding its operating results.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P142_S0	To calculate CAD, the Partnership begins with net income and adds back non-cash expenses consisting of amortization expense related to debt financing costs and bond issuance costs, interest rate derivative expense or income, provision for loan losses, impairments on MRBs, PHC Certificates, real estate assets and property loans, and Restricted Units compensation expense, to the Partnership s net income (loss) as computed in accordance with GAAP, and deducts Tier 2 income (see Note 3 to the Partnership s consolidated financial statements) attributable to the Partnership as defined in the Amended and Restated LP Agreement.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P143_S0	Net income is the GAAP measure most comparable to CAD.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P144_S0	There is no generally accepted methodology for computing CAD, and the Partnership s computation of CAD may not be comparable to CAD reported by other companies.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P144_S1	Although the Partnership considers CAD to be a useful measure of the Partnership s operating performance, CAD is a non-GAAP measure that should not be considered as an alternative to net income that is calculated in accordance with GAAP, or any other measures of financial performance presented in accordance with GAAP.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P145_S0	Currently, cash distributions are made to the Partnership s Unitholders at an annual rate of $0.50 per Unit.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P145_S1	The amount of the cash per Unit distributed may increase or decrease at the determination of AFCA 2 based on its assessment of the amount of cash available for this purpose.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P145_S2	During the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, we generated Cash Available for Distribution of $0.60, $0.50 and $0.53 per Unit, respectively.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P145_S3	We believe that as we continue to implement our current investment plans, we will be able to continue to generate sufficient CAD to maintain cash distributions to Unitholders at the existing level of $0.50 per Unit per year without the use of other available cash.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P145_S4	However, there is no assurance that we will be able to generate CAD at levels in excess of the current annual distribution rate, which could result in a reduced annual distribution rate per Unit.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P147_S1	This adjustment represents the 25% of Tier 2 income due to the General Partner.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P148_S1	The remaining Tier 2 income allocated to the general partner was realized on the gains on sale of the Northern View, Residences of Weatherford, Residences of DeCordova and Eagle Village MF Properties, net of tax.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P148_S3	This limit was reached during the year ended December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P148_S4	All income in excess of the limit is considered Tier 3 income that is allocated entirely to the BUCs.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P149_S1	In addition, we realized gross gains of approximately $12.4 million and $1.7 million from the sales of the Arboretum and Woodland Park, respectively.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P151_S1	The development at the University of Nebraska - Lincoln is accounted for as an MF Property and the cash received for these fees has been eliminated within the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P151_S2	For purposes of CAD, we treat these fees as if received from an unconsolidated entity.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P154_S1	The Residential Properties are owned by entities that are not controlled by us.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P154_S2	We have no equity interest in these entities and do not guarantee any obligations of these entities.

1059142_18_ITEM7_P156_S0	We do not engage in trading activities involving non-exchange traded contracts.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P156_S1	As such, we are not materially exposed to any financing, liquidity, market, or credit risk that could arise if we had engaged in such relationships.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P156_S2	We do not have any relationships or transactions with persons or entities that derive benefits from their non-independent relationships with us or our related parties, other than what is disclosed in Note 24 to the Company s consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P157_S0	Contractual Obligations As discussed in Notes 15 through 18 to the Company s consolidated financial statements, the amounts maturing in 2017 consist of the principal paid on LOCs, the TEBS credit facility with Freddie Mac, the TOB, Term TOB and Term A/B credit facilities with DB, and payments on the MF Property mortgages payable and other secured financing.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P157_S1	Our strategic objective is to leverage our MRB portfolio utilizing long-term securitization financings either with Freddie Mac through its TEBS program or with Deutsche Bank through its Term A/B Trust program.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P157_S2	This strategy allows us to better match the duration of our assets and liabilities and to better manage the spread between our assets and liabilities.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P158_S0	As part of our strategy of acquiring MRBs, we will enter into bond purchase commitments related to MRBs to be issued and secured by properties under construction.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P158_S1	Upon execution of the bond purchase commitment, the proceeds from the MRBs issued will be used to pay off the construction related debt and MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P159_S0	We account for our Bond Purchase Commitments as available-for-sale securities and record the estimated fair value as an asset or liability with changes in such valuations recorded in other comprehensive income.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P159_S1	See Note 20 to the Company s consolidated financial statements for additional details.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P159_S2	We have the following contractual obligations as of December 31, 2017:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P160_S0	We are also contractually obligated to pay interest on our long-term debt obligations.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P160_S1	The weighted average interest of our lines of credit is 4.4% at December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P160_S2	The weighted average interest of our debt financing is 3.7% at December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P160_S3	The weighted average interest of our mortgages payable and other secured financings is 4.2% at December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P161_S0	Inflation Substantially all of the resident leases at the Residential Properties, which collateralize our MRBs, allow for adjustments in the rent payable at the time of renewal, subject to rent restrictions related to the MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P161_S1	Additionally, the MF Properties may be able to seek rent increases.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P161_S2	The majority of these leases are for one year or less.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P161_S3	The short-term nature of these leases generally serves to reduce the risk to the properties of the adverse effects of inflation; however, market conditions may prevent the properties from increasing rental rates in amounts sufficient to offset higher operating expenses.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P162_S0	Inflation did not have a significant impact on our financial results for the years presented in this report.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P163_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires us to make judgments, assumptions, and estimates.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P163_S1	The application of these judgments, assumptions, and estimates can affect the amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses reported by us.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P164_S0	Our significant accounting policies are described in Note 2 and 25 to the Company s consolidated financial statements, which are incorporated by reference.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P164_S1	We consider the following to be our critical accounting policies because they involve our judgments, assumptions and estimates that significantly affect the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P164_S2	If these estimates differ significantly from actual results, the impact on our consolidated financial statements may be material.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P165_S0	Variable Interest Entities Under the consolidation guidance, the Partnership must evaluate entities in which it holds a variable interest to determine if the entities are variable interest entities ( VIEs ) and if the Partnership is the primary beneficiary.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P165_S1	The entity that is deemed to have (1) the power to direct the activities of a VIE that most significantly impact the entity s economic performance and (2) the obligation to absorb losses of the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE, is considered the primary beneficiary.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P165_S2	If the Partnership is deemed to be the primary beneficiary, then it must consolidate the VIEs in the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P165_S3	The Company has consolidated all VIEs in which it has determined it is the primary beneficiary.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P165_S4	In the Company s consolidated financial statements, all transactions and accounts between the Partnership and the Consolidated VIEs have been eliminated in consolidation.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P165_S5	The Partnership re-evaluates VIEs at each reporting date based on events and circumstances at the VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P165_S6	As a result, changes to the Consolidated VIEs may occur in the future based on changes in circumstances.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P166_S0	The accounting guidance on consolidations is complex and requires significant analysis and judgment.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P166_S1	The General Partner does not believe that the consolidation of VIEs for reporting under accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) impacts the Partnership s status as a partnership for federal income tax purposes or the status of Unitholders as partners of the Partnership, the treatment of the MRBs on the properties owned by Consolidated VIEs as debt, the nature of the interest payments, which it believes to be tax-exempt, received on the MRBs secured by the properties owned by Consolidated VIEs or the manner in which the Partnership s income is reported to Unitholders on IRS Form K-1.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P167_S0	The unallocated deficit of the Consolidated VIEs consists of the accumulated historical net losses of the Consolidated VIEs since the applicable consolidation date.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P167_S1	The unallocated deficit of the Consolidated VIEs and the Consolidated VIEs net losses subsequent to that date are not allocated to the General Partner and Unitholders as such activity is not contemplated by, or addressed in, the Amended and Restated LP Agreement.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P168_S0	Fair Value of Financial Instruments Current accounting guidance on fair value measurements establishes a framework for measuring fair value and provides for expanded disclosures about fair value measurements.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P169_S0	Establishes a three-level hierarchy for fair value measurements based upon the transparency of inputs to the valuation of an asset or liability on the measurement date.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P170_S0	Inputs refer broadly to the assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability, including assumptions about risk.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P171_S0	To increase consistency and comparability in fair value measurements and related disclosures, the fair value hierarchy prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into three broad levels.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P171_S1	The three levels of the hierarchy are defined as follows:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P172_S0	Level 1 inputs are quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P173_S0	Level 2 inputs are inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly, for substantially the full term of the financial instrument.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P174_S0	Level 3 inputs are unobservable inputs for asset or liabilities.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P175_S0	The categorization within the valuation hierarchy is based upon the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P175_S1	Following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for assets and liabilities measured at fair value.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P176_S0	Investments in MRBs and Bond Purchase Commitments.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P176_S1	The fair value of the Partnership s investments in MRBs and bond purchase commitments is based upon prices obtained from a third-party pricing service, which are indicative of market prices.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P176_S2	There is no active trading market for the MRBs and price quotes for the MRBs are not available.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P177_S0	The valuation methodology of the Partnership s third-party pricing service incorporates commonly used market pricing methods.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P177_S1	It considers the underlying characteristics of each MRB as well as other quantitative and qualitative characteristics including, but not limited to, market interest rates, legal structure of the borrower, seniority to other obligations, operating results of the underlying property, geographic location, and property quality.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P177_S2	The MRB values are then estimated using a discounted cash flow and yield to maturity or call analysis.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P178_S0	The Partnership analyzes pricing data received from the third-party pricing service by comparing it to the Partnership s internal valuation methodology.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P178_S1	The Partnership s internal valuation methodology considers current market interest rates as well as quantitative and qualitative characteristics similar to those used by the third-party pricing service.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P178_S2	The fair value estimates of these MRBs, whether estimated by the third-party pricing service or the Partnership, are based largely on unobservable inputs the Partnership believes would be used by market participants and requires the use of judgment on the part of the third-party pricing service and management.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P178_S3	Due to the judgments involved, the fair value measurement of the Partnership s investments in MRBs and bond purchase commitments is categorized as a Level 3 input.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P179_S0	Investments in Public Housing Capital Fund Trust Certificates.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P180_S0	The fair value of the Partnership s investment in PHC Certificates is based upon prices obtained from a third-party pricing service, which are indicative of market prices.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P181_S0	There is no active trading market for the trusts certificates owned by the Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P182_S0	The valuation methodology of the Partnership s third-party pricing service incorporates commonly used market pricing methods.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P182_S1	It considers the underlying characteristics of each PHC Trust as well as other quantitative and qualitative characteristics including, but not limited to, market interest rates, security ratings from rating agencies, the impact of potential political and regulatory change, and other inputs.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P183_S0	The Partnership analyzes pricing data received from the third-party pricing service by comparing it to the Partnership s internal valuation methodology.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P184_S0	The Partnership s internal valuation methodology begins with the current market yield rate for a AAA rated tax-free municipal bond for a term consistent with the weighted-average life of each of the Public Housing Capital Fund trusts, adjusted largely for unobservable inputs the Partnership believes would be used by market participants.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P185_S0	The valuation methodologies used by the third-party pricing service and the Partnership encompass the use of judgment in their application.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P185_S1	Due to the judgments involved, the fair value measurement of the Partnership s investment in PHC Certificates is categorized as a Level 3 input.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P185_S2	The fair value of the Partnership s taxable MRBs is based upon prices obtained from a third-party pricing service, which are indicative of market prices.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P185_S3	There is no active trading market for the taxable MRBs and price quotes are not available.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P186_S0	The valuation methodology of the Partnership s third-party pricing service incorporates commonly used market pricing methods.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P186_S1	It considers the underlying characteristics of each taxable MRB as well as other quantitative and qualitative characteristics including, but not limited to, market interest rates, legal structure of the borrower, seniority to other obligations, operating results of the underlying property, geographic location, and property quality.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P186_S2	The taxable MRBs values are then estimated using a discounted cash flow and yield to maturity or call analysis.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P187_S0	The Partnership analyzes pricing data received from the third-party pricing service by comparing it to the Partnership s internal valuation methodology.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P187_S1	The Partnership s internal valuation methodology considers current market interest rates as well as quantitative and qualitative characteristics like those used by the third-party pricing service.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P187_S2	The fair value estimates of these taxable MRBs, whether estimated by the third-party pricing service or the Partnership, are based largely on unobservable inputs the Partnership believes would be used by market participants and requires the use of judgment on the part of the third-party pricing service and management.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P187_S3	Due to the judgments involved, the fair value measurement of the Partnership s investments in taxable MRBs are categorized as a Level 3 input.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P188_S0	The effect of the Partnership s interest rate derivatives is to set a cap, or upper limit, on the base rate of interest paid on the Partnership s variable rate debt equal to the notional amount of the derivative agreement.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P188_S1	The effect of the Partnership s interest rate swaps is to change a variable rate debt obligation to a fixed rate for that portion of the debt equal to the notional amount of the derivative agreement.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P189_S0	The fair value of the interest rate derivatives is based on a model whose inputs are not observable and therefore is categorized as a Level 3 input.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P189_S1	The inputs in the valuation model include three-month London Inter-bank Offered Rate ( LIBOR ) rates, unobservable adjustments to account for the SIFMA index, as well as any recent interest rate cap trades with similar terms.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P190_S0	Impairment The Partnership accounts for its investments in MRBs, taxable MRBs and bond purchase commitments under the guidance for accounting for certain investments in debt and equity securities.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P190_S1	The Partnership s investments in these instruments are classified as available-for-sale securities and are reported at estimated fair value.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P190_S2	The net unrealized gains or losses on these investments is reflected in other comprehensive income.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P190_S3	Unrealized gains and losses do not affect the cash flow of the bonds, distributions to Unitholders, or the characterization of the interest income of the financial obligation of the underlying collateral.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P190_S4	See Note 25 for a description of the Partnership s methodology for estimating fair value of mortgage revenue bonds, taxable MRBs and bond purchase commitments.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P191_S0	The Partnership periodically reviews each of its MRBs, taxable MRBs and bond purchase commitments for impairment.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P191_S1	The Partnership evaluates whether unrealized losses are considered other-than-temporary based on various factors including:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P192_S0	Recoveries or additional declines in fair value after the balance sheet date.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P193_S0	While the Partnership evaluates all available information, it focuses specifically on whether the security s estimated fair value is below amortized cost, if the Partnership has the intent to sell or may be required to sell the security prior to the time that the value recovers or until maturity, and whether the Partnership expects to recover the security s entire amortized cost basis.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P193_S1	The recognition of other-than-temporary impairment and the potential impairment analysis are subject to a considerable degree of judgment, the results of which when applied under different conditions or assumptions could have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P194_S0	If the Partnership experiences deterioration in the values of its investment portfolio, the Partnership may incur impairments to its investment portfolio that could negatively impact the Partnership s financial condition, cash flows, and reported earnings.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P194_S1	PHC Certificates Impairment The Partnership periodically reviews the PHC Certificates for impairment.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P194_S2	The Partnership evaluates whether a decline in the fair value of the investments is below its amortized cost is other-than temporary based on various factors including:
1059142_18_ITEM7_P195_S0	Volatility of the fair value of the security.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P196_S0	The Partnership reviews real estate assets at least quarterly and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of a property may not be recoverable.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P196_S1	When indicators of potential impairment suggest that the carrying value of the real estate assets may not be recoverable, the Partnership compares the carrying amount to the undiscounted net cash flows expected to be generated from the use of the assets.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P196_S2	If the carrying value exceeds the undiscounted net cash flows, an impairment loss is recorded to the extent that the carrying value of the property exceeds its estimated fair value.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P196_S3	See Note 9 for information on recognized impairment charges.
1059142_18_ITEM7_P196_S4	Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements For a discussion on recently issued accounting pronouncements, see Note 2 to the Company s consolidated financial statements which are incorporated by reference.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Interest rates are highly sensitive to many factors, including governmental, monetary and tax policies, domestic and international economic and political considerations, and other factors beyond our control.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The nature of our MRBs, PHC Certificates and the debt financing used to finance these investments exposes us to financial risk due to fluctuations in market interest rates.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The MRBs and PHC Certificates bear base interest at fixed rates.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P1_S1	In addition, the MRBs may also pay contingent interest that fluctuates based upon the cash flows of the underlying property and proceeds from the refinancing or sale of the property.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Our primary credit risk is the risk of default on our investment in MRBs and taxable property loans collateralized by the Residential Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The MRBs are not direct obligations of the governmental authorities that issue the MRBs and are not guaranteed by such authorities, any insurer or other party.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P3_S1	In addition, the MRBs and the associated taxable property loans are non-recourse obligations of the property owner.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P3_S2	As a result, the sole source of principal and interest payments (including both base and contingent interest) on the MRBs and the taxable property loans is the net rental revenues generated by these properties or the net proceeds from a sale or refinance of these properties.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P4_S0	If a property is unable to sustain net rental revenues at a level necessary to pay current debt service obligations on our MRB or taxable property loans, a default may occur.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S0	A property s ability to generate net rental income is subject to a wide variety of factors, including rental and occupancy rates of the property and the level of its operating expenses.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Occupancy rates and rents are directly affected by the supply of, and demand for, multifamily residential properties in the market area where the property is located.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S2	This is affected by several factors such as local or national economic conditions, the amount of new apartment construction and the affordability of single-family homes.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S3	In addition, factors such as government regulation (e.g. zoning laws), inflation, real estate and other taxes, labor problems, and natural disasters can affect the economic operations of a multifamily residential property.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S4	We also have credit risk in our investment in PHC Certificates, which are custodial receipts evidencing loans made to a number of public housing authorities.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S5	Principal and interest on these loans are payable by the respective public housing authorities solely out of annual appropriations to be made to the public housing authorities by HUD under HUD s Capital Fund Program.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S6	If Congress fails to continue making annual appropriations for the Capital Fund Program at or near current levels, or there is a delay in the approval of appropriations, the public housing authorities may not have funds to pay principal and interest on the loans underlying the PHC Certificates.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S7	Defaults on the MRBs, taxable property loans, or the public housing authorities loans backing the PHC Certificates may reduce the amount of future cash available for distribution to Unitholders.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S8	In addition, if a property s net rental income declines, it may affect the market value of the property.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S9	If the market value of a property deteriorates, the amount of net proceeds from the ultimate sale or refinancing of the property may be insufficient to repay the entire principal balance of the MRB or taxable property loan secured by the property.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S10	In the event of a default on a MRB or taxable property loan, we will have the right to foreclose on the mortgage or deed of trust securing the property.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S11	If we take ownership of the property securing a defaulted MRB, we will be entitled to all net rental revenues generated by the property.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P5_S12	If such an event occurs, these amounts will not provide tax-exempt income.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P6_S0	We actively manage the credit risks associated with our MRBs and taxable property loans by performing a complete due diligence and underwriting process of the properties securing these investments prior to investing.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P6_S1	In addition, we carefully monitor the performance of the properties underlying these investments subsequent to their purchase by the Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P7_S0	Our primary method of managing the credit risk associated with the PHC Certificates is to monitor the ratings reports issued at least annually by a rating agency for each of three PHC Certificates.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P7_S1	Mortgage Revenue Bonds and PHC Certificate Sensitivity Analysis A third-party pricing service is used to value our MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P7_S2	The pricing service uses a discounted cash flow and yield to maturity or call analyses which encompasses judgment in its application.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P8_S0	The key assumption in the yield to maturity or call analysis is the range of effective yields of the individual MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P8_S1	The effective yield analysis for each MRB considers the current market yield on similar MRBs, specific terms of the MRB, and various characteristics of underlying property serving as collateral for the MRB such as debt service coverage ratio, loan to value, and other characteristics.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P9_S0	We value the PHC Certificates based upon prices obtained from a third-party pricing service, which are indicative of market prices.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P10_S0	There is no active trading market for the PHC Certificates.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P11_S0	The valuation methodology of our third-party pricing service incorporates commonly used market pricing methods.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P11_S1	It considers the underlying characteristics of each PHC Trust as well as other quantitative and qualitative characteristics including, but not limited to, market interest rates, security ratings from rating agencies, the impact of potential political and regulatory change, and other inputs.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P12_S0	The fair value estimate by the third-party pricing service encompasses the use of judgment in its application.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P13_S0	We completed a sensitivity analysis which is hypothetical and is as of a specific point in time.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P13_S1	The results of the sensitivity analysis may not be indicative of actual changes in fair value and should be used with caution.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P13_S2	The table below summarizes the sensitivity analysis metrics related to the investments in the MRBs and PHC Certificates at December 31, 2017:
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P14_S0	The properties securing the Partnership s MRBs are geographically dispersed throughout the United States, with significant concentrations (geographic risk) in Texas, California and South Carolina.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P14_S1	At December 31, 2017, and 2016, the concentration in Texas as a percentage of principal outstanding was approximately 44% and 45%, respectively.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P14_S2	At December 31, 2017, and 2016, the concentration in California as a percentage of principal outstanding was approximately 20% and 20%, respectively.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P14_S3	At December 31, 2017, and 2016, the concentration in South Carolina as a percentage of principal outstanding was approximately 16% and 12%, respectively.

1059142_18_ITEM7A_P16_S0	The mortgages payable and other secured financings range between 3.9% and 4.7%.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P17_S0	We enter into interest rate cap agreements to mitigate our exposure to interest rate fluctuations on the variable rate financing facilities.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P17_S1	The following table sets forth certain information regarding the Partnership s interest rate cap agreements at December 31, 2017:
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P18_S0	(1) For additional details, see Note 25 to the Partnership's condensed consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P19_S0	We have contracted for two interest rate swaps with DB.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P20_S0	On a quarterly basis, the Partnership reassesses its interest rate swap positions.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P20_S1	In the second quarter of 2017, the Partnership determined that due to the stabilization of the Decatur Angle and Bruton MRB properties and securitization of the related MRBs into fixed rate Term A/B Trust financings, the interest rate swaps were not needed to mitigate interest rate risk on financings related to the MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P20_S2	The Partnership then determined that the interest rate swaps are intended to mitigate interest rate risk for the variable rate PHC TOB Trusts.

1059142_18_ITEM7A_P23_S0	The interest rate sensitivity table ( Table ) represents the change in interest income from investments net of interest on debt and interest rate derivative expenses over the next twelve months, assuming an immediate parallel shift in the LIBOR yield curve and the resulting implied forward rates are realized as a component of this shift in the curve.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P23_S1	Assumptions include anticipated interest rates, relationships between interest rate indices and outstanding investments, liabilities and interest rate derivative positions.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P23_S2	No assurance can be made that the assumptions included in the Table presented herein will occur or that other events would not occur that would affect the outcomes of the analysis.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P23_S3	Furthermore, the results included in the Table assume the Partnership does not act to change its sensitivity to the movement in interest rates.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P24_S0	As the above information incorporates only those material positions or exposures that existed as of December 31, 2017, it does not consider those exposures or positions that could arise after that date.
1059142_18_ITEM7A_P24_S1	The ultimate economic impact of these market risks will depend on the exposures that arise during the period, our risk mitigation strategies at that time and the overall business and economic environment.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P0_S0	To the Board of Managers and Partners of America First Multifamily Investors, L.P.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of America First Multifamily Investors, L.P. and its subsidiaries (the Company ) as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income, partners capital and cash flows for each of the two years in the period ended December 31, 2017, including the related notes (collectively referred to as the consolidated financial statements ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P1_S1	We also have audited the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P2_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the two years in the period ended December 31, 2017 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P2_S1	Also in our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017 based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the COSO.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P3_S0	The Company's management is responsible for these consolidated financial statements, for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in Management Report On Internal Control Over Financial Reporting appearing under Item 9A.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P3_S1	Our responsibility is to express opinions on the Company s consolidated financial statements and on the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our audits.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P3_S2	We are a public accounting firm registered with the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) ("PCAOB") and are required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws and the applicable rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PCAOB.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P4_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P4_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement, whether due to error or fraud, and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P5_S0	Our audits of the consolidated financial statements included performing procedures to assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to error or fraud, and performing procedures that respond to those risks.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P5_S1	Such procedures included examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P5_S2	Our audits also included evaluating the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P5_S3	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P5_S4	Our audits also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P5_S5	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P6_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P6_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P7_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P7_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P8_S0	We have served as the Company s auditor since 2016.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P10_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P10_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P10_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P10_S4	As discussed in Notes 6, 7, and 25, the consolidated financial statements include total investments valued at approximately $655,000,000 (75% of total assets) and $521,000,000 (70% of total assets) as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively, whose fair values have been estimated by management in the absence of readily determinable fair values.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P10_S5	At December 31, 2015, management s estimates were based on discounted cash flows or yield to maturity analyses performed by management.
