1059142_18_ITEM8_P16_S0	Basis of Presentation America First Multifamily Investors, L.P. (the Company or Partnership ) was formed on April 2, 1998, under the Delaware Revised Uniform Limited Partnership Act for the purpose of acquiring, holding, selling and otherwise dealing with a portfolio of mortgage revenue bonds ( MRBs ) that have been issued to provide construction and/or permanent financing for affordable multifamily and student housing residential properties (collectively Residential Properties ) and commercial properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P16_S1	The Partnership expects and believes the interest earned on these mortgage revenue bonds is excludable from gross income for federal income tax purposes.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P16_S2	Thus, most of the income earned by the Partnership is exempt from federal income taxes.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P16_S3	The Partnership may also invest in other types of securities that may or may not be secured by real estate and may make property loans secured by multifamily residential properties which may or may not be financed by mortgage revenue bonds held by the Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P16_S4	The Partnership may acquire real estate securing its mortgage revenue bonds or property loans through foreclosure in the event of a default or through the receipt of a fee simple deed in lieu of foreclosure.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P16_S5	In addition, the Partnership may acquire interests in multifamily, student, and senior citizen residential properties ( MF Properties ) in order to position itself for future investments in mortgage revenue bonds issued to finance these properties or to operate the MF Property until its highest and best use can be determined by management.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P17_S0	The general partner is America First Capital Associates Limited Partnership Two ( AFCA 2 or General Partner ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P17_S1	The general partner of AFCA 2 is Burlington Capital LLC ( Burlington ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P17_S2	The Partnership has issued Beneficial Unit Certificates ( BUCs ) representing assigned limited partner interests to investors ( Unitholders ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P17_S3	During 2017 and 2016, the Partnership issued non-cumulative, non-voting, non-convertible Series A Preferred Units ( Series A Preferred Units ) in private placements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P17_S4	The Series A Preferred Units are redeemable in the future and represent limited partnership interests in the Partnership pursuant to a subscription agreement with five financial institutions (Note 21).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P18_S0	All disclosures of the number of units for properties related to mortgage revenue bonds, taxable MRBs and MF Properties are unaudited.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P19_S0	Summary of Significant Accounting Policies Consolidation The Partnership, as used herein, includes the Partnership and its consolidated subsidiaries.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P19_S1	At December 31, 2017, the consolidated subsidiaries of the Partnership ( Consolidated Subsidiaries ) consist of:
1059142_18_ITEM8_P20_S0	ATAX TEBS I, LLC, a special purpose entity owned and controlled by the Partnership, created to hold MRBs to facilitate the TEBS Financing ( M24 TEBS Financing ) with Freddie Mac.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P21_S0	ATAX TEBS II, LLC, a special purpose entity owned and controlled by the Partnership, created to hold MRBs to facilitate the second TEBS financing ( M31 TEBS Financing ) with Freddie Mac.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P22_S0	ATAX TEBS III, LLC, a special purpose entity owned and controlled by the Partnership created to hold MRBs to facilitate the third TEBS Financing ( M33 TEBS Financing ) with Freddie Mac.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P23_S0	ATAX Vantage Holdings, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Partnership, committed to loan money or provide equity for the development of multifamily properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P24_S0	One MF Property is owned by a wholly-owned corporation ( the Greens Hold Co ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P24_S1	Property until its sale in March 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P24_S2	The Greens Hold Co held 100% ownership interest in the Eagle Village, Residences of DeCordova and Residences of Weatherford MF Properties until their sale in November 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P25_S0	Two MF Properties are owned directly by the Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P26_S0	Prior to January 1, 2016, the Partnership has consolidated two variable interest entities ( VIE ), Bent Tree and Fairmont Oaks properties (the Consolidated VIEs ), in the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P26_S1	The Partnership did not hold an ownership interest in the Consolidated VIEs but did own the MRBs that financed the Consolidated VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P27_S0	The Consolidated VIEs are presented as discontinued operations for all periods presented and all significant transactions and accounts between the Partnership and the VIEs have been eliminated in consolidation.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P28_S0	The Company s consolidated financial statements reported in this Form 10-K include the financial position and results of operations of the Partnership and the Consolidated VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P28_S1	The Consolidated VIEs were sold in the fourth quarter of 2015.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P29_S0	Variable Interest Entities Under the consolidation guidance, the Partnership must evaluate entities in which it holds a variable interest to determine if the entities are variable interest entities ( VIEs ) and if the Partnership is the primary beneficiary.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P29_S1	The entity that is deemed to have (1) the power to direct the activities of a VIE that most significantly impact the entity s economic performance and (2) the obligation to absorb losses of the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the entity that could potentially be significant to the VIE, is considered the primary beneficiary.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P29_S2	If the Partnership is deemed to be the primary beneficiary, then it must consolidate the VIEs in the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P29_S3	The Company has consolidated all VIEs in which it has determined it is the primary beneficiary.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P29_S4	In the Company s consolidated financial statements, all transactions and accounts between the Partnership and the Consolidated VIEs have been eliminated in consolidation.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P29_S5	The Partnership re-evaluates VIEs at each reporting date based on events and circumstances at the VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P29_S6	As a result, changes to the Consolidated VIEs may occur in the future based on changes in circumstances.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P30_S0	The accounting guidance on consolidations is complex and requires significant analysis and judgment.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P30_S1	The General Partner does not believe that the consolidation of VIEs for reporting under accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) impacts the Partnership s status as a partnership for federal income tax purposes or the status of Unitholders as partners of the Partnership, the treatment of the MRBs on the properties owned by Consolidated VIEs as debt, the nature of the interest payments, which it believes to be tax-exempt, received on the MRBs secured by the properties owned by Consolidated VIEs or the manner in which the Partnership s income is reported to Unitholders on IRS Form K-1.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P31_S0	The unallocated deficit of the Consolidated VIEs consists of the accumulated historical net losses of the Consolidated VIEs since the applicable consolidation date.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P31_S1	The unallocated deficit of the Consolidated VIEs and the Consolidated VIEs net losses subsequent to that date are not allocated to the General Partner and Unitholders as such activity is not contemplated by, or addressed in, the First Amended and Restated Agreement of Limited Partnership dated September 15, 2015, as amended (the Amended and Restated LP Agreement ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P31_S2	The Partnership sold its variable interests in Bent Tree and Fairmont Oaks (the Consolidated VIEs) in the fourth quarter of 2015.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P31_S3	The sale of the Consolidated VIEs met the criteria for discontinued operations presentation and have been classified as such in the Company s consolidated financial statements for all periods presented.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P31_S4	The gains and results of operations of the Consolidated VIEs are reported as part of the discontinued operations in net income for the year ended December 31, 2015 (see Notes 14).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P32_S0	Acquisition Accounting Pursuant to the guidance on acquisition accounting, the Partnership allocates the contractual purchase price of a property acquired to the land, building, improvements and leases in existence as of the date of acquisition based on their relative fair values.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P32_S1	The building is valued as if vacant.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P33_S0	The estimated valuation of in-place leases is calculated by applying a risk-adjusted discount rate to the projected cash flow deficit at each property during an assumed lease-up period for these properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P33_S1	This allocated cost is amortized over the average remaining term of the leases and is included in the statement of operations under depreciation and amortization expense.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P34_S0	The acquisition related costs to acquire a property are expensed as incurred.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P35_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents Cash and cash equivalents include highly liquid securities and investments in federally tax-exempt securities with maturities of three months or less when purchased.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P35_S1	Concentration of Credit Risk The Partnership maintains the majority of its unrestricted cash balances at three financial institutions.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P35_S2	The balances insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation are equal to $250,000 at each institution.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P35_S3	At various times the cash balances exceeded the $250,000 limit.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P35_S4	The Partnership is also exposed to risk on its short-term investments in the event of non-performance by counterparties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P35_S5	The Partnership does not anticipate any non-performance.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P35_S6	This risk is minimized significantly by the Partnership s portfolio being restricted to investment grade securities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P36_S0	Restricted Cash Restricted cash is legally restricted to use and is comprised of resident security deposits, required maintenance reserves, escrowed funds, and property rehabilitation.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P36_S1	In addition, the Partnership is required to maintain restricted cash balances related to the TEBS Financing facilities and the Partnership s interest rate derivatives.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P36_S2	The Partnership accounts for its investments in MRBs, taxable MRBs and bond purchase commitments under the guidance for accounting for certain investments in debt and equity securities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P36_S3	The Partnership s investments in these instruments are classified as available-for-sale securities and are reported at estimated fair value.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P36_S4	The net unrealized gains or losses on these investments is reflected in other comprehensive income.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P36_S5	Unrealized gains and losses do not affect the cash flow of the bonds, distributions to Unitholders, or the characterization of the interest income of the financial obligation of the underlying collateral.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P36_S6	See Note 25 for a description of the Partnership s methodology for estimating fair value of mortgage revenue bonds, taxable MRBs and bond purchase commitments.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P37_S0	The Partnership periodically reviews each of its MRBs, taxable MRBs and bond purchase commitments for impairment.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P37_S1	The Partnership evaluates whether unrealized losses are considered other-than-temporary based on various factors including:
1059142_18_ITEM8_P38_S0	Recoveries or additional declines in fair value after the balance sheet date.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P39_S0	While the Partnership evaluates all available information, it focuses specifically on whether the security s estimated fair value is below amortized cost, if the Partnership has the intent to sell or may be required to sell the security prior to the time that the value recovers or until maturity, and whether the Partnership expects to recover the security s entire amortized cost basis.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P39_S1	The recognition of other-than-temporary impairment and the potential impairment analysis are subject to a considerable degree of judgment, the results of which when applied under different conditions or assumptions could have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P40_S0	If the Partnership experiences deterioration in the values of its investment portfolio, the Partnership may incur impairments to its investment portfolio that could negatively impact the Partnership s financial condition, cash flows, and reported earnings.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P40_S1	There were no impairment charges reported by the Partnership related to MRBs, taxable MRBs or bond purchase commitments during the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P41_S0	The Partnership owns some MRBs which were purchased at a discount or premium.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P41_S1	The discount or premium on an investment is amortized on an effective yield method over the term of the related MRB and is recognized as investment income in the current period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P41_S2	The Partnership eliminates the MRBs and the associated interest income and interest receivable when it consolidates the underlying real estate collateral in accordance with implementation of the consolidation guidance for VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P42_S0	Investment in PHC Certificates and MBS Securities The Partnership accounts for its investments in PHC Certificates under the guidance for accounting for certain investments in debt and equity securities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P42_S1	The Partnership s investments in these instruments are classified as available-for-sale securities and are reported at estimated fair value.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P42_S2	The net unrealized gains or losses on these investments is reflected in other comprehensive income.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P42_S3	Unrealized gains and losses do not affect the cash flow of the underlying contractual payments, distributions to Unitholders, or the characterization of the interest income of the financial obligation of the underlying collateral.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P42_S4	See Note 25 for a description of the Partnership s methodology for estimating fair value for the PHC Certificates and MBS Securities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P42_S5	The Partnership sold its remaining MBS Securities in the first quarter of 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P43_S0	The Partnership periodically reviews the PHC Certificates and MBS Securities for impairment.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P43_S1	The Partnership evaluates whether a decline in the fair value of the investments is below its amortized cost is other-than temporary.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P44_S0	Volatility of the fair value of the security.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P45_S0	See Note 7 for information on recognized impairment of the PHC Certificates.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P46_S0	The PHC Certificate Trust I was purchased at a premium and PHC Certificate Trusts II and III were purchased at a discount.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P46_S1	The discount or premium on an investment is amortized on an effective yield method over the term of the related PHC Certificate and is recognized as investment income in the current period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P47_S0	Real Estate Assets The Partnership s investments in real estate are carried at cost less accumulated depreciation.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P47_S1	Depreciation of real estate is based on the estimated useful life of the related asset, generally 19-40 years on multifamily, student housing, and senior citizen residential apartment buildings and five to 15 years on capital improvements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P47_S2	Depreciation expenses is calculated using the straight-line method.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P47_S3	Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred, while improvements, renovations, and replacements are capitalized.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P47_S4	The Partnership also holds land held for investment and development which is reported at cost.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P48_S0	The Partnership recognizes gains and losses equal to the difference between proceeds on sale and the net carrying value of the assets at the date of disposition.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P48_S1	The Partnership reviews real estate assets at least quarterly and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of a property may not be recoverable.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P48_S2	When indicators of potential impairment suggest that the carrying value of the real estate assets may not be recoverable, the Partnership compares the carrying amount to the undiscounted net cash flows expected to be generated from the use of the assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P48_S3	If the carrying value exceeds the undiscounted net cash flows, an impairment loss is recorded to the extent that the carrying value of the property exceeds its estimated fair value.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P48_S4	See Note 9 for information on recognized impairment charges.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P49_S0	Investment in Unconsolidated Entities The Partnership makes initial investments in and is committed to invest, through ATAX Vantage Holdings, LLC, in certain limited liability companies ( Vantage Properties ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P49_S1	ATAX Vantage Holdings, LLC holds a limited membership interest in the Vantage Properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P49_S2	The investments will be used to construct multifamily properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P49_S3	The Partnership does not have a controlling interest in the Vantage Properties and accounts for its limited partnership interest under the equity method of accounting.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P49_S4	The Partnership earns a return on its investment that is guaranteed by an unrelated third party.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P49_S5	The term of third-party guarantee is from initial investment date through the second anniversary of construction completion.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P50_S0	Due to the third-party guarantee provided, cash flows are expected to be sufficient to pay the Partnership its earned return.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P50_S1	As a result, the Partnership records the return on the investment earned as investment income in the Partnership s consolidated statements of operations (Note 10).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P51_S0	The Partnership reviews its investments in unconsolidated affiliates for impairment whenever events or changes in business circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the investments may not be fully recoverable.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P51_S1	Evidence of a loss in value that is other than temporary includes, but is not limited to, the absence of an ability to recover the carrying amount of the investment, the inability of the investee to sustain an earnings capacity that justifies the carrying amount of the investment, or, where applicable, estimated sales proceeds that are insufficient to recover the carrying amount of the investment.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P51_S2	The Partnership s assessment as to whether any decline in value is other than temporary is based on its ability and intent to hold the investment and whether evidence indicating the carrying value of the investment is recoverable within a reasonable period of time outweighs evidence to the contrary.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P51_S3	If the fair value of the investment is determined to be less than the carrying value and the decline in value is considered other than temporary, an impairment charge is recorded equal to the excess of the carrying value over the estimated fair value of the investment.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P52_S0	The Partnership invests in taxable property loans made to the owners of certain multifamily properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P52_S1	Most of the property loans are with multifamily properties that secure MRBs owned by the Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P52_S2	The Partnership recognizes interest income on the property loans as earned and is reported within other interest income on the consolidated statements of operations.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P52_S3	Interest income is not recognized for property loans that are deemed to be in nonaccrual status.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P53_S0	largely on the value of the property or its cash flows that collateralize the loans.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P53_S1	The Partnership periodically evaluates these loans for potential losses by estimating the fair value of the property that collateralizes the loans and comparing the fair value to the outstanding MRBs or senior financing plus the Partnership s property loans.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P54_S0	The Partnership utilizes a discounted cash flow model ( DCF ) that considers varying assumptions.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P54_S1	The DCF analysis may assume multiple revenue and expense scenarios, various capitalization rates, and multiple discount rates.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P54_S2	The Partnership may also consider other information such as independent appraisals in estimating a property s fair value.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P54_S3	If the estimated fair value of the property, after deducting the amortized cost basis of the MRB or senior financing, exceeds the principal balance of the taxable property loan then no potential loss is indicated and no allowance for loan loss is recorded.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P54_S4	If a potential loss is indicated, an allowance for loan loss is recorded against the outstanding loan amount and a loss is realized.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P55_S0	The determination of the need for an allowance for loan loss is subject to considerable judgment.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P55_S1	See Note 11 for additional information on the Partnership s loan loss allowances.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P56_S0	Assets Held for Sale The Partnership reports assets and related liabilities as held for sale on the consolidated balance sheet in the period that the Partnership has committed to a plan to dispose of an asset or asset group, the asset or asset group is being marketed for sale, and it is probable the sale will be completed within one year.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P56_S1	Once an asset or asset group is determined to be held for sale, the Partnership discontinues depreciation of the asset or asset group.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P56_S2	The Partnership has evaluated the accounting guidance related its TOB, Term TOB, Term A/B and TEBS Financings and has determined that the securitization transactions do not meet the accounting criteria for a sale or transfer of financial assets and will, therefore, be accounted for as secured financing transactions.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P56_S3	More specifically, the guidance on transfers and servicing sets forth the conditions that must be met to de-recognize a transferred financial asset.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P56_S4	This guidance provides, in part, that the transferor has surrendered control over transferred assets if and only if the transferor does not maintain effective control over the transferred assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P57_S0	The financing agreements contain certain provisions that allow the Partnership to unilaterally cause the holder to return the securitized assets, other than through a cleanup call.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P57_S1	Based on these terms, the Partnership has concluded that it has not transferred effective control over the transferred assets and, as such, the transactions do not meet the conditions to de-recognize the transferred assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P57_S2	In addition, the Partnership has evaluated the securitization trusts associated with the TOB, Term TOB, Term A/B and TEBS Financings in accordance with guidance on consolidation of VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P57_S3	See Note 5 for the consolidation analysis related to these secured financing arrangements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P57_S4	The Partnership is deemed to be the primary beneficiary of these securitization trusts and consolidates the assets, liabilities, income and expenses of the securitization trusts in the Partnership s consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P58_S0	Deferred Financing Costs Debt financing costs are capitalized and amortized utilizing the effective interest method through either the stated maturity or the optional redemption of the related debt financing agreement.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P58_S1	Debt financing costs associated with revolving line of credit arrangements are reported within other assets on the consolidated balance sheets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P58_S2	Debt financing costs for other debt financings are reported as reductions to the carrying value of the related debt financings on the consolidated balance sheets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P59_S0	Bond issuance costs are capitalized and amortized utilizing the effective interest method over the stated maturity of the related MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P59_S1	Bond issuance costs are reported as an adjustment to the carrying cost of the related MRB on the consolidated balance sheets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P60_S0	Income Taxes No provision has been made for income taxes of the Partnership because the Unitholders are required to report their share of the Partnership s taxable income for federal and state income tax purposes, except for certain entities described below.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P61_S0	The Partnership recognizes franchise margin tax expense on revenues in certain jurisdictions relating to MF Properties and Investments in unconsolidated entities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P61_S1	Certain of the Consolidated VIEs and The Greens Hold Co are corporations subject to federal and state income taxes.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P61_S2	The Partnership will recognize income tax expense or benefit for the federal and state income taxes incurred by these entities on the Partnership s consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P62_S0	The Partnership evaluates its tax positions taken in the Partnership s consolidated financial statements under the interpretation for accounting for uncertainty in income taxes.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P62_S1	As such, the Partnership may recognize a tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if the Partnership believes it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by taxing authorities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P62_S2	The Partnership accrues interest and penalties as incurred within income tax expense.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P62_S3	and the utilization of tax net operating losses ( NOL ) generated in prior years that had been previously recognized as deferred income tax assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P62_S4	The Partnership fully utilized its NOL carryforwards during 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P62_S5	The Partnership values its deferred tax assets and liabilities by using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to reverse, and reflects changes to enacted rates contained in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 that was signed into law in December 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P62_S6	The Partnership records a valuation allowance for deferred income tax assets if it believes all, or some portion, of the deferred income tax asset may not be realized.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P62_S7	Any increase or decrease in the valuation allowance that results from a change in circumstances that causes a change in the estimated ability to realize the related deferred income tax asset is included in deferred income tax expense.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P63_S0	The interest income received by the Partnership from its MRBs is dependent upon the net cash flow of the underlying properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P63_S1	Base interest income on fully performing MRBs is recognized as it is earned.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P63_S2	Base interest income on MRBs not fully performing is recognized as it is received.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P63_S3	Past due base interest on MRBs previously not fully performing is recognized as it is received.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P63_S4	The Partnership reinstates the accrual of base interest once the MRBs ability to perform is adequately demonstrated.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P64_S0	Base interest income related to tax-exempt and taxable MRBs are disclosed within investment income and other interest income, respectively, on the consolidated statements of operations.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P65_S0	Certain MRBs contain contingent interest provisions that generate excess available cash flow.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P66_S0	Contingent interest income is recognized when realized or realizable.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P66_S1	Past due contingent interest on MRBs, which are or were previously not fully performing, is recognized when realized or realizable.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P66_S2	At December 31, 2017 and 2016, the Partnership s MRBs were fully performing as to their base interest.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P67_S0	Revenue Recognition on Investments in Real Estate, MBS, and PHC Certificates The Partnership s Consolidated VIEs and the MF Properties are lessors of multifamily, student housing, and senior citizen rental units under leases with terms of one year or less.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P67_S1	Rental revenue is recognized, net of rental concessions, on a straight-line method over the related lease term.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P67_S2	Interest income on the MBS and PHC Certificates is recognized as it is earned.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P68_S0	The Partnership reports all derivative instrument assets or liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets at fair value.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P68_S1	The Partnership s derivative instruments are not designated as hedging instruments and changes in fair value are recognized in the consolidated statements of operations as interest expense.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P68_S2	The Partnership is exposed to loss should a counterparty to its derivative instruments default.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P68_S3	The Partnership does not anticipate non-performance by any counterparty.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P69_S0	Redeemable Series A Preferred Units The Partnership has issued Series A Preferred Units, which represent limited partnership interests in the Partnership, to various financial institutions.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P69_S1	The Series A Preferred Units are recorded as mezzanine equity due to the holders redemption option which, if and when the units become subject to redemption, is outside the Partnership s control.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P69_S2	In addition, the costs of issuing the Series A Preferred Units are netted against the carrying value and amortized to the first redemption date (Note 21).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P70_S0	The Partnership has issued BUCs representing assigned limited partnership interests to investors.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P70_S1	Costs related to the issuance of BUCs are recorded as a reduction to partners capital when issued.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P71_S0	The Partnership s 2015 Equity Incentive Plan (the Plan ), as approved by the Unitholders in September 2015, permits the grant of Restricted Unit Awards ( RUA or RUAs ) and other awards to the employees of Burlington, the Partnership, or any affiliate of either, and members of Burlington s Board of Managers for up to 3.0 million BUCs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P71_S1	RUAs are generally granted with vesting conditions ranging from three months to up to three years.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P71_S2	RUAs currently provide for the payment of distributions during the restriction period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P71_S3	The RUAs provide for accelerated vesting if there is a change in control or upon death or disability of the Participant.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P72_S0	The Partnership accounts for forfeitures when they occur.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P72_S1	The fair value of each RUA is estimated on the grant date based on the Partnership s exchange-listed closing price of the BUCs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P72_S2	The Partnership recognizes compensation expense for the RUAs on a straight-line basis over the requisite vesting period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P72_S3	The Partnership accounts for modifications to RUAs as they occur if the fair value of the RUAs change, there are changes to vesting conditions or the awards no longer qualify for equity classification.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P73_S0	Net Income per BUC The Partnership uses the two-class method to allocate net income available to BUCs and the unvested Restricted Units as the Restricted Units are participating securities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P73_S1	Unvested Restricted Units are included with BUCs for the calculation of diluted net income per BUC using the treasury stock method, if the treasury stock method is more dilutive than the two-class method.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P74_S0	The preparation of the accompanying consolidated financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires the Partnership to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P74_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P74_S2	The most significant estimates and assumptions include those used in determining investment valuations, investment impairments, impairment of real estate assets, allocation of the purchase price for acquisition accounting and allowances for loan losses.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P74_S3	Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements In March 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-08.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P74_S4	The ASU requires that premiums on purchased callable debt securities be amortized as a yield adjustment to the earliest call date.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P74_S5	Previously, premiums were required to be amortized as a yield adjustment to maturity.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P74_S6	The guidance is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within that reporting period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P74_S7	The standard will be applied using a modified retrospective approach through a cumulative-effect adjustment to retained earnings as of the beginning of the year of adoption.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P74_S8	The Partnership has determined adoption of the standard will not have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P75_S0	In January 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-01, Business Combinations; Clarifying the Definition of a Business.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P75_S1	The ASU modifies the requirements to meet the definition of a business under Topic 805, Business Combinations.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P75_S2	The amendments provide a screen to determine when a set of identifiable assets and liabilities is not a business.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P75_S3	The screen requires that when substantially all the fair value of the gross assets acquired (or disposed of) is concentrated in a single identifiable asset or group of similar identifiable assets, the set is not a business.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P75_S4	The impact is expected to result in fewer transactions being accounted for as business combinations.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P75_S5	The ASU is effective for the Partnership for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017 and is applied prospectively.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P75_S6	It is expected that the new standard would reduce the number of future real estate acquisitions that will be accounted for as business combinations and, therefore, reduce the amount of acquisition costs that will be expensed.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P76_S0	In November 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-18, Statement of Cash Flows; Restricted Cash.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P76_S1	The ASU requires that a statement of cash flows explain the change during the period in the total of cash, cash equivalents, and amounts generally described as restricted cash or restricted cash equivalents.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P76_S2	Therefore, amounts generally described as restricted cash and restricted cash equivalents should be included with cash and cash equivalents when reconciling the beginning-of-period and end-of-period total amounts shown on the statement of cash flows.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P77_S0	The ASU also requires certain disclosure regarding the nature of restrictions on cash balances.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P78_S0	The ASU is effective for the Partnership s annual and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2017 and is applied retrospectively.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P78_S1	The Partnership has determined adoption of the standard will not have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P79_S0	In August 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-15, Statement of Cash Flows (Topic 230).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P79_S1	The ASU clarifies the presentation of cash receipts and cash payments related to certain transactions.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P79_S2	The ASU is effective for the Partnership for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017 and is applied retrospectively.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P79_S3	The Partnership has determined adoption of the standard will not have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P80_S0	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-13, Financial Instruments Credit Losses (Topic 326).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P80_S1	The ASU enhances the methodology of measuring expected credit losses to include the use of forward-looking information to better inform credit loss estimates.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P80_S2	The ASU is effective for the Partnership s annual and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2019 and is applied under a modified-retrospective approach.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P80_S3	The Partnership is currently assessing the impact of the adoption of this pronouncement on the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P81_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P81_S1	The ASU requires the recognition of right-of-use assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet and disclosure of key information about leasing arrangements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P81_S2	The ASU offers specific accounting guidance for embedded lease arrangements, lease terms and incentives, sale-leaseback agreements, and related disclosures.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P81_S3	The ASU is effective for the Partnership s annual and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2018 and requires a modified retrospective adoption, with early adoption permitted.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P82_S0	The Partnership has performed a preliminary assessment of its lessor and lessee leasing arrangements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P82_S1	Lessor arrangements with tenants at the MF Properties are not expected to be materially impacted by adoption of the standard as substantially all leases are for terms of 12 months or less.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P83_S0	The Partnership has four lessee arrangements for which it is assessing the quantitative and qualitative impact of the standard.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P83_S1	The Partnership has not elected early adoption of the standard and is currently evaluating the impact this standard will have on its consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P84_S0	In January 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-01, Financial Instruments Overall (Subtopic 825-10).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P84_S1	The ASU simplifies and clarifies the recognition, measurement, presentation, and disclosure of financial instruments.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P84_S2	The ASU is effective for the Partnership s annual and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P84_S3	The Partnership has determined adoption of the standard will not have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P85_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P85_S1	The updated standard is a new comprehensive revenue recognition model that requires revenue to be recognized in a manner that depicts the transfer of goods or services to a customer at an amount that reflects the consideration expected to be received in exchange for those goods or services.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P86_S0	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-14 which deferred the effective date of ASU 2014-09 by one year.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P86_S1	During 2016, the FASB issued ASU Nos. 2016-10, 2016-12 and 2016-20 that provide additional guidance related to the identification of performance obligations within a contract, assessing collectability, contract costs, and other technical corrections and improvements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P86_S2	The Partnership expects to use the modified retrospective transition method and will adopt the standard effective January 1, 2018.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P86_S3	The Partnership has completed an assessment of its revenue streams and performance obligations and is currently evaluating the quantitative and qualitative impacts of the new standard on the business.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P86_S4	The Partnership has determined that revenues within investment income, contingent interest income, other interest income are not within the scope of this standard.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P86_S5	Furthermore, the majority of property revenues are within the scope of the Lease ASU and outside the scope of the Revenue ASU.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P86_S6	The Partnership believes the new standard will only impact property revenues related to non-lease revenue streams, other income, and certain provisions that apply to gains on sale of real estate assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P86_S7	The impact to non-lease revenue streams within the scope of this standard is immaterial to the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P87_S0	In February 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-05.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P87_S1	The ASU eliminates guidance specific to real estate sales in Accounting Standards Codification 360-20.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P87_S2	As such, sales and partial sales of real estate assets will now be subject to the same derecognition model as all other nonfinancial assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P87_S3	The guidance is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P87_S4	The effective date of this guidance coincides with revenue recognition guidance.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P87_S5	The Partnership has determined adoption of the standard will not have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P88_S0	The Amended and Restated LP Agreement of the Partnership contains provisions for the distribution of Net Interest Income, Net Residual Proceeds and Liquidation Proceeds, for the allocation of income or loss from operations and for the allocation of income and loss arising from a repayment, sale, or liquidation of investments.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P88_S1	Income and losses will be allocated to each Unitholder on a periodic basis, as determined by the General Partner, based on the number of BUCs held by each Unitholder as of the last day of the period for which such allocation is to be made.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P88_S2	Distributions of Net Interest Income and Net Residual Proceeds will be made to each Unitholder of record on the last day of each distribution period based on the number of BUCs held by each Unitholder on that date.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P88_S3	For purposes of the Amended and Restated LP Agreement, cash distributions, if any, received by the Partnership from its investment in MF Properties (Note 9) will be included in the Partnership s Net Interest Income and cash distributions received by the Partnership from the sale of such properties will be included in the Partnership s Net Residual Proceeds.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P89_S0	Series A Preferred Units were created pursuant to the First Amendment to the Amended and Restated LP Agreement (the First Amendment ), which became effective on March 30, 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P89_S1	The holders of the Series A Preferred Units are entitled to distributions at a fixed rate prior to payment of distributions to other Unitholders.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P89_S2	Cash distributions are currently made on a quarterly basis.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P89_S3	AFCA 2 can elect to make distributions on a monthly or semi-annual basis.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P89_S4	On each distribution date, Net Interest Income (Tier 1) is distributed 99% to the limited partners and Unitholders as a class and 1% to AFCA 2.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P89_S5	Net Interest Income (Tier 2) and Net Residual Proceeds (Tier 2) representing contingent interest up to 0.9% per annum of the principal amount of the MRBs on a cumulative basis are distributed 75% to the limited partners and Unitholders as a class and 25% to AFCA 2.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P89_S6	Net Interest Income (Tier 3) and Net Residual Proceeds (Tier 3) received by the Partnership in excess of any contingent interest included in Net Interest Income (Tier 2) and Net Residual Proceeds (Tier 2) are distributed 100% to the limited partners and Unitholders as a class.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P90_S0	The distributions paid or accrued per BUC during the fiscal years ended December 31, 2017, 2016, and 2015 were as follows:
1059142_18_ITEM8_P91_S0	The Partnership has disclosed basic and diluted net income per BUC on the consolidated statements of operations.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P91_S1	The unvested RUAs issued under the Plan are considered participating securities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P91_S2	There were no dilutive Units for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P92_S0	Variable Interest Entities Consolidated VIEs The capital structure of Bent Tree and Fairmont Oaks (the Consolidated VIEs ) consisted of senior debt, subordinated debt, and equity capital.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P92_S1	The senior debt was in the form of a MRB and accounts for the majority of the total capital of each VIE.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P92_S2	As the bondholder, the Partnership was entitled to principal and interest payments and has certain protective rights as established by the MRB documents.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P93_S0	The equity ownership in these entities is ultimately held by corporations which are owned by three individuals, one of which is a related party to the Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P93_S1	Additionally, each of these properties was managed by an affiliate of the Partnership, Properties Management, which is an affiliate of Burlington.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P93_S2	The Partnership determined it was the primary beneficiary of the Consolidated VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P93_S3	The Consolidated VIEs were sold in the fourth quarter of 2015 with the gains and results of operations of the Consolidated VIEs reported as part of the discontinued operations in net income for all periods presented.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P93_S4	No net income or loss from these properties operations or sale accrued to the Unitholders or the General Partner during 2017, 2016 and 2015.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P93_S5	The Partnership determined the TOB Trusts, Term A/B Trusts and TEBS Financings are VIEs and the Partnership is the primary beneficiary.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P93_S6	In determining the primary beneficiary of these specific VIEs, the Partnership considered which party has the power to control the activities of the VIEs which most significantly impact their financial performance, the risks that the entity was designed to create, and how each risk affects the VIE.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P94_S0	The executed agreements related to the TOB Trusts, Term A/B Trusts and TEBS Financings stipulate the Partnership has the sole right to cause the Trusts to sell the underlying assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P94_S1	If they were sold, the extent to which the VIEs will be exposed to gains or losses would result from decisions made by the Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P95_S0	As the primary beneficiary, the Partnership reports the TOB Trusts, Term A/B Trusts and TEBS Financings on a consolidated basis.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P95_S1	The Partnership reports the senior floating-rate participation interests ( SPEARS ) related to the TOB Trusts and the Class A Certificates for both the Term A/B Trusts and TEBS Financings as secured debt financings on the consolidated balance sheets (Note 17).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P95_S2	The MRBs secured by the TOB Trusts, Term A/B Trusts and TEBS Financings are reported as assets on the consolidated balance sheets (Note 6).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P96_S0	Non-Consolidated VIEs The Partnership has variable interests in various entities in the form of MRBs, property loans and investments in unconsolidated entities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P96_S1	These variable interests do not allow the Partnership to direct the activities that most significantly impact the economic performance of such VIEs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P96_S2	As a result, the Partnership is not considered the primary beneficiary and does not consolidate the financial statements of these VIEs in the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P96_S3	The Partnership held variable interest in 23 and 20 non-consolidated VIEs at December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P96_S4	The following table summarizes the Partnerships variable interests in these entities at December 31, 2017 and 2016:
1059142_18_ITEM8_P97_S0	The maximum exposure to loss for the MRBs is equal to the cost adjusted for paydowns at December 31, 2017 and 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P97_S1	The difference between a MRB s carrying value on the consolidated balance sheets and the maximum exposure to loss is a function of the unrealized gains or losses on the MRB.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P98_S0	The maximum exposure to loss on the property loans at December 31, 2017 and 2016 is equal to the unpaid principal balance plus accrued interest.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P98_S1	The difference between a property loans carrying value and the maximum exposure is the value of loan loss allowances that have been recorded against the property loans.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P99_S0	Investments in Mortgage Revenue Bonds The Partnership owns MRBs that were issued by various state and local governments, their agencies and authorities to finance the construction or rehabilitation of income-producing real estate properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P99_S1	However, the MRBs do not constitute an obligation of any state or local government, agency or authority and no state or local government, agency or authority is liable on them, nor is the taxing power of any state or local government pledged to the payment of principal or interest on the MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P99_S2	The MRBs are non-recourse obligations of the respective owners of the properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P99_S3	The sole source of the funds to pay principal and interest on the MRBs is the net cash flow or the sale or refinancing proceeds from the properties.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P100_S0	Each MRB is collateralized by a mortgage on all real and personal property included in the related property.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P100_S1	The MRBs bear interest at a fixed rate and two of the mortgage revenue bonds provide for the payment of additional contingent interest that is payable from available net cash flow generated by the related property.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P101_S0	The following tables present information regarding the mortgage revenue bonds owned by the Partnership as of December 31, 2017 and 2016:
1059142_18_ITEM8_P102_S0	See Note 25 for a description of the methodology and significant assumptions for determining the fair value of the MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P103_S0	Unrealized gains or losses on the MRBs are recorded in the consolidated statements of comprehensive income to reflect changes in their estimated fair values resulting from market conditions and fluctuations in the present value of the expected cash flows from the MRBs.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P112_S0	7. PHC Certificates The Partnership owns 100% of the LIFERs of three TOB Trusts ( PHC Trusts ) sponsored by DB.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P112_S1	The TOB Trusts are consolidated VIEs (Note 5) and the Partnership consolidates the assets of the PHC Trusts in the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P113_S0	The assets held by the PHC Trusts consist of custodial receipts evidencing loans made to numerous public housing authorities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P113_S1	Principal and interest on these loans are payable by the respective public housing authorities out of annual appropriations to be made to the public housing authorities by under HUD s Capital Fund Program established under the Quality Housing and Work Responsibility Act of 1998 (the Capital Fund Program ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P113_S2	The PHC Trusts have a first lien on these annual Capital Fund Program payments to secure the public housing authorities respective obligations to pay principal and interest on their loans.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P113_S3	The loans payable by the public housing authorities are not debts, nor guaranteed by the government of the United States of America or HUD.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P113_S4	Interest payable on the public housing authority debt held by the PHC Trusts is exempt from federal income taxes.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P113_S5	The PHC Certificates issued by each of the PHC Trusts have been rated investment grade by Standard Poor s.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P113_S6	The Partnership had the following investments in the PHC Certificates on December 31, 2017 and 2016:
1059142_18_ITEM8_P114_S0	See Note 25 for a description of the methodology and significant assumptions for determining the fair value of the PHC Certificates.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P114_S1	Unrealized gains or losses on the PHC Certificates are recorded in the consolidated statements of comprehensive income to reflect changes in their estimated fair values resulting from market conditions and fluctuations in the present value of the expected cash flows from the PHC Certificates .
1059142_18_ITEM8_P115_S0	The Partnership recognized an impairment charge on PHC Certificate Trust I of approximately $762,000 during the year ended December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P115_S1	There were no impairment charges recorded for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P115_S2	See Note 2 for information considered in the Partnership s evaluation of impairment of the PHC Certificates.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P116_S1	The Partnership then collapsed the related three remaining MBS Trusts and paid all obligations in full from the proceeds of the sales.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P118_S0	The MBS Securities are backed by residential mortgage loans and interest received is expected to be exempt from federal income taxation.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P119_S3	The general partner of Northern View is an unaffiliated party and its 1% ownership interest is reflected in the Partnership s consolidated financial statements as noncontrolling interest.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P142_S2	The following table summarizes income tax expense for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015:
1059142_18_ITEM8_P143_S0	The Partnership s income tax expense fluctuates from period to period based on the timing of the taxable income.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P143_S1	Deferred income tax expense is generally a function of the period s temporary differences (i.e. depreciation, amortization of finance costs, etc.), and the utilization of net operating losses generated in prior years that had been previously recognized as a deferred income tax asset.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P143_S2	The deferred tax assets and liabilities are valued based on enacted tax rates, including consideration of the Jobs and Tax Cuts Act of 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P143_S3	This legislation reduced the maximum corporate income tax rate from 35% to 21% and resulted in a net deferred income tax benefit to the Partnership of approximately $15,000 for the year ended December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P143_S4	The net operating loss carryover reported on the Greens Hold Co 2015 tax return was utilized in its entirety in 2016 due to the gain on sale of the Arboretum.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P143_S5	Accordingly, all valuation allowances, totaling $405,000, were reversed during the year ended December 31, 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P144_S0	For the years ended December 31, 2017, income taxes computed by applying the U.S. Federal statutory rates to income from continuing operations before income taxes for the Greens Hold Co differ from the provision for income taxes due primarily to state income taxes (net of the effect on federal income tax) and the impact of tax rate changes on deferred income tax asset and liabilities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P144_S1	For the years ended December 31, 2016, income taxes computed by applying the U.S. Federal statutory rates to income from continuing operations before income taxes for the Greens Hold Co differ from the provision for income taxes due primarily to state income taxes (net of the effect on federal income tax) and the impact of changes in NOL valuation allowances.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P145_S0	The Partnership accrues interest and penalties associated with uncertain tax positions as part of income tax expense.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P145_S1	There was no accrued interest or penalties at December 31, 2017 and 2016.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P156_S0	(2) The variable rate is indexed to LIBOR plus an applicable margin.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P157_S0	The Partnership has entered into an unsecured Credit Agreement (the Credit Agreement ) for a Line of Credit ( non-operating LOC ) of up to $50.0 million with Bankers Trust, the Partnership s sole lead arranger and administrative agent.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P157_S1	The Credit Agreement originated in March 2015 and was subsequently amended.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P157_S2	In April 2017, the available commitment was increased $10.0 million to a total commitment of $50.0 million.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P157_S3	The non-operating LOC bears interest at a variable rate equal to 3.0% plus the 30-day London Interbank Offered Rate ( LIBOR ) as of December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S0	The principal amount of each acquisition advance is due on the 270th day following the advance date (the Repayment Date ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S1	The Partnership may extend any Repayment Date for up to three additional 90-day periods.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S2	In order to extend the Repayment Date, the Partnership must make principal payments equal to 5% of the original advance for the first extension, 10% for the second extension, and 20% for the third extension.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S3	The Repayment Date may not be extended beyond the stated maturity of the non-operating LOC.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S4	The Repayment Dates for the balance outstanding at December 31, 2017, exclusive of available extensions, range from June 2018 to September 2018.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S5	The proceeds of the non-operating LOC will be used by the Partnership for the purchase of multifamily real estate, taxable MRBs, MRBs, PHC certificates, or mortgage-backed securities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S6	The Partnership intends to repay each advance either through alternative long-term debt or equity financing.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S7	The non-operating LOC contains a covenant, among others, that the Partnership s ratio of the lender s senior debt will not exceed a specified percentage of the market value of the Partnership s assets, as defined in the Credit Agreement.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S8	The Partnership is in compliance with all covenants at December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S9	During 2017 and 2016, the Partnership had an unsecured operating LOC with Bankers Trust with a maturity date in May 2019.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S10	In March 2016, the available commitment on the operating LOC was increased from $5.0 million to $7.5 million.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P158_S11	In May 2017, the available commitment on the operating LOC was further increased to $10 million.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P159_S0	The operating LOC bears interest at a variable rate equal to 3.25% plus the 30-day LIBOR.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P159_S1	The Partnership is required to make prepayments of the principal to reduce outstanding principal balance on the operating line to zero for fifteen consecutive days during each calendar quarter.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P159_S2	The Partnership fulfilled this requirement during the three months ended December 31, 2017 and the first quarter of 2018.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P166_S0	The Partnership executed a Master Trust Agreement with DB which allows the Partnership to execute multiple TOB, Term TOB and Term A/B Trust (collectively, Trusts ) structures upon the approval and agreement of terms by DB.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P166_S1	Under each TOB Trust structure, the trustee issues SPEARS and LIFERS that represent beneficial interests in the securitized asset held by the TOB Trusts.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P166_S2	Under each Term TOB and Term A/B Trust structure, the trustee issues Class A and Class B Certificates that represent beneficial interests in the securitized asset held by the Term TOB or Term A/B Trusts.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P166_S3	DB has purchased the SPEARS and Class A Certificates and the Partnership has retained the LIFERS and Class B Certificates of each Trust.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P166_S4	Pursuant to the terms of the Trusts, the Partnership is required to reimburse DB for any shortfall realized on the contractual cash flows on the SPEARS or Class A Certificates.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P166_S5	The LIFERS and Class B Certificates grant the Partnership certain rights to the securitized assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P166_S6	The Trusts are VIEs, and the Partnership is the primary beneficiary due to its rights to the underlying assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P166_S7	The Partnership consolidates the Trusts in the consolidated financial statements accordingly.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P167_S0	The Partnership is required to meet certain covenants under the Master Trust Agreement.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P167_S1	At December 31, 2017, the most restrictive covenant requiring that cash available to distribute plus interest expense for the trailing twelve months must be at least twice the trailing twelve-month interest expense.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P167_S2	On December 31, 2017, the Partnership was in compliance with all covenants.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P167_S3	If the Partnership were to be out of compliance with any of these covenants, it would trigger a termination event of the financing facilities.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P168_S0	The variable TOB Financings at December 31, 2017 and 2016 are secured by three PHC Certificates (See Note 7).

1059142_18_ITEM8_P175_S0	At December 31, 2017 and 2016, the Partnership, through three wholly-owned subsidiaries (collectively, the Sponsors ), sponsored three separate TEBS Financings the M24 TEBS Financing ( TEBS I ), M31 TEBS Financing ( TEBS II ) and M33 TEBS Financing ( TEBS III ).
1059142_18_ITEM8_P175_S1	The TEBS Financings are structured such that the Partnership transfers MRBs to Freddie Mac to be securitized into the TEBS Financings.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P175_S2	Freddie Mac then issues Class A and Class B Freddie Mac Multifamily Variable Rate Certificates (collectively, the TEBS Certificates ), which represent beneficial interests in the securitized assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P175_S3	The Class A TEBS Certificates are sold to unaffiliated investors and entitle the holders to cash flows from the securitized assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P175_S4	The Class B TEBS Certificates are retained by the Sponsors and grant the Partnership rights to certain cash flows from the securitized assets after payment to the Class A Certificates and related facility fees, as well as certain other rights to the securitized assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P176_S0	Financings are VIEs, and the Partnership is the primary beneficiary due to its rights to the underlying assets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P176_S1	The Partnership consolidates the TEBS Financings in the consolidated financial statements accordingly.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P176_S2	See Note 6 for information regarding the MRBs securitized within each TEBS Financing.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P177_S0	Under the terms of TEBS Financings, the Sponsors have one extension option for each TEBS to extend the term for a set additional period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P177_S1	At the end of the original term of TEBS I in September 2017, the Partnership elected to extend the term of the financing for an additional three-year period through September 2020.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P177_S2	At the end of the original term of TEBS II in July 2019, the Partnership may elect to extend the financing for an additional five-year period through July 2024.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P177_S3	At the end of the original term of TEBS III in July 2020, the Partnership may elect to extend the financing for an additional five-year period through July 2025.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P177_S4	Should the Sponsors elect not to extend the terms of TEBS II and TEBS III, the Sponsor must pay all remaining amounts due to the Class A Certificates plus any unpaid trust fees.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P178_S0	The terms of the TEBS Financings require the Partnership to fund cash into certain escrow accounts.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P178_S1	Balances in the escrow accounts are reported as restricted cash on the consolidated balance sheets at December 31, 2017 and 2016.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P178_S2	There were three unscheduled paydowns during 2017, one each for TEBS I, TEBS II and TEBS III, due to redemptions of MRBs held by the respective TEBS.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P187_S1	The Partnership paid approximately $139,000 and $358,000 for the interest rate derivatives, respectively.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P188_S1	The Partnership paid approximately $59,000 for the interest rate derivative.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P189_S0	The Partnership has contracted for two interest rate swaps with DB.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P189_S1	On a quarterly basis, the Partnership reassesses its interest rate swap positions.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P189_S2	In the second quarter of 2017, the Partnership determined that due to the stabilization of the Decatur Angle and Bruton MRB properties and securitization of the related MRBs into fixed rate Term A/B Trust financings, the interest rate swaps were not needed to mitigate interest rate risk on financings related to the MRBs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P189_S3	The Partnership then determined that the interest rate swaps are intended to mitigate interest rate risk for the variable rate PHC TOB Trusts.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P190_S0	The Partnership is required to fund a cash collateral account at DB for an amount greater than or equal to the fair value of the interest rate swaps.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P190_S1	Such cash balances were approximately $850,000 and $1.4 million at December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively, and are reported within restricted cash on the consolidated balance sheets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P191_S0	These interest rate derivatives and interest rate swaps are not designated as hedging instruments and, accordingly, they are recorded at fair value with changes in fair value included in current period earnings as interest expense.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P191_S1	See Note 25 for a description of the methodology and significant assumptions for determining the fair value of the interest rate derivatives and interest rate swap arrangements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P191_S2	The interest rate derivatives are presented within other assets and the interest rate swap arrangements are reported as a derivative swap liability on the consolidated balance sheets.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P192_S0	Commitments and Contingencies The Partnership, from time to time, may be subject to various legal proceedings and claims that arise in the ordinary course of business.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P192_S1	These matters are frequently covered by insurance.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P193_S0	If it has been determined that a loss is probable to occur, the estimated amount of the loss is accrued in the consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P193_S1	While the resolution of these matters cannot be predicted with certainty, the Partnership believes the outcome of such matters will not have a material effect on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P194_S0	Bond Purchase Commitments As part of the Partnership s strategy of acquiring MRBs, the Partnership will enter into bond purchase commitments related to MRBs to be issued and secured by properties under construction.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P194_S1	Upon execution of the bond purchase commitment, the proceeds from the MRBs will be used to pay off the construction related debt.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P194_S2	The Partnership bears no construction or stabilization risk during the commitment period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P194_S3	The Partnership accounts for its bond purchase commitments as available-for-sale securities and reports the asset or liability at fair value.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P194_S4	Changes in the fair value of bond purchase commitments are recorded in other comprehensive income.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P199_S2	Other Guarantees In March 2017, the Partnership entered into a guaranty agreement whereby the Partnership has guaranteed payment of the construction loan of Vantage at Panama City Beach, LLC.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P199_S3	The Partnership will only have to perform on the guarantee upon a default by Vantage at Panama City Beach, LLC.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P199_S4	The guarantee is initially for the entire amount of the construction loan and decreases to 50% and 25% as certain debt service coverage levels are obtained by the borrower.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P199_S5	The construction loan has a maximum available balance of $25.6 million.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P199_S6	The outstanding balance on the construction loan was approximately $8.6 million at December 31, 2017, which is the Partnership s current exposure under the guarantee.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P199_S7	No amount has been accrued for this contingent liability because the likelihood of a guarantee claim is remote.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P199_S8	The Partnership is also required to maintain minimum cash and net worth requirements, which were met at December 31, 2017.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P200_S0	Pursuant to the sale of the Greens Property in 2012, the Partnership entered into guarantee agreements with an unaffiliated entity under which the Partnership has guaranteed certain obligations of the general partner of the Greens of Pine Glen limited partnership, including an obligation to repurchase the interests of BC Partners if certain repurchase events occur.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P200_S1	Remaining potential repurchase events relate primarily to the delivery of LIHTCs, or tax credit recapture and foreclosure.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P200_S2	No amount has been accrued for this contingent liability because the likelihood of a repurchase event is remote.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P200_S3	The maximum exposure to the Partnership at December 31, 2017, under the guarantee provision of the repurchase clause is approximately $2.6 million and represents 75% of the equity contributed by BC Partners.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P200_S4	The term of the guarantee agreement ends in 2027.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P201_S1	Remaining potential repurchase events relate primarily to the delivery of LIHTCs, or tax credit recapture and foreclosure.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P201_S4	The term of the guarantee agreement ends in 2026.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P201_S5	The 50/50 MF Property has a ground lease with the University of Nebraska-Lincoln with an initial lease term expiring in March 2038.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P201_S6	There is also an option to extend the lease for an additional five-year period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P201_S7	Annual lease payments are $100 per year.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P202_S0	cash is available at the property, to the University of Nebraska-Lincoln based on its revenues.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P202_S1	At December 31, 2017, the minimum aggregate annual payment due under the agreement is approximately $127,000.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P202_S2	The minimum aggregate annual payment increases 2% annually until July 31, 2034 and increases of 3% annually thereafter.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P202_S3	The 50/50 MF Property may be required to make additional payments under the agreement if its gross revenues exceed certain thresholds.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P202_S4	The agreement will terminate upon termination of the ground lease.

1059142_18_ITEM8_P202_S6	The Partnership reported expenses related to the agreement of approximately $168,000, $168,000 and $120,000 for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P203_S0	As the holder of residual interests issued in its TOB Trust, Term A/B Trust and TEBS Financing arrangements, the Partnership is required to guarantee certain losses that can be incurred by the trusts created in connection with these financings.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P203_S1	These guarantees may result from a downgrade in the investment rating of PHCs held by the trust or of the senior securities issued by the trust, a ratings downgrade of the liquidity provider for the trust, increases in short term interest rates beyond pre-set maximums, an inability to re-market the senior securities or an inability to obtain liquidity for the trust.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P204_S0	In the case of the TEBS, Freddie Mac will step in first on an immediate basis and the Partnership will have 10 to 14 days to remedy.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P204_S1	If the Partnership does not remedy, the trust will be collapsed.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P204_S2	If such an event occurs, the trust collateral may be sold and if the proceeds are not sufficient to pay the principal amount of the senior securities plus accrued interest and other trust expenses, the Partnership will be required to fund any such shortfall pursuant to its guarantee.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P204_S3	If the Partnership does not fund the shortfall, the default and liquidation provisions will be invoked against the Partnership.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P204_S4	In the event of a shortfall the maximum exposure to loss would be approximately $562.6 million prior to the consideration of the proceeds from the sale of the trust collateral.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P204_S5	The Partnership has never been, and does not expect in the future, to be required to reimburse the financing facilities for any shortfall.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P205_S0	Redeemable Series A Preferred Units The Partnership has issued non-cumulative, non-voting, non-convertible Series A Preferred Units via private placements to five financial institutions.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P205_S1	The Series A Preferred Units have no stated maturity, are not subject to any sinking fund requirements, and will remain outstanding indefinitely unless repurchased or redeemed by the Partnership or holder.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P205_S2	Upon the sixth anniversary of the closing of the sale of Series A Preferred Units to a subscriber, and upon each anniversary thereafter, the Partnership and each holder of Series A Preferred Units will have the right to redeem, in whole or in part, the Series A Preferred Units held by such holder at a per unit redemption price equal to $10.00 per unit plus an amount equal to all declared and unpaid distributions.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P205_S3	In the event of any liquidation, dissolution, or winding up of the Partnership, the holders of the Series A Preferred Units are entitled to a liquidation preference in connection with their investments.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P205_S4	With respect to anticipated quarterly distributions and rights upon liquidation, dissolution, or the winding-up of the Partnership s affairs, the Series A Preferred Units will rank senior to the Partnership s BUCs and to any other class or series of Partnership interests or securities expressly designated as ranking junior to the Series A Preferred Units , and junior to any other class or series of Partnership interests or securities expressly designated as ranking senior to the Series A Preferred Units .

1059142_18_ITEM8_P208_S1	RUAs are generally granted with vesting conditions ranging from three months to approximately three years.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P208_S2	RUAs currently provide for the payment of distributions during the restriction period.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P208_S3	The RUAs provide for accelerated vesting if there is a change in control or death or disability of the participant.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P208_S4	The fair value of each RUA is estimated on the grant date based on the Partnership s exchange-listed closing price of the BUCs.
1059142_18_ITEM8_P208_S5	The Partnership recognizes compensation expense for the RUAs on a straight-line basis over the requisite vesting period.
